The reorganization seeks to enhance collaboration and shareholder value through the energy transition.

title: Phillips 66 increases ambition of GHG emissions reduction targets
summary: Following sustained investor pressure, Phillips 66 has become the first U.S. refiner and second U.S. oil company to set Scope 3 emissions targets, pledging a 15% reduction in emissions intensity by 2030, alongside a 30% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 operational emissions intensity. This move, seen as a significant precedent for the industry, highlights the impact of investor engagement in pushing oil and gas companies towards more comprehensive climate commitments. While investors welcomed this, they continue to engage for more ambitious targets, particularly regarding absolute emissions reductions rather than intensity-based goals.

title: Chevron kicks off oil industry's Q4 results with a miss
summary: Chevron (CVX.N) reported fourth-quarter profits that missed Wall Street estimates and provided a weak outlook for this year's oil and gas production, causing its shares to drop. The company's earnings of $2.65 per share were below the $3.12 per share forecast, largely due to weaker output, downstream margins, and a hit from timing of bookings in its LNG business. Despite this, Chevron achieved its best annual earnings since 2014, driven by spending cuts, and announced increased shareholder returns including a share buyback and a dividend hike.

title: Chevron, Marathon raise quarterly dividend as energy prices rally
summary: Chevron Corp and Marathon Oil Corp both announced increases to their quarterly dividends, joining other U.S. oil and gas companies in returning cash to shareholders. This move comes as fuel demand rebounds and energy prices, including U.S. oil prices, have significantly risen. Chevron increased its dividend to $1.42 per share, while Marathon raised its dividend by 16.7% to 7 cents per share.

title: Noble Energy investors lose bid to sue over $5 bln Chevron deal
summary: A Delaware judge dismissed a class action lawsuit filed by former Noble Energy shareholders against the company's directors. The shareholders alleged that the directors pushed for Chevron Corp.'s $5 billion acquisition of Noble Energy to boost their pandemic-affected stock packages and rejected a higher 2018 offer for the same reason. The court found that the board adequately disclosed information and shareholders were fully informed to vote on the 2020 deal.

title: Noble Energy’s $5 Billion Chevron Deal Beats Investor Challenge
summary: A Delaware judge dismissed a lawsuit challenging Noble Energy Inc.'s $5 billion sale to Chevron Corp., ruling that investors were adequately informed about the deal before their approval vote. The court rejected claims that Noble's former board withheld material information, including a previous $6 billion offer for only some assets and details about executive change-in-control benefits, deeming such information immaterial to the shareholder decision. The ruling emphasizes that directors only need to provide accurate and complete disclosure of material information to obtain a stockholder vote.

title: Chevron shares touch record high ahead of Q4 results
summary: Shares of U.S. oil major Chevron Corp touched an all-time high intraday on Wednesday, boosted by a strong stock market rally and rising oil prices, ahead of its fourth-quarter financial results. Oil prices reached $90 a barrel for the first time in seven years, leading to a surge in major producers' stocks. Analysts anticipate Chevron to report earnings per share of $3.12 for the fourth quarter.

title: Oil majors TotalEnergies and Chevron withdraw from Myanmar
summary: Oil majors TotalEnergies and Chevron have announced their withdrawal from Myanmar, citing the worsening humanitarian situation after the 2021 coup. They were partners in the Yadana gas project and MGTC transportation system. TotalEnergies evaluated that "the junta is settled in power and our analysis is that, unfortunately, it is there to stay," leading to their decision to initiate the contractual process of withdrawing without financial compensation.

title: Oil giants Total, Chevron to leave Myanmar citing human rights
summary: TotalEnergies and Chevron Corp announced their withdrawal from Myanmar due to the worsening human rights situation and rule of law following the military coup in February 2021. Total stated their presence no longer allowed them to make a sufficiently positive contribution, and human rights groups largely welcomed the move. The companies were involved in the Yadana gasfield and MGTC transportation system.

title: Desert delight Living and working in Midland
summary: This article showcases the experience of ConocoPhillips employees living and working in Midland, Texas, particularly after the integration with Concho Resources. Employees describe Midland as a family-friendly community with strong ties to the oil and gas industry, offering unique advantages like proximity to Permian assets and a welcoming culture, despite not having all the amenities of a larger city. The piece highlights the work-life balance, community spirit, and career opportunities available in this energetic desert community.

title: Transocean's Offshore Drilling Rig to Drill Carbon Injection Well in Norway
summary: Transocean's drilling rig, the Transocean Enabler, will be used by Equinor to drill a carbon injection well in Norway for the Northern Lights Carbon Capture Storage Project. This project is a joint venture by Equinor, Shell, and TotalEnergies, aiming to establish Europe's first cross-border CO2 transport and storage network to mitigate emissions. Transocean highlighted its participation as an example of leveraging its core competencies for renewable and alternative energy projects.

title: W&T Offshore expands in Gulf of Mexico with $47M acquisition
summary: W&T Offshore is expanding its operations in the Gulf of Mexico through a new $47 million acquisition. CEO Tracy Krohn stated that the current environment for acquisitions in the Gulf remains favorable. This move highlights the company's continued investment and growth strategy in the region.

title: Sempra CLO Carolyn Benton Aiman: ‘DEI Should Be in a Corporate Legal Department’s DNA’
summary: The article spotlights Carolyn Benton Aiman, Chief Legal Officer of Sempra Infrastructure, and her unwavering commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). Aiman, a finalist for the 2021 Houston Corporate Counsel Award for Achievement in Diversity and Inclusion, emphasizes that DEI should be a fundamental part of a corporate legal department's operations, akin to a company's safety culture. She advocates for leaders to actively model inclusive behaviors and ensure their actions align with their words to promote true inclusivity within the legal profession and beyond.

title: Commodities Notched Their Best Year Since 2009, Despite Precious Metals Weakness
summary: Commodities experienced their best year since 2009, with the Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index gaining 27% in 2021, driven largely by energy prices. Precious metals, however, were the worst-performing category, with gold down 3.6% blamed on expectations of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates. The article highlights the resurgence of fossil fuels due to increased demand and discusses various market trends across emerging markets, energy, and digital currencies.

title: Insight: Harmful soot unchecked as Big Oil battles EPA over testing
summary: A deadly form of soot pollution from U.S. refineries, known as condensable fine particulate matter, has gone unregulated for decades due to a dispute between the U.S. oil industry and federal environmental officials over measurement methods. This delay has led to significant unchecked emissions, with regional regulators in California attempting to crack down, sparking litigation from oil refiners like Chevron Corp and PBF Energy Inc. The EPA acknowledges issues with its current testing method but continues research, while environmental scientists warn against further delays in regulation.

title: Chevron agrees to transfer part of offshore Suriname field to Shell
summary: Chevron Corp has agreed to transfer one-third of its 60% equity interest in an offshore Suriname block to Royal Dutch Shell. This agreement, a "farmout" contract, means Shell will join Suriname's state oil company, Staatsolie, which retains its 40% stake in the Block 5 venture. The deal highlights growing interest in Suriname's offshore oil exploration.

title: Chevron Technology Ventures President Barbara Burger to retire after 34 years at Chevron
summary: Barbara Burger, President of Chevron Technology Ventures, is retiring after 34 years with Chevron Corp. Chevron Technology Ventures was established in 1999 to integrate external technologies into Chevron's core business operations.

title: Chevron Phillips Chemical gives green light to propylene expansion in Baytown
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical has made a final investment decision (FID) to proceed with a propylene expansion project in Baytown, Texas. The company will add a new propylene splitter unit to its Cedar Bayou facility. This unit is expected to be operational in 2023 and will have a substantial annual production capacity of 1 billion pounds.

title: Caterpillar, BNSF and Chevron inks MoU for H2-fuel cells powered locomotive demonstration
summary: Caterpillar, BNSF Railway Company, and Chevron U.S.A. Inc. have signed an MOU to demonstrate a hydrogen fuel cell-powered locomotive, aiming to confirm its feasibility and performance as a lower-carbon alternative to traditional fuels for line-haul rail. Progress Rail will design and build the prototype, Chevron will develop the fueling infrastructure, and BNSF will demonstrate the locomotive on its lines. This collaboration represents a significant step towards advancing hydrogen technology in heavy-duty transport and exploring a commercially viable hydrogen economy.

title: Chevron Announces Leadership Changes
summary: Chevron Corporation announced that Barbara J. Burger, vice president of innovation and president of Chevron Technology Ventures (CTV), will retire, effective February 1, 2022. Jim Gable, currently vice president of Downstream Technology & Services, will succeed Burger. This change reflects Chevron's ongoing focus on leadership transition and the continued development of externally integrated technologies within its innovation arm.

title: Nigeria Overhauls Its Oil and Gas Laws with Petroleum Industry Act – Publications
summary: Nigeria has passed the Petroleum Industry Act (PIA) to overhaul its oil and gas laws, aiming to foster a business-friendly environment and make its economy gas-powered by 2030. The PIA introduces significant reforms in governance, upstream operations, gas exploitation, fiscal regimes, and host community protection. These changes are designed to adapt to global energy transitions while addressing the economic prospects of oil-producing regions.

title: Iraq says Halliburton, Exxon in talks for stake in oil field
summary: Iraq's energy minister stated that Halliburton Co. and Exxon Mobil Corp. are discussing Exxon's sale of its stake in the West Qurna-1 oil field. Iraq prefers a U.S. partner for Exxon's stake but would buy it through Basra Oil Co. if talks with Halliburton fail. The article also mentions current OPEC+ production plans and Chevron's potential investment in southern Iraq.

title: Brookstone: Powell Stares Down Inflation But Our Gauge Reads 100% Bullish
summary: The article discusses how Fed Chair Powell's actions signal an earlier end to asset purchasing to allow for rate hikes, amidst ongoing global economic challenges like supply chain issues and energy market volatility. Despite these headwinds, FormulaFolios' Recession Probability Index is low at 27.58, and their Bull/Bear indicator is 100% bullish, suggesting a higher likelihood of stock market increases in the near term. The authors emphasize the importance of maintaining long-term investment discipline during volatile times.

title: ICE says new Midland WTI futures contract to go live in late January
summary: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) announced its new Midland WTI American Gulf Coast futures contract will go live in late January, aiming to create a new U.S. light sweet index reflecting crude exports. This contract is a restructuring of the ICE Permian WTI crude oil futures, designed to offer greater liquidity and stability following the historic collapse of WTI futures in 2020. It includes oil from Enterprise's ECHO terminal and Magellan Houston terminal, significantly increasing the underpinning supply capacity.

title: ConocoPhillips buys Shell’s Permian business for $9.5bn
summary: ConocoPhillips has acquired Shell's Permian Basin assets in the US for $9.5 billion, encompassing 225,000 net acres and producing properties. This acquisition is expected to improve ConocoPhillips' business drivers, enhance cash flow, and lower its GHG intensity. Shell plans to use the proceeds primarily for shareholder distributions and balance sheet strengthening.

title: CVS Health, Microsoft Partner To Bring ‘Digital First’ Care To Customers
summary: CVS Health and Microsoft Corp. announced a five-year partnership to personalize care for CVS's over 100 million customers, utilizing Microsoft's technology and cloud services. The collaboration aims to accelerate CVS's digital transformation, deliver customized health recommendations, improve medication adherence, and enhance operational efficiency for front-line workers. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the initiative focuses on leveraging data and technology to improve customer experience and care delivery.

title: Court hears Steven Donziger's criminal appeal in Chevron saga
summary: A federal appeals court in Manhattan heard arguments regarding the criminal conviction of environmental lawyer Steven Donziger. His lawyers contend that the private attorneys appointed as special federal prosecutors in his contempt case lacked proper supervision, violating the Constitution's Appointments Clause. Donziger's conviction stems from his long-running legal battle with Chevron Corp over oil pollution in Ecuador.

title: US legislators call for release of environmental lawyer Donziger
summary: Nine US legislators have urged the Justice Department to release environmental lawyer Steven Donziger, who was sentenced to six months in prison for criminal contempt after battling Chevron Corp over pollution in Ecuador. Donziger had won a $9.5bn judgment against Chevron in an Ecuadorian court, which was later rejected by a US judge, leading to his disbarment and subsequent contempt conviction. The legislators argue the case chills environmental advocacy and call for immediate action from Attorney General Merrick Garland.

title: Chevron shuts Australian Gorgon LNG Train 1 after minor gas leak
summary: Chevron has idled Train 1 at its Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant in Western Australia following the discovery of a minor gas leak. The leak, located on piping associated with the dehydration unit, prompted a precautionary shutdown, though the company continues to deliver LNG from Trains 2 and 3 and gas to Western Australia. It is currently unclear how long the unit will remain down for investigation and repairs.

title: Phillips 66 Converting Louisiana Refinery
summary: Phillips 66 announced plans to convert its Alliance Refinery in Belle Chasse, Louisiana, to a terminal facility in 2022. This decision was made after evaluating repair costs following Hurricane Ida and considering the site's value as a midstream asset. The conversion will impact approximately 900 employees and contractors, and Phillips 66 plans to support them through the transition while maintaining its role as a major refiner.

title: Gevo investing in corn-based aviation fuel, including restart of Minnesota plant
summary: Gevo is investing in corn-based aviation fuel, restarting its Luverne, Minnesota plant to produce isobutanol and convert it into a facility for sustainable aviation fuel. This plant will serve as a pilot site for Gevo's Net-Zero 1 production facility expected in 2024, aiming to supply major airlines looking to lower their carbon footprint. Gevo is also collaborating with ADM, Chevron, and Axens North America Inc. to accelerate the production and distribution of sustainable aviation fuel.

title: EOG Eyeing ‘Incredible Value’ for LNG Exports from Permian, Eagle Ford and Dorado
summary: EOG Resources Inc. plans to focus on returning value to shareholders rather than boosting production volumes, despite higher commodity prices. The company sees "incredible value" in exporting natural gas as LNG from its Permian, Eagle Ford Shale, and Dorado assets, and is also piloting a carbon capture and storage venture to reduce emissions. EOG reported sharply higher profits and production in 3Q2021, increased its dividend, and approved share repurchases.

title: An Environmental Hero or Outlaw? Can It Be Both? (Published 2021)
summary: Steven Donziger, a lawyer who won a $9.5 billion settlement against Chevron, began a six-month prison sentence for contempt of court, sparking debate over whether he is an environmental hero or an outlaw. The article explores the complexities of his case, including his controversial tactics against Chevron and why his supporters view him as a martyr, while critics highlight his rule-breaking. Ultimately, the piece reflects on how this polarized view often overshadows the continued suffering of the Ecuadorean tribespeople at the center of the original lawsuit.

title: NextEra Energy Stock Forecast: Sunny and Windy
summary: This article provides an in-depth forecast for NextEra Energy (NEE), positioning it as a leading renewable energy stock that offers both growth and dividend income. It highlights NextEra Energy's dual business model as the world's largest utility company (FPL) and largest generator of renewable energy (NextEra Energy Resources), and discusses how it stands to benefit from the $1.2 Trillion Infrastructure Bill and global shifts towards nuclear and wind energy. The article also benchmarks NEE's performance against various indices, concluding that its future looks bright given current market and political landscapes.

title: COP26: 15 Ways GE Is Helping To Bring About A More Sustainable Future | GE News
summary: This article details 15 ways GE is contributing to a more sustainable future, aligning with the goals of COP26. It highlights GE's commitments to carbon neutrality and net-zero emissions, along with innovations in sustainable aviation fuel, advanced wind turbine technology, hydrogen power, grid modernization, and small modular nuclear reactors. The initiatives demonstrate GE's diverse efforts to reduce carbon emissions across various industries.

title: Oil prices are up, but do not expect a gas-like crunch
summary: Oil prices are hovering above $80 per barrel due to OPEC+'s supply tightening, but a full-blown energy crisis is unlikely as economic growth is not strong enough to sustain high prices long-term. Despite the current tightening market and recovery in demand, the article argues that the primary driver of high oil prices is OPEC+'s political decision to restrict production rather than robust, sustained economic expansion. The abundance of OPEC spare capacity suggests that a "gas-like crunch" is not imminent, as long-term price developments hinge on true economic growth rather than temporary stimulus-driven recovery.

title: How Chevron imprisoned environmental lawyer Steven Donziger
summary: This article details the story of environmental lawyer Steven Donziger, who was imprisoned for contempt of court after successfully suing Chevron for $9.5 billion on behalf of Ecuadorian indigenous communities affected by oil pollution. It highlights Chevron's alleged campaign to discredit Donziger and avoid paying damages, as well as the international community's condemnation of his prosecution. The piece argues that Donziger's case sets a chilling precedent for environmental activism against powerful corporations.

title: Argentina bets on natural gas despite climate commitments
summary: Argentina is prioritizing the expansion of natural gas production and its pipeline network from the Vaca Muerta fields, despite its climate commitments to reduce emissions. President Alberto Fernández's government views natural gas as a key fuel for energy transition and export, aiming to save money on imports and boost the economy. Environmental organizations, however, argue that these plans contradict emission reduction targets and could lead to stranded assets, while highlighting environmental and social risks for local communities.

title: Oil and gas rally boosts Chevron's quarterly profit to 8-year high
summary: Chevron Corp reported its highest quarterly profit in eight years, reaching $6.11 billion, driven by surging oil and gas prices, increased output, and recovering motor fuel demand. The strong financial performance resulted in a significant increase in cash flow and boosted the company's shares. Chevron plans to continue its focus on oil production, adding drilling rigs and aiming for annual output increases through 2025.

title: A new 100-page report raises alarm over Chevron’s impact on planet
summary: A new 100-page independent report details Chevron's extensive history of environmental damages and its failure to pay the vast majority of court-ordered fines and settlements. The report highlights 70 ongoing cases in 31 countries, with only 0.006% of the $50.5 billion owed having been paid. It also notes the imprisonment of human rights lawyer Steven Donziger, who led a major case against Chevron in Ecuador.

title: Suncor doubles dividend as oil price surge powers profit
summary: Suncor Energy Inc doubled its dividend after posting a third-quarter profit, benefiting from a rebound in crude prices. The Canadian oil and gas producer generated strong free cash flow due to soaring energy prices and growing global fuel demand, reinstating its dividend to pre-pandemic levels. The company's production and refinery throughput also saw significant increases compared to the previous year.

title: Chevron foe Donziger surrenders after losing bid to avert prison
summary: Disbarred lawyer Steven Donziger, known for his legal battle with Chevron Corp, surrendered to federal authorities after an appeals court denied his request to delay his six-month prison term for criminal contempt. Donziger's lawyer confirmed his surrender and custody at a federal prison in Connecticut. The contempt conviction stems from Donziger's failure to comply with court orders related to a civil case against Chevron.

title: Tsakos: A life in shipping
summary: Dr. Nikolas Tsakos, founder, CEO, and president of Tsakos Energy Navigation (TEN), discusses his life in shipping, the legacy of his family, and his vision for the future of the tanker industry. Despite a challenging year for tankers, Tsakos is optimistic about a comeback and emphasizes the importance of owner communication and sustainable practices, advocating for improved existing fuel infrastructure over radical new solutions for decarbonization. The article highlights his early career, the founding of TEN, and his views on industry challenges like decarbonization and the fragmentation of the tanker sector.

title: Marathon is committed to meet current, future needs
summary: Marathon Petroleum Corp. details its commitment to meeting today's energy demands while simultaneously investing in a sustainable and energy-diverse future, particularly at its Detroit refinery. The company highlights its efforts in emissions and water-use reduction, community engagement through grants and volunteer work, and investment in emerging technologies. This piece emphasizes the dual focus of providing current essential petroleum products and developing sustainable practices for the future.

title: Traders Keep GUSHing Over This Oil and Gas ETF
summary: Bullish traders in the oil and gas sector are profiting from leveraged ETFs like the Direxion Daily S&P Oil & Gas Exp. & Prod. Bull 2X Shares (GUSH), which has seen significant gains. The article highlights that rising gasoline and crude-oil prices, driven by a confluence of factors, are translating into substantial returns for these traders, despite consumer pain at the pump. GUSH has delivered a 185% gain on the year, showcasing a strong rebound from previous losses.

title: Chevron Is Playing Americans for Fools with ‘Green’ Ad Blitz
summary: Chevron has aired nearly 30,000 "green" ads over the past 15 months, portraying itself as committed to sustainability, despite its abysmal climate record and minimal investment in lower-carbon energy. Environmental groups have filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission, accusing the company of deceptive advertising given its significant contributions to greenhouse gas emissions and efforts to block climate action legislation. Critics argue this Ad blitz is a "greenwashing" tactic to maintain business as usual rather than a genuine shift towards environmental responsibility.

title: Daehan secures order for up to six LNG-fuelled tankers from TEN
summary: South Korea’s Daehan Shipbuilding has secured a contract from Greek owner Tsakos Energy Navigation (TEN) for the construction of four to six dual-fuelled LNG-powered aframax tankers. The deal, valued at approximately $418 million if all six ships are built, was delayed due to rising steel costs. The vessels are scheduled for delivery from September to December 2023 and are expected to generate around $350 million under a long-term contract with Norway’s Equinor.

title: Chevron commits to net zero operational emissions by 2050
summary: Chevron Corp (CVX.N) has announced a target to achieve net zero operational emissions by 2050, aligning with increasing pressure from investors and governments on energy companies to combat climate change. This commitment focuses on upstream and indirect emissions from its own operations. Unlike some European peers, Chevron's goals do not include greenhouse gases from all fuel products sold, but it plans to pivot towards low-carbon businesses and triple investments to reduce its carbon footprint.

title: Chevron Adopts Operational Net Zero ‘Aspiration’ by 2050
summary: Chevron (CVX) announced an "aspiration" to achieve net-zero emissions from its own operations by 2050, responding to increasing investor and societal pressure for a low-carbon future. The company also set a target to reduce carbon intensity by 5% from 2016 levels by 2028, encompassing Scope 3 emissions from its customers for the first time. This move signifies a shift towards cleaner production, even as higher output remains possible under these new targets.

title: Exclusive Analysis: In U.S. TV Ads, Chevron Motors Past Its Big Oil Competition in Boasting of Sustainability Accolades
summary: Chevron significantly outspent its major oil competitors (BP, Exxon Mobil, Shell) in U.S. television advertising between June 2020 and August 2021, airing nearly 30,000 ads focused heavily on sustainability. While other companies aired far fewer ads or focused on traditional oil and gas messaging, 80% of Chevron's airings featured sustainability-focused language, despite external skepticism about the industry's green transition claims. This advertising strategy contrasts with its competitors' more limited or product-focused ad campaigns during the same period.

title: How to Invest in Companies That Are Actually Helping the Environment
summary: ESG funds have gained popularity as investors seek to align their money with environmental concerns, but their effectiveness is debated due to broad definitions and limited regulation. This article explores how to identify truly sustainable investments, highlighting the vetting processes of fund managers and criteria for companies genuinely commitmed to environmental progress, urging investors to scrutinize reports and core business practices.

title: Disbarred lawyer who fought Chevron gets prison time for disobeying court orders
summary: Disbarred environmental lawyer Steven Donziger was sentenced to six months in prison for criminal contempt due to his repeated refusal to comply with court orders in a lawsuit brought against him by Chevron Corp. U.S. District Judge Loretta A. Preska highlighted Donziger's consistent defiance of the U.S. judicial system. The charges stemmed from his failure to surrender electronic devices, his passport, and attempts to monetize his interest in a $9.5 billion pollution judgment against Chevron.

title: US lawyer who sued Chevron sentenced to 6 months in contempt case
summary: US lawyer Steven Donziger, known for his two-decade legal battle against Chevron Corp over pollution in the Ecuadorian rainforest, has been sentenced to six months in prison for criminal contempt. The charges stem from his refusal to comply with court orders, including handing over electronic devices, despite his claims that he was being targeted for successfully winning a $9.5bn judgment against Chevron in Ecuador. Donziger plans to appeal the decision, which comes after two years of home confinement and a UN panel's call for his release.

title: TikTok Hero and Chevron Foe Donziger Gets Six Months in Jail
summary: Steven Donziger, the lawyer who won an $8.6 billion judgment against Chevron Corp., has been sentenced to six months in jail for contempt of court. This sentencing follows the judgment against Chevron being scrapped due to fraud and bribery, though Donziger retains significant support from environmental activists and public figures.

title: New Mexico drilling permit roundup: Spur Energy Partners LLC approved for seven drilling permits
summary: The New Mexico Oil Conservation Division recently approved 22 drilling permits, with Spur Energy Partners LLC receiving seven of them. Of the total permits, 11 were for Eddy County, nine for Lea County, and two for San Juan County. Other companies like EOG Resources Inc. and Mewbourne Oil Co. also secured 11 permits each.

title: Alshair Fiyaz Family Office Divests Shipping Asset in Transition toward Renewable Energy and Sustainable Investments
summary: ALFI Investments, the family office of Alshair Fiyaz, has divested its final oil shipping asset, the Suezmax crude oil tanker Cap Diamant, to refocus on sustainable investments. The capital from the sale will be redeployed into emerging energy transition opportunities like biofuels and green hydrogen. This move aligns with ALFI's strategy to achieve a "carbon-negative" portfolio and exit all fossil fuel investments within the next three to five years.

title: EXCLUSIVE Conoco offers to sell some secondary U.S. oil acreage -document
summary: ConocoPhillips is offering to sell approximately $500 million in conventional oil and gas properties in the U.S. Permian basin. This move follows two major shale acquisitions and aims to divest less valuable acreage as part of a broader plan to sell up to $5 billion in assets by 2023. RBC Capital Markets has been hired to manage the sale, with initial bids due on October 13th.

title: Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass Train 6 closer to service
summary: Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass Train 6 is moving closer to operation after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved the introduction of feed gas. The liquefied natural gas unit is now expected to come online in the first quarter of next year, earlier than initially anticipated. Cheniere also recently announced its first stock dividend of 33 cents per share, payable on November 17.

title: Exxon, Chevron conceal payments to some governments -watchdog
summary: U.S. oil majors Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp have reportedly failed to meet a core transparency standard set by the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI), a global anti-corruption body. EITI stated that these companies have declined to publicly disclose payments made to governments in countries that are not EITI members, despite having board seats on the organization. This lack of transparency contrasts with European-based oil companies like BP, Shell, and Total, which do disclose such payments.

title: Chevron sets goals for RNG, renewable diesel, SAF production
summary: Chevron has announced its goals for the production of renewable natural gas (RNG), renewable diesel, and sustainable aviation fuels (SAF). The company's focus on these areas signals a commitment to expanding its presence in the renewable energy sector. This move aligns with broader industry trends towards decarbonization and alternative fuel sources.

title: Disbarred Chevron foe Donziger pleads for time served sentence
summary: Disbarred lawyer Steven Donziger, found guilty of criminal contempt after two decades of legal battles against Chevron over rainforest pollution in Ecuador, has requested a Manhattan federal court to sentence him to time served. His lawyers argue that his nearly 800 days of home confinement since 2019 are "enough" punishment, highlighting the unique nature of his prosecution by private lawyers after the Southern District of New York declined to act. The contempt case originated from Donziger's failure to comply with court orders related to a $9.5 billion judgment against Chevron, which a U.S. judge deemed secured through bribery, fraud, and extortion.

title: As energy transition plays out, Shell exits Permian with $9.5 bln sale to ConocoPhillips
summary: Shell is selling its Permian Basin business for $9.5 billion in cash to ConocoPhillips as part of its strategy to shift towards renewable energy and meet its net-zero goals. ConocoPhillips will acquire 225k net acres with a current production of 175 thousand barrels equivalent per day, aiming to enhance its role in the energy transition with lower GHG intensity barrels and increasing its dividend. The deal, expected to close in Q4 2021, allows Shell to fund shareholder distributions and strengthen its balance sheet, while ConocoPhillips increases its divestment targets to help finance the acquisition.

title: ConocoPhillips’ $9.5B Deal For Shell’s Texas Oil Fields Spells End To Permian Consolidation Rush
summary: ConocoPhillips has acquired Shell's Permian Basin assets for $9.5 billion, marking the largest all-cash acquisition in the U.S. upstream sector in over three years. This deal signifies ConocoPhillips' deepened commitment to shale, particularly the Permian, following its $13.3 billion acquisition of Concho Resources, and likely signals an end to the rapid consolidation rush in the region. The transaction allows Shell to reduce its carbon footprint and distribute significant proceeds to shareholders, while ConocoPhillips expands its presence in the key oil-producing area at an attractive price point.

title: Shell exits Permian with $9.5 bln Texas shale sale to ConocoPhillips
summary: Royal Dutch Shell announced the sale of its Permian Basin assets to ConocoPhillips for $9.5 billion in cash, marking its exit from the largest U.S. oilfield as it refocuses on clean energy transitions. ConocoPhillips' acquisition of 225,000 net acres strengthens its position in U.S. shale, while both companies made moves related to shareholder returns and greenhouse gas emission targets. The deal highlights a divergence between European and U.S. producers regarding future hydrocarbon investments.

title: Royal Dutch Shell Sells Permian Basin Oil Holdings for $9.5 Billion (Published 2021)
summary: Royal Dutch Shell sold its Permian Basin oil holdings to ConocoPhillips for $9.5 billion in cash, marking a significant step for Shell toward cleaner energy production amidst investor and public pressure to reduce carbon emissions. This deal consolidates ConocoPhillips' position as a major player in the Permian Basin, which is seeing a recovery in American shale oil production and a wave of acquisitions. Shell's exit comes nine years after it acquired the field and developed it to produce about 200,000 barrels a day.

title: Suit claims BP trader sacked for raising Nigeria bribe concerns
summary: A former oil trader for British energy giant BP, Jonathan Zarembok, alleges he was fired for raising concerns about bribes being paid in Nigeria to secure local contracts. Zarembok claims BP paid "abnormally large" fees to a local agent and that the company's proposed reasons for these payments were a "sham." BP denies the allegations, stating that the payments were legitimate and thoroughly vetted, and that Zarembok's dismissal was due to an "irretrievably broken down" working relationship.

title: Newsletter: A hydrogen hub in Utah could power L.A.'s climate future. Now Chevron wants in
summary: A newsletter discusses how a hydrogen hub in Utah, initially planned to replace a coal plant with natural gas, is now aiming for 100% green hydrogen power for Los Angeles. Chevron Corp. plans to invest in the Advanced Clean Energy Storage project, which would store hydrogen in underground salt domes, sparking debate among activists about their commitment to clean energy versus continued focus on fossil fuels. The project presents a unique potential solution for large-scale energy storage in the Western U.S., but its success as a climate model remains to be seen.

title: Chevron CEO warns of high energy prices and supply crunches
summary: Chevron CEO Mike Wirth warns of sustained high energy prices due to producers' reluctance to invest in new projects despite surging commodity markets. Shareholders are prioritizing immediate cash returns over new developments, leading to potential supply shortages and economic risks. Environmental concerns and government policies are further constraining capital for the industry.

title: Chevron would rather pay dividends than invest in wind and solar -CEO
summary: Chevron's CEO Mike Wirth stated the company prefers to return money to shareholders through dividends rather than investing in wind and solar power projects. Wirth explained that these renewable sources generate low financial returns for stockholders, suggesting investors can use their dividends to directly fund renewable projects instead.

title: Landmark Legal Cases to Secure Clean Water and Clean Air as a Right For All
summary: Earthjustice highlights fifty years of landmark legal cases focused on securing clean water and clean air as a fundamental right. The article details significant victories, including those related to the Clean Air Act, Mercury & Air Toxics Standards, and the Clean Water Act, demonstrating how legal action holds polluters accountable and strengthens environmental protections across the nation and internationally. These cases range from local community protection to nationwide policy changes and international collaborations.

title: Chevron triples low-carbon investment, but avoids 2050 net-zero goals
summary: Chevron Corp pledged to triple its low-carbon investments to $10 billion through 2028, focusing on reducing its carbon emissions footprint. However, the company is not yet committing to a 2050 net-zero emissions target, citing concerns about realism and deliverability, a stance that diverges from European oil producers. The investment will be allocated across areas such as carbon capture, greenhouse gas reductions, renewable fuels, and hydrogen energy.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Chevron to Triple Low-Carbon Investment
summary: Chevron Corp. is set to triple its investment in low-carbon technologies, committing $10 billion through 2028. This move signifies the oil giant's increasing focus on businesses like biofuels, hydrogen production, and carbon capture. The new commitment is a significant increase from its previous pledge of approximately $3 billion.

title: Syngenta, Chevron Could Face Billions in Claims Over Weed Killer
summary: Syngenta AG and Chevron Corp. are facing a growing number of lawsuits, filed almost daily over the last seven months, alleging a link between their weed killer, Paraquat, and Parkinson’s disease in farmers and field workers. The companies could be liable for billions in claims as a result of these lawsuits. An Illinois judge is set to oversee these suits, signaling a significant legal challenge for the companies involved.

title: Mercuria gets into natural gas retail stations with Chevron JV
summary: Mercuria and Chevron have formed a joint venture to purchase American Natural Gas, a company operating 60 compressed natural gas stations across the U.S. This move marks Mercuria's entry into the natural gas retail station market. Compressed natural gas is presented as an alternative to traditional gasoline or diesel.

title: Chevron, Caterpillar announce collaboration agreement on hydrogen
summary: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. and Caterpillar Inc. have announced a collaboration agreement to develop hydrogen demonstration projects. The focus will be on transportation and stationary power applications, including a hydrogen-fueled locomotive and associated fueling infrastructure, to assess hydrogen's feasibility as a commercially viable alternative to traditional fuels. This initiative aims to advance a hydrogen economy and help customers achieve climate-related objectives.

title: Chevron to sell test batch of sustainable aviation fuel to Delta Air
summary: Chevron Corp plans to produce and sell a test batch of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to Delta Air Lines at Los Angeles International Airport. This initiative is part of a partnership with Google to track SAF emissions data using cloud-based technology. Delta aims to replace 10% of its jet fuel with SAF by 2030, and the companies hope to create a transparent model for analyzing greenhouse gas emission reductions.

title: Hurricane Ida: Chevron's Gulf of Mexico Platforms Appear Undamaged
summary: Chevron Corp reported on Wednesday that its offshore facilities in the Gulf of Mexico appeared to be undamaged after Hurricane Ida. The company has begun redeploying personnel to assess damage and restore production, while the Fourchon and Empire terminals and their related pipeline systems remain shut-in.

title: Offshore oil and gas producer Beacon makes major final investment decision in Gulf of Mexico
summary: Beacon Offshore Energy has made its first final investment decision (FID) on the deepwater Shenandoah discovery project in the Gulf of Mexico. This decision could elevate Beacon Offshore Energy to become one of the top 10 offshore producers in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. The project marks a significant milestone for the Houston-based oil and gas producer.

title: Venture Global, Cheniere Move Closer to Starting Up Louisiana LNG Projects
summary: Venture Global and Cheniere Energy are advancing their Louisiana LNG projects, with both Calcasieu Pass and Sabine Pass signaling potential startup by year-end. Venture Global's Calcasieu Pass is authorized to introduce feed gas, while Cheniere's Sabine Pass sixth train is expected to be fully operational in early 2022. These developments are poised to increase U.S. natural gas exports this winter to meet global LNG demand.

title: Exxon sting surfaces in climate litigation
summary: A secret recording of an Exxon Mobil Corp. lobbyist admitting to the company's obstruction of climate action has surfaced in climate change litigation against the oil giant. The recording, in which lobbyist Keith McCoy details how Exxon relied on "shadow groups" to deny scientific consensus on global warming, is being cited in a "friend of the court" brief in Minnesota’s climate lawsuit. This development is seen as a significant new data point, revealing an Exxon insider's admission of the company's historical and ongoing efforts to misrepresent climate science.

title: Many of Oklahoma's biggest businesses aren't mandating vaccines for employees. That could change.
summary: While many large businesses nationwide are implementing vaccine mandates, several prominent Oklahoma companies have not yet, though this could change following the FDA's full approval of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. Legal experts suggest this approval removes an impediment for employers considering mandates, leading to potential shifts in company policies across various industries including energy, retail, and tech. The article details current vaccine and mask policies of several major Oklahoma businesses, many of which are re-evaluating their stances.

title: Most flares from Texas Permian oil drilling lack permits -study
summary: A report by Earthworks claims that major oil producers like Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell are flaring gas in the Permian Basin without the required Texas state permits. The study found that between 69% and 84% of observed flares were likely unpermitted, despite industry claims of compliance and efforts to reduce flaring. Texas regulators, however, contend that Earthworks' analysis is flawed and based on incomplete data, as some unpermitted flaring is allowed under specific conditions.

title: Chevron Sees Brazil’s Pre-salt Oil as Prize Asset
summary: Chevron Corp is expressing strong interest in Brazil’s pre-salt oil discoveries, with its Brazil chief highlighting it as potentially the most important development in the company's long presence in the country. The company has held interests in 11 deep water projects since 2018 and is eyeing a December auction for licenses in two pre-salt blocks, following improved incentives from the Brazilian government. Despite past issues with high license fees and regulatory uncertainty, Chevron states incentives have improved, including a 70% reduction in signing bonuses, though further regulation and financial motivation are still needed for new oil projects.

title: Chevron Sees Brazil's Pre-salt Oil as Prize Asset
summary: Chevron Corp is keen to participate in Brazil's pre-salt oil discoveries, with its Brazil chief calling it a potentially crucial development for the company. The U.S. oil major is considering bidding in a December auction for pre-salt blocks, noting improved incentives compared to a stalled 2019 auction. However, the company emphasized the need for further regulatory and financial improvements to attract new oil investments in the country.

title: Natural Gas ETFs Bounce on Supportive Short-Term Fundamentals
summary: Natural gas exchange-traded funds performed well on Monday as natural gas prices rebounded due to supportive short-term fundamentals like higher LNG demand and lower production. While peak summer demand may have passed, analysts suggest a potential downside near-term before storage trajectories provide support. Weather forecasts show continued above-normal heat for the coming week, influencing price movements.

title: Refiner Boosts Battery Bet
summary: Phillips 66, a major U.S. oil refiner, is diversifying into battery technology by acquiring a 16% stake in Australian company Novonix Ltd. for $150 million. This investment supports the development of a domestic supply chain for EV and energy storage markets in the U.S., as Phillips 66 anticipates gasoline demand has already peaked. The company views battery materials as a significant growth opportunity and a hedge against declining demand for traditional fossil fuels.

title: Oil slips as COVID dampens outlook, again
summary: Oil prices dropped by 2 percent, extending previous losses, due to a rising US dollar and concerns over new COVID-19 restrictions in Asia, particularly China, which are dampening global fuel demand. Analysts point to the accelerating Delta variant and curbs in China, the world's second-largest oil consumer, as significant factors, despite expectations that the market can eventually absorb additional supply from OPEC+.

title: HollyFrontier and Holly Energy Partners Add Sinclair Dinosaur for $1.8B
summary: Dallas-based HollyFrontier Corporation and Holly Energy Partners announced an agreement to acquire and combine with Sinclair Oil from the Sinclair Corporation in a deal valued at $1.8 billion. The newly formed company will be called HF Sinclair Corporation, headquartered in Dallas, and will replace HollyFrontier in public trading on the NYSE. The acquisition includes Sinclair's market branding, commercial activities, renewable diesel business, and two Rocky Mountain area refineries, consistent with the company's growth strategy.

title: San Antonio-based NuStar sells 8 storage terminals to Sunoco in $250 million deal
summary: San Antonio-based NuStar Energy L.P. announced it is selling eight oil storage terminals to Sunoco LP for $250 million, representing 14.8 million barrels of storage capacity. The divestiture is part of NuStar's strategy to reduce its $3.4 billion debt and focus on core pipeline and storage assets, with the proceeds going towards improving debt metrics. Sunoco, in turn, will significantly expand its midstream business by acquiring these facilities and an additional terminal from Cato, Inc.

title: Devon, Conoco Said to Study $10 Billion Shell Permian Assets
summary: Devon Energy Corp. and ConocoPhillips are reportedly evaluating Royal Dutch Shell Plc’s Permian Basin oil fields for a potential acquisition, which could be valued at up to $10 billion. Chevron Corp. is also among the companies considering bids for these assets, primarily located in West Texas. This move indicates Shell's strategy to reduce its acreage, aligning with other European majors.

title: TotalEnergies hits another oil target offshore Suriname
summary: TotalEnergies and APA Corporation have announced their fifth oil discovery off the coast of Suriname at the Sapakara South-1 well on Block 58, which encountered 30 meters net pay of oil. This success, following previous discoveries, reinforces their strategy for large resource volumes and low development costs in the region. Analysts suggest Suriname could become a significant oil production hub with low breakeven prices and substantial recoverable reserves.

title: Chevron (CVX) Taps Permian Chief to Run New Low-Carbon Division
summary: Chevron Corp. is establishing a new business unit, Chevron New Energies, to focus on scaling up new technologies like carbon capture and hydrogen. Jeff Gustavson, currently head of North America exploration and production, will lead this division, signaling Big Oil's adaptation to the energy transition. Ryder Booth will take over Gustavson's current role.

title: Cenovus retires $1 billion in debt as oil price surge lifts Canadian energy sector
summary: Cenovus Energy Inc. retired nearly $1 billion in debt in the second quarter, anticipating it will meet its interim net debt target of $10 billion by year-end due to surging oil prices. The Calgary-based oil producer reported significant free cash flow and a swing to profit, signaling a robust recovery for the Canadian energy sector. This financial turnaround reflects the easing of COVID-19 restrictions and strong commodity prices after a volatile 2020.

title: Big investors are divesting from fossil fuels – should you?
summary: The article explores the dilemma for Australian investors regarding fossil fuels: whether to invest in undervalued energy names or join the growing trend of divestment. It presents arguments from both "bulls" who see continued demand from Asian markets and "bears" who warn of stranded assets due to renewable energy advancements and tightening regulations. The piece discusses the potential for energy companies to transition to green futures and the financial risks involved for investors.

title: Iraq wants American firm to replace Exxon, prime minister says
summary: Iraq's Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi stated that Iraq wants another American company to replace Exxon Mobil Corp as it exits the country. Exxon is selling its 32.7% stake in the West Qurna 1 oilfield, and while it has agreements with Petrochina and Pertamina, Iraq insists on another American firm as its replacement. Foreign investment is crucial for Iraq, as oil revenue accounts for at least 95% of its income.

title: Hess, ConocoPhillips, Shell, Petrobras contract Transocean floaters
summary: Transocean Ltd. has announced new contracts and contract extensions for its offshore drilling rig fleet, totaling approximately $7.3 billion in backlog. Major contracts include Hess for the Discoverer Inspiration in the US Gulf of Mexico, Petrobras for the Petrobras 10000 offshore Brazil, ConocoPhillips for the Transocean Norge offshore Norway, and Shell for the Transocean Barents also offshore Norway. Additionally, several rigs are scheduled for out-of-service periods in Q3 and Q4 2021.

title: Precision Drilling posts $75.9M loss in 2nd quarter despite better outlook
summary: Precision Drilling Corp. reported a net loss of $75.9 million in the second quarter despite a 6.1 per cent increase in revenues due to higher oil and natural gas prices and an improved outlook for the Canadian energy sector. The company tripled its Canadian rig count and expects a strong industry recovery, with rig activations planned through the third quarter. However, labour shortages are presenting a significant challenge to the industry.

title: Will DaVita’s indictment alter its big political spending in California?
summary: Dialysis giant DaVita and its former CEO face federal antitrust charges, raising questions about the company's substantial political spending in California. DaVita spent $135 million to defeat two ballot measures and contributed $1.3 million to state politicians, making it a major player in California politics. The indictment, while unrelated to patient treatment, could impact lawmakers' willingness to accept contributions from the company.

title: Exxon Mobil adds first woman top-tier executive with external CFO hire
summary: Exxon Mobil has appointed Kathyrn Mikells as its new chief financial officer, making her the first woman and external hire to join the oil major's management committee. This move comes as Exxon faces investor pressure to diversify its leadership and shake up its executive suite after years of poor returns and as competitors invest more in energy transition. Mikells' appointment is seen as a significant step towards change in the company's historically rigid internal promotion structure.

title: A Closer Look at the PR Feud Between Liberty Oilfield and the North Face
summary: Liberty Oilfield Services launched a marketing campaign against The North Face, accusing the outdoor brand of hypocrisy regarding its climate activism while relying on fossil fuels for its products. This feud highlights the complex and often contentious relationship between the outdoor industry and the oil and gas sector. The North Face, while acknowledging its reliance on fossil fuels, states it carefully considers co-branding partnerships and is working to reduce its environmental impact.

title: Shell hastens efforts to hit goal of net-zero emissions
summary: Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corp. is accelerating its "Powering Progress" strategy to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 or sooner, aligning with Shell Global's commitment. Recent initiatives include solar installations at mobility sites, a voluntary carbon offset program for fleets which has already offset 4.63 tons of carbon dioxide, and the use of sustainable building materials like Shell Bitumen FreshAir and eco-bricks in new stations. The company emphasizes strategic collaboration with stakeholders to develop renewable energy sources and reduce its carbon footprint.

title: Shell plans to exit California joint venture with Exxon Mobil
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc (RDSa.L) intends to exit Aera, its oil and gas-producing joint venture in California with Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM.N). The move is part of Shell's strategy to divest carbon-intensive assets and increase investments in renewables, aligning with investor pressure to reduce fossil-fuel holdings. Aera accounts for about 25% of California's oil and gas production, and Shell is also considering selling assets in the Permian Basin.

title: Equinor to collaborate with U. S. Steel on hydrogen and carbon capture and storage development
summary: Equinor has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with U. S. Steel to explore the development of hydrogen and carbon capture and storage (CCS) in the Appalachian Basin. This collaboration aims to assess the technological and commercial viability of these solutions to help the US achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, focusing on supporting energy-intensive industries. The initial work includes feasibility studies, screening third-party partners, and advocating for supportive policies.

title: ExxonMobil, FuelCell Energy Partner on ‘Game Changing’ Technology
summary: ExxonMobil and FuelCell Energy are collaborating on developing carbon reduction technologies, with FuelCell Energy focusing on converting methane-rich fuels into electricity and capturing carbon to produce more electricity. ExxonMobil is also developing biofuels and algae for fuel production to address the dual challenge of meeting energy demand while lowering emissions. This partnership highlights the importance of collaboration between large and smaller companies in tackling climate change.

title: ETF issuers ‘systematically’ allocate to new carbon-intensive bonds, research finds
summary: New academic research indicates that ETF issuers consistently purchase new bonds from carbon-intensive companies, despite increasing focus on ESG investing. The study, titled "Breaking the Bond: Primary Markets and Carbon-Intensive Financing," found that 13.6% of new bonds acquired by 35 large US-listed corporate bond ETFs between 2015 and 2020 were from carbon-intensive sectors, exceeding the wider global corporate bond market's 10%. This trend raises concerns that ETFs could become "buyers of last resort" for these sectors, potentially hindering the transition to a low-carbon economy.

title: ICE Extends European Natural Gas Forward Curve Amid Record Interest
summary: Intercontinental Exchange Inc. (ICE) is extending its European natural gas forward curve for Dutch TTF futures until December 2031 due to record interest and strong trading activity. This extension, driven by customer requests, will allow market participants to better hedge global gas price risk and optimize LNG portfolios. The move aligns the futures contract with typical lengths of medium- to long-term LNG deals.

title: Chevron to Rebrand or Open More Than 30 CNG Retail Sites by 2025
summary: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. announced plans to rebrand or open over 30 compressed natural gas (CNG) retail sites by 2025, reinforcing its commitment to cleaner energy. This initiative includes rebranding its first station in Napa, Calif., and builds on existing investments in renewable natural gas with companies like California Bioenergy and Brightmark, as well as a partnership with Clean Energy Fuels Corp. for a carbon-negative RNG initiative at California ports.

title: Turkey turns to U.S. firms as plans Black Sea gas extraction, official says
summary: Turkey has shared data on its Black Sea gas discovery with U.S. energy majors Chevron and Exxon Mobil, signaling a potential shift towards foreign cooperation in extracting the estimated 540 billion cubic meters field. This move comes as Turkey, previously intent on developing the field independently, considers the technical and financial reasons for a consortium and aims to reduce its energy dependence on other nations. The collaboration could also help ease tensions between NATO allies Turkey and the U.S.

title: Valaris awarded drillship contract from Chevron
summary: Valaris Ltd. announced it has been awarded a three-year contract by Chevron in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico for its drillship Valaris DS-18 (Relentless). The contract is set to begin in the first quarter of 2022, directly following its current contract. The drillship, built in 2015, is capable of drilling in ultradeepwater conditions.

title: Coca-Cola Sued for False Advertising Over Sustainability Claims
summary: Earth Island Institute has filed a lawsuit against Coca-Cola, alleging false advertising and greenwashing due to the company's sustainability claims, despite being the world's leading plastic waste generator. The suit, filed in District of Columbia Superior Court, does not seek damages but aims to halt Coca-Cola's deceptive marketing practices and encourage transparency regarding its plastic use. This action highlights a broader issue of corporations, including those in the fossil fuel industry, facing legal challenges over misleading environmental representations.

title: Transocean and Jurong agree new delivery dates for high spec drillship duo
summary: Transocean and Jurong Shipyard Pte Ltd (JSPL) have agreed to new, delayed delivery dates for the ultra-deepwater drillships Deepwater Atlas and Deepwater Titan. The agreement includes deferred payment plans for both rigs, which are described as the world's most capable and highest specification drilling rigs. This arrangement significantly improves Transocean's liquidity and extends its financial runway.

title: Will Chevron Divest Canada Oil Sands Asset?
summary: Chevron Corp. is considering selling its 20% stake in a Canadian oil sands mine due to investor pressure to curb emissions. CEO Michael Wirth stated that while the asset generates good cash flow, it's not strategic, and the company would be open to a sale if fair value is met. This potential divestment aligns with other major oil companies that have shed oil sands holdings amidst increasing climate-related demands from shareholders and courts.

title: Chevron Increases Base Oil Prices Again, Prices for Several Base Oil Grades Touch Record Highs
summary: Chevron Corp. has announced its second base oil price increase in a month, effective May 28, 2021, with various grades seeing hikes of 20-30 cents/gallon. Other manufacturers like Excel Paralubes, Phillips 66, and ExxonMobil are also raising prices. These increases are attributed to tight supply, robust demand, and rising production costs, leading base oil prices to record highs.

title: Five ways to trade the divergence between the Chinese yuan and U.S. dollar
summary: The Chinese yuan's recent surge to a three-year high against the U.S. dollar has created opportunities for inverse trades. Two traders suggest five ways investors can capitalize on this divergence, including emerging market bonds, copper, gold miners, energy stocks, and crude oil. These strategies leverage the yuan's strength and the perceived weakness of the dollar.

title: What Exxon, Chevron climate shake-ups mean for oil
summary: Climate change activists achieved significant victories at Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp., securing a board shake-up at Exxon and expanded climate goals at Chevron through shareholder votes. These moves, following years of pressure and investor organizing, signify a potential shift in strategy for major U.S. oil producers regarding emissions and climate change. The impact will depend on the new board members at Exxon and how Chevron implements its broadened emissions targets.

title: ExxonMobil Shareholders to Company: We Want a Different Approach to Climate Change
summary: ExxonMobil shareholders voted to elect two new corporate directors supported by an investment firm seeking to push the oil giant toward a more climate-friendly strategy. This move is seen as a significant blow to Exxon's current leadership and signals strong shareholder concern about the company's approach to the energy transition, potentially leading to a re-evaluation of its long-term strategy. The vote highlights growing investor pressure on major oil companies to address climate change more aggressively.

title: Exxon CEO is dealt a stinging setback at hands of activist
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. CEO Darren Woods suffered a major setback as activist investor Engine No. 1 successfully secured at least two board seats despite vocal opposition from Exxon. This unprecedented victory for a small activist firm against a major oil producer signals a growing willingness among institutional investors to push for corporate action on climate change and raises questions about Exxon's energy transition strategy.

title: EXCLUSIVE BlackRock backs 3 dissidents to shake up Exxon board -sources
summary: BlackRock, Exxon Mobil Corp's second-largest shareholder, is backing several candidates from Engine No. 1 to join Exxon's board, challenging the energy giant's strategy following years of weak financial performance and reluctance to invest in renewable energy. This support from a major institutional investor like BlackRock highlights growing shareholder frustration and the increasing importance of environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) factors in investment decisions, potentially influencing the outcome of Exxon's upcoming annual shareholder meeting.

title: Nordic American Tankers reports $25m loss
summary: Nordic American Tankers Ltd reported a net loss of $25 million in the first quarter of the year, an improvement from the previous quarter's $28.7 million loss. Despite the loss, the company remains optimistic about the future of the tanker market, citing easing Opec oil production cuts and strong global oil demand. Nordic American Tankers also announced a dividend payment of two cents per share, marking its 95th consecutive quarterly dividend.

title: Oil prices back to $66 a barrel in US
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Monday, May 24, 2021, with West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $66.05 and Brent crude at $68.46 a barrel. While oil prices rose, the performance of Oklahoma and Texas energy stocks was mixed, with some companies experiencing gains and others losses, including Cimarex Energy Co. which fell after announcing a merger. Natural gas prices, however, saw a slight decrease.

title: BHP Sells Its Stake in the GoM Neptune Field to EnVen
summary: BHP announced it is divesting its 35% stake in the Neptune field in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico to Houston-based EnVen Energy Corp. The transaction will increase EnVen's interest in the deepwater field from 30% to 65%, while BHP will continue to operate the field under contract until regulatory approval. This divestment aligns with BHP's long-term strategy to reshape its portfolio, though the Gulf of Mexico remains a key region for the company.

title: The TJX Companies (TJX) Q1 2022 Earnings: Key financials and quarterly highlights
summary: The TJX Companies reported strong financial results for Q1 2022, with net income reaching $533.9 million, or $0.44 per share, reversing a net loss from the prior year. Net sales significantly increased by 126% to $10.1 billion. CEO Ernie Herrman expressed optimism about the company's strong positioning post-health crisis and its opportunities for global market share expansion.

title: Target Corp. (TGT) Q1 Earnings: Key financials and quarterly highlights
summary: Target Corporation (TGT) reported strong Q1 2021 earnings, with total revenue increasing 23.4% to $24.1 billion and GAAP net income soaring over 600% to $2 billion. Both revenues and earnings exceeded market expectations. The company anticipates mid to high single-digit comparable sales growth for Q2 2021, followed by positive single-digit growth for the latter half of the year.

title: Methanex will not accept short-term gas contract from NGC
summary: Methanex announced that it will not accept a short-term gas contract from NGC for its Titan plant at the Point Lisas Industrial Estate, stating that month-by-month contracts are not feasible for restarting the plant. The company prefers a medium to longer-term agreement to justify the significant investment needed for a restart and to ensure profitability through market cycles. Despite a competitor restarting operations on short-term agreements, Methanex is prioritizing certainty and a more economically viable long-term solution.

title: US lawyer who sued Chevron over Ecuador pollution faces charges
summary: Steven Donziger, a disbarred American lawyer, is on trial for criminal contempt for failing to comply with court orders in a civil case brought by Chevron. This legal battle is the latest development in a long-running dispute stemming from Donziger's representation of Ecuadorian villagers who sued Chevron over environmental contamination. Chevron claims the initial $9.5bn judgment Donziger won in Ecuador was secured through bribery and fraud.

title: How a Century of Moments Built MRC Global
summary: This article chronicles the 100-year history of MRC Global, a leading PVF distributor, tracing its evolution from Jerry McJunkin's initial company in 1921 to its current global presence. It highlights key moments like mergers, strategic acquisitions, and investments in technology like the Houston Operations Complex and the MRCGO e-commerce platform. The article emphasizes how the company has adapted to industry changes, customer needs, and economic cycles, positioning itself for future success under new leadership.

title: Exxon Outvotes Other Shareholders to Beat Back Net-Zero Resolution for Imperial Oil
summary: Imperial Oil Ltd. shareholders, led by parent company ExxonMobil, voted to defeat a resolution for the company to adopt a net-zero carbon emissions target by 2050. While ExxonMobil owns 69.6% of Imperial, 58% of other shareholders voted in favor of the resolution, highlighting a rift. Imperial's CEO stated that such a long-term target is premature without clear, achievable steps, focusing instead on a 2023 emissions reduction goal.

title: Natural Gas Giant EQT Buys Marcellus Assets Of Alta Resources For $2.9 Billion
summary: EQT Corp., the nation's largest natural gas producer, announced the acquisition of Alta Resources' Marcellus shale assets for $2.9 billion. This deal, consisting of $1 billion in cash and 105 million shares of EQT common stock, expands EQT's footprint in the northeastern Marcellus and boosts its free cash flow. The acquisition highlights the continued strategic growth under EQT CEO Toby Z. Rice, leveraging Alta's lower operational and pipeline transport costs.

title: EQT Enters Northeast Pennsylvania in $2.9B Deal for Alta’s Marcellus Assets
summary: EQT Corp. has agreed to acquire Alta Resources Development LLC in a $2.9 billion deal, expanding its Marcellus Shale acreage by 300,000 net acres and establishing a presence in Northeast Pennsylvania. This acquisition is projected to boost EQT's volumes to 5.6 Bcfe/d from 4.6 Bcfe/d and increase free cash flow by 55% to $5.5 billion through 2026, while also accelerating deleveraging targets. The deal underscores EQT's strategy of consolidating the Appalachian basin and capitalizing on certified natural gas demand.

title: Chevron pitches $100 million in New Mexico properties as oil M&A heats up
summary: Chevron is offering to sell approximately 73,000 acres of oil and gas properties in New Mexico, including over 1,000 producing wells with $1.1 million in monthly revenue. The sale, potentially valued around $100 million, comes as oil firms accelerate divestitures in a rebounding oil market, particularly in the Permian Basin. This move reflects a trend of increased M&A activity in the oil sector, driven by favorable valuations and rising oil prices.

title: Chevron Corporation: A must-know brief overview
summary: This article provides a brief overview of Chevron Corporation (CVX), an energy company involved in exploration, production, refining, marketing, and transportation of oil and gas. It discusses CVX's current valuation, market capitalization, enterprise value, and its operational segments (Upstream and Downstream). The article also mentions ETFs that hold CVX and refers to its Q1 2014 earnings announcement.

title: Chevron Announces First Quarter 2021 Results
summary: Chevron Corporation reported Q1 2021 earnings of $1.4 billion, reflecting strengthened performance due to higher oil prices and cost efficiencies, despite lower downstream margins from the pandemic. The company maintained capital discipline, increased its dividend, and made strategic moves toward a lower-carbon future and the acquisition of Noble Midstream Partners LP. Upstream operations saw improved earnings, particularly in the U.S., while international upstream earnings decreased due to lower sales volumes and other factors.

title: UAE Wealth Fund to Buy Share of Israeli Gas Field
summary: Mubadala, the UAE's sovereign wealth fund, plans to acquire a 22 percent stake in Israel's Tamar offshore natural gas field from Delek for $1.1 billion. This deal, the largest commercial agreement since the Abraham Accords, significantly advances the UAE's diplomatic and energy profile in the Mediterranean region. The acquisition faces geopolitical complexities, including Palestinian opposition and regional rivalries, while highlighting the broader growth of East Mediterranean energy production.

title: Timeline: Looking back at departing Chesapeake Energy CEO Doug Lawler's time with the company
summary: This article provides a timeline of major events during Doug Lawler's tenure as CEO of Chesapeake Energy, from his appointment in 2013 to his departure in 2021. It highlights the company's efforts to reduce debt, its oil expansion, the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing and subsequent emergence, and the renaming of Chesapeake Energy Arena. Lawler's time was marked by significant financial challenges and strategic shifts to keep the company afloat.

title: Greentown Labs Houston looks to usher in new era of energy
summary: Greentown Labs Houston, a "climatech startup incubator," officially opened its doors, aiming to cultivate clean-energy leaders and businesses in Houston. The incubator provides workspaces, labs, and community access for startups, with founding partners including energy giants like Chevron and Shell. Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner emphasized the city's "moral obligation" to reduce carbon emissions.

title: Does The Energy Sector and "ERX" Still Have Room to Run?
summary: The S&P 500 Energy index and the Direxion Daily Energy Bull 3X Shares (ERX) have shown significant strength in 2021, with ERX up 56%. Analysts suggest the sector still has room to run, supported by a bullish oil report from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and anticipated global demand growth despite potential fragility from rising COVID-19 cases. The IEA revised up global oil demand for 2021 and expects strong demand growth in the latter half of the year.

title: Chemical Used in Many Oil Refineries Could Cause Mass Deaths If Leaked
summary: An investigation reveals that modified hydrofluoric acid (MHF), used in many oil refineries, poses a significant danger to nearby residents, with a potential leak causing mass casualties. Despite industry claims of safety, experts argue that MHF is nearly identical to deadly hydrofluoric acid (HF) and could form a flesh-eating vapor cloud. Community activists and local officials are pushing for a ban on these chemicals, highlighting past incidents and the inadequacy of current safety measures, particularly in earthquake-prone areas.

title: Struggle Heats Up Over Future of Delek US
summary: A contentious battle is ongoing between Delek US Holdings Inc. and Carl Icahn's CVR Energy Inc. CVR is suing Delek US over CEO compensation and tactics, while Delek US accuses CVR of using classic Icahn strategies like pushing for share buybacks and a hasty sale of its retail business. The conflict highlights differing views on Delek US's valuation and future strategy, with CVR seeking to replace board directors and Delek US defending its management and financial performance.

title: COVID-19 surge complicates busy maintenance season for Canada's oil sands
summary: Canada's oil sands face challenges during their busy annual maintenance season due to a third wave of COVID-19, making workers reluctant to travel. Despite companies introducing rapid testing and travel assistance, finding skilled tradespeople is difficult with several oil sands sites fighting outbreaks. This could impact maintenance schedules crucial for regulatory compliance and safety, potentially affecting crude output.

title: MRC Global marks its centennial more with relief than revelry
summary: MRC Global, a leading distributor of pipe, valves, and fittings to the energy industry, is celebrating its centennial with a new CEO and a sense of optimism after a challenging year. The company recorded a significant loss in 2020 due to plunging oil prices and the pandemic but is now seeing improvements. They are also preparing for the industry's shift towards alternative energy sources.

title: Oil prices up on strong economic outlook, stock draw
summary: Oil prices increased on Wednesday due to strong economic data from the US and China, fueling expectations of a quicker global economic recovery. This surge is also supported by a larger-than-expected crude oil inventory drawdown forecast in the US. However, ongoing negotiations in Vienna regarding the Iran nuclear deal could introduce more Iranian oil to the market, potentially limiting price gains.

title: Occidental CEO Hollub opposes a carbon tax despite rivals' support for idea
summary: Occidental Petroleum CEO Vicki Hollub has voiced her opposition to a carbon tax, despite the backing it has received from major rival oil companies and some trade groups. Hollub argues that a carbon tax would negatively impact a significant portion of the industry, consumers, and particularly economically disadvantaged individuals. Meanwhile, Occidental is pursuing ambitious climate targets and is trying to make its low-carbon unit profitable.

title: Fossil Fuel Companies Took Billions in U.S. Coronavirus Relief Funds but Still Cut Nearly 60,000 Jobs
summary: A new analysis by BailoutWatch reveals that dozens of fossil fuel companies received $8.2 billion in tax benefits through the CARES Act in 2020 but still cut nearly 60,000 jobs. This contradicts the stated intent of Congress to maintain employment, as companies like Marathon Petroleum ($2.1 billion in benefits, nearly 2,000 jobs cut) and NOV ($591 million, nearly 8,000 jobs cut) prioritized cash flow and shareholder rewards. The article highlights that these tax changes, while not explicitly targeting the oil industry, uniquely benefited them due to their volatile earnings.

title: Court Affirms Dismissal of NYC Climate Suit
summary: The Second Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the dismissal of New York City's climate change lawsuit against major oil companies, ruling that the Clean Air Act governs domestic emissions and foreign policy concerns preclude judicial intervention in regulating foreign emissions. The court emphasized that federal common law displaces state law in this context, deeming global warming a "uniquely international problem of national concern" unsuitable for state nuisance law. This decision contrasts with other courts allowing state-level climate suits, highlighting ongoing litigation regarding climate change liability.

title: Drillers Burned Off Gas at a Staggering Rate as Winter Storm Hit Texas
summary: During the winter storm in Texas, drillers in the Permian Basin were forced to burn off an estimated 1.6 billion cubic feet of natural gas in a single day, a fivefold increase from pre-crisis rates. This flaring occurred because pipelines froze and power plants went offline, leaving nowhere for the gas to go. Satellite analysis confirms this as one of the highest spikes in flaring ever observed in the region.

title: Chevron to stop flow of funds after failing to sell stake in Kitimat LNG project
summary: Chevron Canada Ltd. is halting funding for its proposed Kitimat LNG project in B.C. after failing to sell its 50 percent stake over 15 months.
