The Indian conglomerate, led by Mukesh Ambani, saw its market value climb to US$189 billion, while Exxon's declined amid a global plunge in fuel demand. This shift reflects Ambani's strategic pivot towards technology and retail, successfully attracting significant investments into its Jio Platforms unit.

title: Chevron Powering Oil Pumps with Solar Panels
summary: Chevron is using solar panels to power oil pumps in its Lost Hills oil field in California, reducing electricity costs and earning low-carbon fuel standard credits. This initiative, while beneficial for Chevron's finances and considered a potential model for replication, has drawn criticism from environmentalists who argue it subverts the clean-energy program's goals. The project highlights a broader debate in California about balancing climate leadership with its status as a major oil-producing state.

title: Precision Drilling second-quarter loss surges as pandemic weakens demand for oil
summary: Precision Drilling Corp. reported a significant surge in its second-quarter loss to $48.9 million, up from $13.8 million a year earlier, with revenues plummeting 47% to $189.8 million due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices. The company expects a muted third-quarter rebound and aims to reduce 2020 cash outflows by up to $150 million through further cost-cutting and capital expenditure reductions. CEO Kevin Neveu stated these actions have financially and competitively positioned the company for an eventual industry recovery.

title: Chevron’s Noble buy reflects Israel’s ‘warming’ ties with Gulf states — expert
summary: Chevron's acquisition of Noble Energy, which holds significant stakes in Israel's offshore natural gas fields, signals a warming of ties between Israel and Gulf states, according to an energy expert. The deal suggests that Israel is no longer a taboo for the international energy industry, which previously avoided the country due to fear of Arab boycotts. Although Chevron has expressed interest in Noble's Israeli assets, there is a possibility that these assets could still be sold due to commercial factors.

title: A visual dashboard of Capital One Financial Q2 2020 earnings
summary: Capital One Financial (NYSE: COF) reported an 8% slip in Q2 revenue to $6.6 billion, missing Wall Street projections, while net loss of $1.61 per share was narrower than analysts' projection. Following the announcement, COF shares fell 3.3%, and the stock has declined nearly 40% since the beginning of the year. Investors are looking forward to management/analyst comments on the Q2 results.

title: Halliburton's $1.7B loss paves way for more bruising results
summary: Halliburton reported a $1.7 billion loss in the second quarter of 2020, primarily due to a significant write-down of assets as oil prices collapsed during the coronavirus pandemic. Despite the loss, the company generated $456 million in free cash flow by aggressively cutting costs and plans to close or sell 100 locations. Analysts anticipate more challenging quarters for Halliburton and the oil-field services industry, although cost-cutting measures are seen as a positive step.

title: Chevron Buying Houston’s Noble Energy for $5 Billion – Deal Could Put More Empty Space in Houston Office Market
summary: Chevron announced its agreement to acquire Houston-based Noble Energy for $5 billion in an all-stock transaction, marking the largest energy sector takeover since the start of the coronavirus pandemic. The deal will expand Chevron's energy assets, including Noble Energy's Permian Basin holdings and offshore assets in Israel, and could lead to more vacant office space in Houston as Chevron consolidates operations. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by Chevron to acquire quality assets during challenging economic times, while offering Noble Energy shareholders a compelling opportunity to join a diversified energy leader.

title: Chevron Agrees to $5 Billion Takeover of Noble Energy
authors: Cara Lombardo and Christopher M. Matthews
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to acquire Noble Energy Inc. for approximately $5 billion in an all-stock deal, making it the largest oil industry takeover since the start of the coronavirus pandemic. The transaction values Noble at $10.38 per share, representing a premium over its recent closing price, and a total value of roughly $13 billion including Noble's debt. This acquisition comes as the oil industry faces significant challenges due to historic drops in demand caused by the pandemic.

title: Chevron to buy Noble Energy in $5 bln deal
summary: Chevron Corp announced an agreement to acquire Noble Energy Inc in an all-stock deal valued at $5 billion, with the total deal value, including debt, estimated at $13 billion. This acquisition will expand Chevron's presence in key oil and gas basins and the eastern Mediterranean, yielding potential annual cost savings of $300 million. The deal comes amidst a challenging period for shale producers due to collapsed oil prices and the ongoing pandemic.

title: Chevron to buy Noble for $5 billion in rare oil-bust deal
summary: Chevron Corp. agreed to acquire Noble Energy Inc. for approximately $5 billion in shares, making it the first major oil industry deal since the coronavirus-induced slump. This acquisition will expand Chevron's shale presence in the Permian Basin and Denver-Julesburg Basin, as well as enhance its footprint in the eastern Mediterranean with the Leviathan gas field off Israel. The deal is seen as a strategic move by Chevron to acquire quality assets during challenging times for the industry.

title: Project Development & Finance Practice Recognized with Three Deal of the Year Awards
summary: Latham & Watkins' Project Development & Finance Practice received three North America Deal of the Year awards from IJGlobal for their work on complex financings in solar, liquefied natural gas (LNG), and midstream oil & gas sectors. The recognized projects include the Recurrent Energy Module Safe Harbor Loan, the Calcasieu Pass LNG financing, and the Midship Pipeline project. This recognition highlights Latham's expertise in significant infrastructure and energy deals.

title: Are Traders Ready to See Oil Prices Go to $0 Again?
summary: Oil traders are contemplating the possibility of oil prices dropping to $0 again, reminiscent of the April 2020 lows caused by the coronavirus pandemic. While prices have rebounded due to supply cuts and easing lockdowns, the risk of renewed declines exists if COVID-19 cases surge and demand falters. The article discusses leveraged ETFs like GUSH for those betting on price increases and DRIP for those on the bearish side.

title: Fracking Firms Fail, Rewarding Executives and Raising Climate Fears
summary: As U.S. oil and gas companies rapidly face bankruptcy due to a global price war and reduced demand, concerns are rising over abandoned wells left to leak planet-warming pollutants and cleanup costs burdening taxpayers. Despite these financial collapses, millions of dollars have been paid out in executive compensation, drawing criticism from financial analysts. Companies like MDC Energy, Whiting Petroleum, Chesapeake Energy, and Diamond Offshore Drilling compensated executives shortly before or during bankruptcy proceedings, highlighting a controversial trend in the industry.

title: Drilling Down: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones goes drilling for natural gas in East Texas
summary: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones, through his company Comstock Resources, is expanding natural gas drilling operations in East Texas' Haynesville Shale. Comstock filed for four new drilling permits in Harrison County, targeting the Carthage field. Other companies like Shell and ConocoPhillips are also active in the Texas oil and gas fields, with Shell drilling in the Delaware Basin and ConocoPhillips in the Eagle Ford Shale.

title: Chesapeake Energy transformation of OKC came with a price
summary: Chesapeake Energy's extensive investment in Oklahoma City, spearheaded by founder Aubrey McClendon, dramatically transformed the city with developments like a sprawling campus and upscale shopping districts. However, this civic transformation coincided with a ballooning company debt that eventually led to Chesapeake filing for bankruptcy. Despite the company's financial struggles and McClendon's death, his legacy of civic impact, particularly on areas like the Boathouse District, continues to be recognized.

title: Duke Energy, Dominion Energy cancel contested Atlantic Coast Pipeline
summary: Duke Energy and Dominion Energy have canceled the multi-state Atlantic Coast Pipeline project, citing escalating costs and regulatory uncertainties. This decision comes despite a recent U.S. Supreme Court victory regarding a critical permit, due to continued opposition and delays. The $8 billion natural gas pipeline was designed to cross West Virginia and Virginia into North Carolina.

title: Exxon Mobil resists write-downs as oil, gas prices plummet
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. is notably resisting writing down the value of its U.S. shale assets despite plummeting oil and gas prices, setting it apart from its peers. Other major energy companies like BP PLC, Hess Corp., Occidental Petroleum Corp., Chevron Corp., and Royal Dutch Shell PLC have all taken significant impairments totaling billions of dollars due to the coronavirus-induced economic slowdown and lower energy prices. This stance has even led to an SEC complaint filed by some accountants, suggesting Exxon should recognize the diminished value of its shale driller XTO Energy.

title: Chesapeake Energy files for bankruptcy, as details emerge of wine cellars and botox
summary: Chesapeake Energy, a key player in the U.S. shale revolution, filed for bankruptcy protection due to heavy debt and a drop in oil and gas prices. The restructuring will wipe out $7 billion in debt, and the company has secured additional financing to continue operations at a reduced capacity. Details emerging from the company's past finances reveal extravagant spending under former CEO Aubrey McClendon, including wine cellars and botox treatments.

title: ‘Google of oil and gas’ files for bankruptcy
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp., once the second-largest natural gas producer in the country and a pioneer of the fracking boom, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company's filing follows a decade of struggling with debt and the legacy of its late founder, Aubrey McClendon, exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic. Despite efforts to reduce debt by $20 billion and lay off thousands of workers, the company was unable to remain solvent.

title: Fracking trailblazer Chesapeake Energy becomes the biggest oil and gas bankruptcy of the pandemic
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corporation, once a pioneer in fracking and the nation's No. 2 natural gas producer, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, becoming the largest oil and gas company to do so during the coronavirus pandemic. The company, which has grappled with significant debt and low energy prices exacerbated by the pandemic, will restructure its balance sheet and legacy contractual obligations. This move follows a sharp drop in oil prices, and the company plans to eliminate around $7 billion in debt and secure new financing to stabilize its capital structure.

title: LATEST TECH NEWS: Verizon joins others to boycott Facebook. 4 other things and a trivia you need to know today, June 26, 2020
summary: This article covers five key tech news stories from June 26, 2020, including Verizon joining the boycott against Facebook due to hate speech concerns, Egyptian edtech OTO Courses securing new investment, Waymo and Volvo partnering on electric robotaxis, the opening of applications for the AppsAfrica Innovation Awards 2020, and Amazon's reported acquisition of self-driving startup Zoox for over $1 billion. It also includes a tech trivia question and answer about the beginning of computer engineering.

title: Slip-up reveals Chevron ties to architect of climate attack
summary: A public relations firm, CRC Advisors, promoting a campaign against climate policies linked to the Green New Deal accidentally revealed its client was Chevron (CVX). The campaign criticized environmental policies as harmful to minority communities, specifically targeting the Green New Deal. Despite Chevron denying involvement, this "clerical error" has renewed suspicions among activists and academics about the company's lobbying activities concerning climate change.

title: Chevron Planning to Sell Stake in Australia's North West Shelf LNG Facility
summary: Chevron Corp. announced its plan to sell its 16.67% interest in Australia's North West Shelf Project, one of the country's largest liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities, following unsolicited approaches from buyers. This decision aligns with the facility's shift towards a third-party tolling model and Chevron's broader asset optimization strategy, despite its ongoing commitment to other major LNG projects in Australia. The energy market has been challenged by the Covid-19 pandemic, leading to significant investment cuts and project postponements in the LNG sector.

title: Chesapeake’s fate marks the end of an era in U.S. shale
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp., once a pioneer in shale drilling, is facing bankruptcy, signaling the end of an era for U.S. shale and potentially the largest corporate casualty in the industry. The company's financial struggles, exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic and years of debt, highlight the broader challenges faced by many North American energy explorers. This situation underscores the unraveling of the shale model established by Chesapeake and its late co-founder Aubrey McClendon, leaving an uncertain future for smaller operators and the industry as a whole.

title: Oxy Starts Returning Staff to U.S. Gulf of Mexico after Storm
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp has begun returning staff to its Gulf of Mexico facilities after Tropical Storm Cristobal moved away. The company plans to fully restaff by Tuesday and resume production once safe. This move follows other energy companies preparing to restart oil and gas production in the region after evacuations and shutdowns.

title: Argentina is nationalising one of world's top soy suppliers
summary: Argentina's President Alberto Fernandez announced plans to nationalize Vicentin SAIC, a major crop trader, by placing it under state control for 60 days and seeking congressional approval for expropriation. This move, which revives memories of past nationalizations and raises concerns among investors, aims to create a state commodities giant and address the company's bankruptcy amidst currency swings and its significant role in Argentina's US$20 billion-a-year crop export business. The decision has sparked debate within Argentina, with critics questioning its legality and constitutionality, while supporters view it as necessary to protect the farming industry.

title: Oil Traders Fret Over Rising Inventories, Questionable Production Cuts
summary: Oil prices experienced volatility due to rising inventories and debates over production cuts among top producers like OPEC+. The extension of current cuts, particularly the 9.7 million barrels per day agreement, is crucial for market stability, as failure to do so could lead to a selling spree, while extending cuts could have longer-term bearish effects on shale production forecasts. Investors can gain exposure to oil through ETFs such as IEO, USOU, and GUSH, with OILK offering an actively managed strategy for WTI crude oil futures.

title: Chevron Oil Cargo Tangled in U.S. Sanctions on Venezuela
summary: A Chevron Corp crude oil cargo is entangled in U.S. sanctions against shipping companies for violating restrictions on business with Venezuela. The vessel MT Seahero, chartered by Chevron, is owned by Adamant Maritime Ltd, which was sanctioned for carrying Venezuelan oil in February. Chevron is working with government agencies to ensure compliance amidst Washington's escalating efforts to oust President Nicolas Maduro.

title: Chevron plans sweeping job cuts with 6,000 employees at risk
summary: Chevron Corp. announced plans to cut its global workforce by 10 to 15 percent, affecting about 6,000 non-gas station employees, in response to the Covid-19 pandemic and record-low oil prices. The job cuts are part of an effort to streamline operations, achieve $1 billion in operating expense savings, and may signal similar actions among other major oil companies. This move follows broader job losses within the energy sector, particularly in oilfield services and North American independent producers.

title: Exclusive: Chevron to cut up to 15% of staff amid restructuring
summary: Chevron Corp plans to cut 10% to 15% of its global workforce, representing about 4,500 to 6,750 jobs, as part of a restructuring effort to align with projected activity levels amid a sharp drop in oil prices and demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This move follows a 30% reduction in its 2020 spending and previous voluntary job cuts. Most of the reductions are expected to occur this year, with additional severance and benefits offered to affected U.S. employees.

title: Exxon, Chevron face shareholders as oil faces uncertain future
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are facing shareholder meetings amidst a global oil crash caused by the coronavirus pandemic, raising questions about the future of oil demand and climate change policies. Despite the challenges, analysts believe these U.S. oil giants are well-equipped to weather the storm due to their strong balance sheets and diversified operations, potentially allowing them to redefine themselves and acquire struggling rivals. However, shareholder resolutions regarding independent board chairmen and differing outlooks on future oil demand highlight ongoing debates within the industry.

title: Chevron Buys More Marcellus Shale
summary: Chevron has expanded its Marcellus shale holdings by purchasing drilling rights for an additional 228,000 acres, following its 2011 acquisition of Atlas Energy. This move aims to secure more gas-rich land amidst a booming U.S. natural gas sector, despite environmental concerns and falling domestic gas prices. The acquisition is estimated to be worth $1.6 billion.

title: Chevron Nigerian Rig Fire Finally Burns Out
summary: A natural gas fire on a Chevron Corp. rig off the coast of Nigeria, which killed two people, finally stopped burning after 46 days. Though the fire is out, Chevron acknowledged the possibility of gas flowing from the well and is drilling a relief well to permanently plug the site. The Nigerian government attributes the explosions, which occurred on January 16 and killed a man from India and another from France, to a "gas kick" or buildup of gas pressure.

title: Unravelling the climate footprint of U.S. liquefied natural gas
summary: This article examines the significant climate footprint of U.S. liquefied natural gas (LNG), particularly from the Permian Basin, challenging its portrayal as a clean energy source for Europe. It highlights high levels of methane emissions and flaring, which compromise the climate benefits of replacing coal, and discusses the EU's proactive stance on methane emissions. The piece also points out the complexities and inconsistencies in measuring and comparing methane emissions across different gas-producing regions globally.

title: Midland-based Propetro, makes dramatic employee layoffs
summary: Propetro Holding Corp. laid off 150 workers and plans to cut up to 28% of its hydraulic fracturing fleets, representing a 9.5% staff reduction, in response to the oil price drop and Covid-19. The company also announced compensation reductions for its board and management and approved a short-term stockholder rights plan to protect its capital structure and ensure fair treatment for shareholders during potential takeovers.

title: Chesapeake Energy considers bankruptcy after losing more than $8B in first quarter
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp. announced it is considering bankruptcy after posting a net loss of $8.3 billion in the first quarter of 2020, largely due to low commodity prices and depressed demand caused by COVID-19. The company also disclosed that executive bonuses were cut, while a new quarterly bonus program was created for rank and file employees. While bankruptcy is an option, the company is also exploring other strategic alternatives to restructure its debt and align its capital structure.

title: Rio Grande LNG and BND amend lease, amid global oil and gas market uncertainty
summary: The Port of Brownsville (BND) and NextDecade’s Rio Grande LNG project have amended their lease agreement, linking its start to a financial investment decision (FID) for the first phase, with a deadline in May 2021 and a possible extension. This amendment comes amidst global oil and gas market uncertainty and delays experienced by several other LNG projects in Texas due to the COVID-19 pandemic and oversupply. The project faces local opposition and legal challenges, with environmental groups welcoming the FID delay.

title: Tankers Round the Cape as Glut Snarls Ports
summary: Due to a global oil glut caused by the coronavirus pandemic, supertankers are undertaking unusual, longer voyages around South Africa's Cape of Good Hope to delay cargo delivery as storage fills up and generate profit from contango market conditions. These rare detours, which avoid the Suez Canal, also capitalize on historically low fuel prices and offer a way for suppliers to manage an oversupplied market. The extended routes highlight the significant impact of the current market disruption on the global shipping industry.

title: Williams lands Gulf of Mexico pipeline deal with Chevron, Total
summary: Oklahoma pipeline operator Williams secured a deal with Chevron and French oil major Total to transport natural gas from their deepwater Anchor project in the Gulf of Mexico. Williams has built an underwater pipeline to connect the Anchor project, expected online by 2024, to its Discovery System, a network of pipelines and processing plants in Paradis, Louisiana. This agreement expands Williams' existing infrastructure in the Gulf of Mexico despite the challenging economic climate due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Halliburton lays off 1,000 at Houston headquarters
summary: Halliburton has laid off 1,000 employees at its Houston headquarters due to record low crude prices and a "dramatic business downturn." This action follows earlier furloughs and is part of broader global reductions, bringing the company's workforce down from 55,000 to about 50,000 worldwide. The company has also implemented significant cost-cutting measures, including executive pay cuts and a reduction in its capital budget, to navigate the challenging market conditions.

title: Williams Tapped to Transport Natural Gas from Chevron's Deepwater Anchor Project
summary: Williams has been selected to transport natural gas from Chevron's massive Anchor development located 140 miles offshore Louisiana. The Anchor project, sanctioned as the first greenfield launch in nine years and the first high-pressure project in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, anticipates first production in 2024. Williams will leverage its existing infrastructure to transport the gas to its Discovery system for processing and fractionation.

title: Crude Oil Pulls Back Amid Profit Taking And Storage Concerns
summary: Crude oil prices, specifically West Texas Intermediate (WTI), experienced a pullback on Wednesday due to profit-taking and ongoing concerns about oversupply, despite a recent rally. Analysts suggest that the rapid increase in prices might have been premature given weak refining margins and persistent storage issues. While demand is showing signs of recovery with economies reopening, it's not yet sufficient to balance global oil production, keeping some investors cautious.

title: Shell to divest natural gas wells in Pennsylvania
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is set to sell its natural gas assets in Tioga County, Pennsylvania, to National Fuel Gas Co. This sale will further expand National Fuel's presence in the state, positioning it as one of the top shale producers. The article notes this transaction while also referencing a broader trend of declining natural gas production and optimism from other Marcellus producers for 2021.

title: Buyer Beware: Retail Investors Buying USO’s Oil ETF
summary: This article warns retail investors about the risks of the United States Oil Fund (USO) ETF, explaining how its design to track daily oil price movements can lead to significant underperformance, especially during market conditions like contango. It highlights how an oversupply of oil and lack of storage in Cushing, Oklahoma, contributed to negative oil prices and USO's dramatic decline, despite retail investors flocking to it. The author also details how USO recently changed its investment strategy to diversify future contracts but notes its long-term underperformance compared to WTI and the S&P 500.

title: Exxon reports historic loss, closes 75% of Permian rigs
summary: Major U.S. oil producers like Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips, and Chevron reported historic losses in the first quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global oil demand. Companies are cutting spending and production, particularly in the Permian Basin, and expect the recovery to be slow, with low prices persisting through the end of the year.

title: Chevron profit up on asset sales, output, cuts 2020 spending plans
summary: Chevron reported a 38% increase in quarterly profit, boosted by asset sales and increased oil output, despite falling demand and weak oil and gas prices. The company subsequently announced further cuts to its 2020 spending budget and plans to curtail oil output in the coming months, reflecting the impact of the oil glut and coronavirus pandemic. Chevron's stock was down 3% following the announcement.

title: Chevron Opposes U.S. Oil Bailouts Amid Shale-Patch Shutdowns
summary: Chevron Corp. CEO Mike Wirth stated the company opposes U.S. government bailouts for oil companies, arguing that market cycles are an inherent part of the industry that companies should prepare for. He emphasized that such bailouts reinforce a moral hazard argument for companies that have not positioned themselves prudently for tough market conditions.

title: Exxon Posts Historic Loss on Rout With Chevron in Retreat
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. reported its first loss in at least three decades, amounting to $610 million, and plans to cut hundreds of thousands of barrels of daily output. Meanwhile, Chevron Corp. slashed $2 billion from its spending plan and accelerated supply curbs, highlighting the financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic on oil giants. These actions reflect the historic falloff in oil demand and the need for significant cost-cutting measures.

title: Abu Dhabi gets world’s record low solar power price offer
summary: Abu Dhabi has received a record low solar power price offer of USD 13.5 per MWh from a consortium of EDF and JinkoSolar for a 1.5 GW photovoltaic plant. The bid, which broke the previous record set in Qatar, is for the Al-Dhafra project, intended to be the world's biggest operational single-site PV plant at 2 GW. This development highlights the continuously decreasing cost of solar energy, especially in the Arabian Peninsula.

title: Production
summary: In 2020, Ecopetrol Group achieved 99.6% of its production goal, reaching 697 thousand barrels of oil equivalent per day, despite the challenges posed by COVID-19, reduced demand, and low prices. Key achievements included the start-up of Castilla 3 Station, acquisition of Chevron’s participation in a contract, and completion of the Piedemonte Association Contract. The group also drilled 255 wells and carried out 281 Workover works, while reiterating its commitment to operations in the Gulf of Mexico and unconventional fields in the United States.

title: U.S. oil plunges 25%, Brent falls below $20 a barrel
summary: U.S. crude oil plunged 25% and Brent crude fell below $20 a barrel due to a lack of available storage and weak fuel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Global fuel demand is down 30% and roughly 85% of worldwide onshore storage was full last week. Retail investment vehicles like the United States Oil Fund LP are shifting holdings to later-dated contracts to avoid similar losses experienced a week prior.

title: What's Driving the Multi Pad Drilling Market Size? Prominent
summary: This article discusses the multi-pad drilling market, highlighting its growth potential, key trends, and competitive landscape. It segments the market by application (onshore, offshore) and pad size, providing regional analysis with a focus on North America, Western Europe, and Asia Pacific as key growth areas. The report profiles major players such as ExxonMobil, Devon Energy, and Chevron, offering an overview of global market trends and opportunities.

title: Trump orders Chevron to halt oil production in Venezuela
summary: The Trump administration ordered Chevron to stop oil production in Venezuela by December 1, as part of efforts to pressure the Maduro regime. This move, while having limited financial impact on Chevron, deals a significant blow to Venezuela's oil industry. Chevron, which has a long history in Venezuela, will be allowed to maintain a limited presence for essential operations.

title: Eaton adds Lori J. Ryerkerk to its board
summary: Eaton (NYSE: ETN) has appointed Lori J. Ryerkerk, chairman, president, and CEO of Celanese Corp. (NYSE: CE), to its board of directors, effective April 22, 2020. Ryerkerk brings extensive experience from the energy industry, including previous roles at Shell Downstream Inc., Hess Corp., and ExxonMobil. She succeeds Todd M. Bluedorn, who served on Eaton's board for 10 years.

title: Northern Trust (NASDAQ: NTRS) Q1 2020 Earnings Infographic
summary: Northern Trust (NASDAQ: NTRS) reported a 4% rise in Q1 2020 earnings, driven by higher revenue and strong momentum before the pandemic's partial impact. Despite a 3% decline in net interest income, non-interest income jumped 35% due to increased client volumes and market volatility. The company highlighted its strong capital base and liquidity as crucial during turbulent times.

title: Oil plunges below zero for first time; Marathon refinery remains open
authors: Damian J. Troise and Alex Veiga
summary: Oil futures plummeted below zero for the first time in history, reaching negative $37.63 per barrel for May delivery, due to a severe collapse in demand from the coronavirus pandemic and a lack of storage capacity. While an international standard for oil also fell, the Detroit Marathon Petroleum Corp. refinery continued operations, monitoring the market as other global markets reacted to the unprecedented plunge. Simultaneously, the broader stock market saw declines, with the S&P 500 down 1.8%, though some tech companies gained.

title: Oil prices dip below zero as producers forced to pay to dispose of excess
summary: US crude oil prices plummeted to negative values for the first time in history, reaching -$38 a barrel, as an oversupply due to the coronavirus crisis overwhelmed storage facilities. Producers were forced to pay buyers to take crude, highlighting the severe impact of reduced demand. While prices rebounded slightly on Tuesday, the long-term outlook remains uncertain, with calls for a shift towards sustainable energy sources.

title: East Bay Oil Refinery to Close Temporarily With Low Gasoline Demand
summary: Marathon Petroleum Co. is temporarily idling its Martinez refinery in Contra Costa County due to a significant drop in gasoline demand caused by COVID-19 related travel restrictions. Production wind-down began April 19, 2020, with completion expected by April 27, though the duration of the shutdown is uncertain. While regular employees will be retained for maintenance and training, contract workers will lose their positions.

title: OPINION: Buffett's taking more Oxy stock, So maybe you shouldn't
summary: This opinion piece discusses Warren Buffett's increased stake in Occidental Petroleum (Oxy), clarifying that it's due to Oxy paying a coupon on preferred stock with shares rather than cash amidst dire oil market conditions. The author argues that Buffett's additional oil exposure is not a choice but a consequence of a risky deal Oxy made to acquire Anadarko, which has now been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and broader economic issues. The article cautions against interpreting Buffett's move as a bullish signal for the oil sector.

title: Stock Alert: Chevron Loses 4%
summary: Shares of Chevron Corp. are down over 4% due to the suspension of a major field expansion project in Kazakhstan, partly owned by Chevron, following a coronavirus outbreak. This comes amidst a broader decline in crude oil futures driven by oversupply and plunging demand. Chevron has also announced measures to preserve cash, including reducing capital spending and suspending its share repurchase program.

title: Exxon Mobil cuts spending plans, reduces expansion budget as coronavirus hits oil demand
summary: Exxon Mobil has significantly reduced its 2020 capital spending by 30% to $23 billion, in response to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices. This cut is deeper than most rivals, with major impacts on U.S. shale production and deferred investment decisions on projects in Mozambique and Guyana. Despite the spending cuts, the company has maintained its shareholder dividend.

title: Rockets target US oil company in Iraq’s Basra province
summary: At least three rockets targeted the site of the American oil field service company Halliburton in Iraq's Basra province, marking the first such attack on US energy interests in recent months. While no casualties were reported and oil production was unaffected, the incident fuels tensions, with pro-Iran militias in Iraq having previously pledged to target US interests. Security forces found a rocket launcher and defused unused rockets nearby.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | A Top Occidental Petroleum Executive Is Out as Company Grapples With Oil Rout
summary: A top executive at Occidental Petroleum Corp., Oscar Brown, has been "forced out" of the company amid challenges from an ill-timed acquisition, declining crude prices, and substantial debt. Brown, who was a key lieutenant to CEO Vicki Hollub and instrumental in the Anadarko Petroleum acquisition, served as senior vice president over strategy, business development, and supply chain. The $38 billion Anadarko deal included a costly $10 billion investment from Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Oil Storage So Full That Traders May Stow It on Pipe Networks
summary: The US oil glut is growing so rapidly that storage facilities are nearing capacity, leading pipeline operators to worry that traders might use pipelines for temporary storage to await better prices. Plains All American Pipeline LP is requiring proof of buyers for crude shipments to prevent this, while Colonial Pipeline Co. has warned clients that unreserved fuel will be sold off. This situation highlights rising concerns about overwhelming storage capacity and the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on demand.

title: Occidental Petroleum reaches truce with activist investor Carl Icahn
summary: Occidental Petroleum has reached an agreement with activist investor Carl Icahn, culminating a months-long dispute. The deal includes granting two of Icahn's deputies board seats, appointing an independent director, and creating a new board oversight committee. In response to plunging oil prices and high debt, Occidental is also implementing significant spending cuts, salary reductions for employees and executives, and a decrease in its 2020 capital spending budget.

title: Oil crash leaves Exxon, Chevron dividends safe -- for now
summary: In the wake of a significant oil market crash driven by a Saudi Arabia-Russia price war and the COVID-19 pandemic, the dividends of ExxonMobil and Chevron are under threat but still considered safe "for now." Both companies have seen their stock prices plummet, leading Chevron to cut capital spending and halt share buybacks to conserve cash. Analysts believe the companies will prioritize dividend payments as long as possible due to their strong balance sheets and the importance of dividends to their investor base.

title: Coronavirus causes ConocoPhillips to temporarily cancel flights for workers to North Slope fields
summary: ConocoPhillips has canceled flights for hundreds of workers to Alaska's North Slope for two weeks to prevent the spread of COVID-19, asking critical personnel to extend their rotations. Other oil companies like BP are continuing screenings for workers, while the virus has led to plunging oil prices and a slowdown in the North Slope oil patch. All companies are implementing measures like social distancing and health screenings, with no confirmed cases on the North Slope at the time of the report.

title: New York Stock Exchange temporarily closing trading floors, going all electronic
summary: The New York Stock Exchange announced it will temporarily close its trading floors and switch to all-electronic trading starting next Monday due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. This decision comes amidst extreme volatility in the U.S. financial markets, with significant drops in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq. Despite the closure, the NYSE assures that trading and regulatory oversight of all listed securities will continue without interruption during normal trading hours.

title: Carl Icahn Ups Stake In Occidental As Turbulent Oil Prices Send Shares Tumbling
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn significantly increased his stake in Occidental Petroleum Corp. to 10% after the company's shares fell due to turbulent oil prices. Icahn, a vocal critic of Occidental's management regarding its Anadarko Petroleum acquisition and associated debt, had previously warned about a potential dividend cut, which materialized recently. He is now seeking to replace the current board of directors at the upcoming annual shareholder meeting.

title: Drilling Down: Independents keep Permian Basin activity going
summary: Independent oil companies are maintaining drilling activity in the Permian Basin, even as major players like Exxon Mobil scale back operations due to the coronavirus and slumping crude prices. Several independent companies filed numerous horizontal drilling permits in the Permian and other shale plays, indicating continued investment in exploration and production. Meanwhile, other regions like the Barnett Shale are experiencing a drought in horizontal drilling permits.

title: U.S. shale producers deepen spending, output cuts as oil prices slump
summary: U.S. shale producers are rapidly deepening spending and output cuts in response to a sharp decline in oil prices, triggered by OPEC's decision to flood a market already suffering from reduced demand due to the coronavirus. Major shale independents like Diamondback Energy Inc. and Parsley Energy Inc. have announced significant reductions in drilling and well completions to maintain cash flow, leading to a sharp drop in their share prices and impacting oilfield service firms. Analysts predict that U.S. oil production growth will be near zero compared to 2019, with further reductions in spending expected as investors are less willing to finance the sector than in previous downturns.

title: Chevron Showcases New Low-Ash Oil
summary: Chevron Products Co. unveiled a new heavy-duty engine oil, Delo 600 ADF, at the American Trucking Associations’ Technology & Maintenance Council annual meeting. This low-ash oil is designed to significantly reduce the clogging of diesel particulate filters (DPFs) by lowering sulfated ash content by 60%. The company showcased the oil's benefits through an educational trailer and a mock DPF, highlighting its potential to improve engine performance and reduce emissions, especially for LTL carriers in urban environments.

title: Stoneridge’s MirrorEye wins technical achievement award
summary: Stoneridge's MirrorEye Camera Monitor System received the 2020 Jim Winsor Technical Achievement Award from the North American Truck Writers committee. This award recognizes its innovation in replacing traditional truck mirrors with a five-camera, three-monitor array that enhances safety, eliminates blind spots, and improves fuel efficiency. Other finalists included Bendix Commercial Vehicle Systems Intellipark, Chevron Delo 600, Link ROI Cabmate, and SAF-Holland SMAR-te Tire Pilot.

title: Chevron sends UK employees home as coronavirus precaution
summary: Chevron Corp sent home approximately 300 employees from its Canary Wharf office in London as a precautionary measure after an employee reported flu-like symptoms following travel from a country affected by the coronavirus. The oil company's action comes amidst increasing fears of the virus's spread in Europe and the UK, with concerns about a potential surge in cases. This move is part of broader efforts in the UK to implement stricter testing and contingency plans, including potential school closures, to mitigate the impact of the virus.

title: Chevron Appalachia sets date for layoffs as it works to sell local assets
summary: Chevron Corp. is planning an initial round of local layoffs on April 6 as part of its effort to divest its Appalachian natural gas operations. The company, which announced its divestment plans in December, has 288 employees at its regional headquarters in Moon Township and 32 employees in Mt. Braddock. This move follows a $6.5 billion noncash charge taken in the fourth quarter to write off asset value due to declining natural gas prices.

title: USA Compression Partners Cuts 2020 Capex
summary: USA Compression Partners LP (USAC) has reduced its 2020 capital expenditures and equipment orders due to the industry downturn, forecasting spending of US$110-120 million and acquiring 56,000 hp of compressors, down from US$150 million and 132,000 hp in 2019. Despite "strong headwinds" in the energy industry, CEO Eric Long anticipates stable cash flows from long-term, high-horsepower contracts and sees continued opportunities in chemical, LNG export, and power generation sectors.

title: See Where 'X' Marks The Spot For XLE
summary: The Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE) experienced a poor start to 2020, being the worst-performing sector in January, largely due to sliding oil prices and concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. Despite being in bear market territory and nursing an 11% loss, some market observers believe a rebound could be possible given that energy is one of the least expensive sectors. The article discusses technical support and resistance levels for XLE, including its late-2018-through-2019 lows at $54 and 2010 lows at $49.

title: Saudi, Kuwait authorise shared oil field restart from Sunday
summary: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have authorized the restart of oil production at the Wafra field starting Sunday, over four years after output was halted due to a concession dispute involving Chevron Corp. The two countries reached an agreement in December to resume production in the shared Neutral Zone. This resumption adds heavy, high-sulfur crude to the market, which is particularly important given U.S. sanctions on Iran and Venezuela.

title: Chevron Enhances Payment Options on Mobile App
summary: Chevron Corp. has enhanced the payment options on its Chevron and Texaco mobile apps by becoming the first energy company to accept Venmo for fuel purchases at the pump. This integration allows users to share or split purchases and is part of Chevron's strategy to innovate retail fuel transactions and provide flexible, seamless interactions for customers. The mobile apps are available for both iOS and Android devices, and Chevron is active in over 180 countries.

title: Westlake Chemical agrees to report plastic pellet spills under activist shareholder pressure
summary: Westlake Chemical Corp. has agreed to publicly report its plastic pellet spills due to pressure from the activist shareholder group As You Sow. This decision follows similar commitments from other major plastics producers like Exxon Mobil, Chevron Phillips Chemical, and Dow Chemical, and comes after Formosa Plastics settled a major lawsuit over a plastic pellet spill for $50 million. Westlake will include this data in its 2020 sustainability report, which will be published in 2021.

title: Icahn demands Oxy reveal if it was approached by potential buyer
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn is demanding that Occidental Petroleum Corp. reveal whether it was approached by any potential buyers before acquiring Anadarko Petroleum Inc. for $37 billion. Icahn, who owns 3% of Occidental, asserts that CEO Vicki Hollub and Chairman Eugene Batchelder prioritized their jobs over investor interests and structured the deal to avoid a shareholder vote. He suggests the deal was a "defensive maneuver" and is seeking records through the courts regarding the company's interactions leading up to the Anadarko deal.

title: A Canadian Energy Company Bought an Oregon Sheriff’s Unit
summary: A Canadian energy company, Pembina Pipeline Corp., funded a specialized unit within the Coos County Sheriff’s Office in Oregon for nearly four years to handle security concerns related to its proposed Jordan Cove Energy Project. This unit, established to monitor opposition and acquire riot control equipment, highlights an unusual partnership between a public law enforcement agency and a private corporation. Critics argue this arrangement biases law enforcement and raises constitutional questions regarding free speech and public safety.

title: All eyes on Exxon and Chevron after BP pledges to go carbon neutral
summary: BP's commitment to go carbon neutral by 2050 intensifies pressure on U.S. oil giants Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. to similarly expand their climate efforts beyond operational emissions. While European peers are investing in low-carbon energy, Exxon and Chevron remain focused on their core oil and gas businesses, viewing climate change as a technology problem yet to be solved, and prioritizing higher returns. This stance puts them at odds with shareholder groups and an increasingly climate-conscious investment landscape.

title: Martinez Named to Top Latinos Leaders in Corporate America
summary: Alumna Maria Martinez ’01, MBA ’06, was recognized by Latino Leaders Magazine as one of the top Latino Leaders in Corporate America, serving as the Vice President of Human Resources & Administration at Murphy Oil Corporation. She is noted for her leadership in global HR programs and her community involvement with organizations like the Greater Houston Women’s Chamber of Commerce. Martinez credits her two degrees from the University of St. Thomas for providing a strong foundation for her professional success.

title: Revealed: big oil's profits since 1990 total nearly $2tn | Oil and gas companies
summary: Four major oil companies, BP, Shell, Chevron, and Exxon, have collectively made nearly $2 trillion in profits since 1990 while being accused of driving climate change and passing the buck. Exxon was the most profitable among them. Experts suggest that the fossil fuel boom is ending as clean energy gains traction, with oil companies becoming the worst-performing investments in US stock markets over the past decade.

title: Coastal GasLink pipeline project, British Columbia, Canada
summary: The Coastal GasLink pipeline project is a 670km-long pipeline in British Columbia, Canada, developed by LNG Canada, a joint venture of major energy companies. With an estimated investment of C$6.6bn ($5bn) and a target operation start in 2023, it aims to transport natural gas from the Dawson Creek area to an LNG processing facility in Kitimat for export. The project is expected to create over 2,000 jobs during construction and generate significant economic benefits for local and indigenous communities.

title: How ExtraMile Is Building Its Brand Through Franchisees
summary: ExtraMile has grown significantly since becoming a joint venture between Chevron Corp. and Jacksons Food Stores, adding over 100 stores to reach 942 sites. A key factor in this expansion is its franchise model, exemplified by franchisee Sal Hassan of H&S Energy LLC, who has converted 48 of his 100+ stores to ExtraMile and plans further growth due to the brand's benefits in buying, negotiation, marketing, and customer recognition.

title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron Help Fuel Investor Revolt
summary: Weak earnings reports from Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp., following Royal Dutch Shell Plc's earlier debacle, are contributing to investor dissatisfaction in the oil majors. The energy sector's weighting in the S&P 500 Index has fallen to a four-decade low, highlighting increasing vulnerability for these companies and a lack of investor confidence. The results suggest a prolonged challenge for these large oil companies to regain shareholder trust.

title: Pemex Claims Ownership of Lion's Share of Zama Field
summary: Mexico's state oil company Pemex is claiming the majority ownership of resources in the Zama offshore field, conflicting with Talos Energy Inc.'s interpretation. This dispute adds to tensions between the Mexican government and the private sector, as both companies vie for operator status of the significant oil field. The resolution of this issue, which could impact Mexico's energy production and revenue, is expected to be determined through technical means and discussions with the Energy Ministry.

title: Microsoft building massive expansion on West Side
summary: Microsoft is undertaking a significant expansion project on the West Side of San Antonio, following its acquisition of the former Chevron Corp. data center. The project involves adding 104,837 square feet to its existing footprint. This development marks a substantial investment by Microsoft in the San Antonio area.

title: Exxon Mobil closes at lowest since October 2013
summary: Exxon Mobil shares reached their lowest closing price since October 2013, driven by falling oil prices stemming from the widening coronavirus outbreak. The decline was also impacted by a regulatory filing from Exxon indicating weaker fourth-quarter results due to issues in its chemicals and refining segments, leading analysts to lower their outlooks for the stock.

title: Exxon, Chevron earnings bring worries about oil prices to the forefront
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. are facing increased scrutiny from Wall Street as they prepare to report fourth-quarter earnings, amidst negative sentiment for the energy sector and declining oil prices. Both integrated energy giants are scheduled to report earnings and conduct conference calls with analysts on Friday.

title: Exxon, Chevron earnings bring worries about oil prices to the forefront
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. are facing scrutiny this week as they prepare to report fourth-quarter earnings amidst negative sentiment for the integrated energy sector and declining oil prices. Both companies are scheduled to release their earnings reports and hold conference calls with analysts on Friday.

title: Harvey Gulf Hires Dunn as Subsea VP
summary: Harvey Gulf International Marine has hired John Dunn as Vice President of Subsea Vessel Operations to expand its subsea business. Dunn, previously with Oceaneering and Meridian Ocean Services, brings extensive experience in subsea vessel operations and marine assurance. His role will involve managing Harvey Gulf's subsea operations, vessels, and teams, as well as seeking opportunities for further global business enhancement.

title: The Hydrogen Council Announces Significant Membership Growth Covering New Geographies and Financial Sector Ahead of 3rd Anniversary CEO Event
summary: The Hydrogen Council announced a significant expansion of its membership, welcoming 22 new companies including Australian and Saudi firms, and establishing a new Investor Group. This growth, bringing the total membership to 81 companies, aims to accelerate the adoption of hydrogen solutions for decarbonization across various sectors globally. The announcement precedes the Council's 3rd anniversary CEO Event and highlights increased collaboration and investment in the emerging hydrogen economy.

title: Petrobras sells $1.5 billion assets in Nigeria, ends activities in Africa
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petrobras has finalized the sale of its shares in Petrobras Oil & Gas B.V. (PO&GBV) to Canada's Africa Oil Corp. for $1.45 billion, marking the end of its activities in Africa. The sale includes indirect interests in Nigerian oil assets such as OML 127 (Agbami Field) and OML 130 (Akpo and Egina fields), which collectively produce significant volumes of crude oil and condensate. This transaction aligns with Petrobras's strategy to optimize its portfolio and improve capital allocation.

title: Activists cheer BlackRock's landmark climate move but call for vigilance
summary: BlackRock, the world's biggest asset manager, announced a significant shift in its investment strategy, divesting $500m from coal-related businesses due to climate risks. Environmentalists hailed this as a major breakthrough but urged continued vigilance and further action, emphasizing that these initial steps are just the beginning of necessary changes in the financial sector to combat climate change. Activists and financial experts alike called for BlackRock to leverage its substantial shareholder power to push for immediate, concrete climate actions from companies it invests in.

title: Understanding the Emissions Challenge
summary: Integrated oil companies are facing increasing pressure to reduce emissions from investors and regulators. This article assesses their efforts, highlighting that while many have adopted targets, Scope 3 emissions (90% of total) remain largely beyond their control. Investments in renewable power generation and increasing natural gas production are identified as the most impactful strategies for reducing full-cycle emissions.

title: Venezuela uses joint-venture oil partners to evade US sanctions
summary: Venezuela is reportedly using joint-venture oil partners, such as Chevron Corp, to evade US sanctions by allocating crude cargoes to them. These partners then market the oil globally, with proceeds used to pay off venture debts, a mechanism largely permitted by Washington to ensure the funds do not reach the Maduro government. However, Venezuela's opposition is lobbying the US to penalize these intermediaries.

title: The 10 Biggest Carbon-dioxide Emitting Firms In The World
summary: This article identifies the ten largest corporate emitters of carbon dioxide globally, responsible for a significant portion of greenhouse gas emissions since 1965. It details each company's emissions, origin, and some of their initiatives or controversies related to climate change. The article also highlights the impact of investor pressure in driving companies towards decarbonization efforts.

title: Cenovus sets bold sustainability targets
summary: Cenovus Energy Inc. announced ambitious environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets for 2030, focusing on climate & greenhouse gas emissions, Indigenous engagement, land & wildlife, and water stewardship. The company aims to reduce emissions intensity by 30% and hold absolute emissions flat by 2030, with a long-term ambition for net-zero emissions by 2050. These targets are integrated into Cenovus's strategy to enhance business resilience and foster long-term sustainability.

title: Occidental Petroleum slashing jobs 'significantly' in cost-cutting move
summary: Occidental Petroleum announced it will begin significant job cuts as a cost-cutting measure following its $38 billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum. The company, which had about 16,000 workers after the merger, has already reduced staff through a voluntary program and is selling assets and cutting spending to manage its increased debt. These moves are also aimed at addressing a proxy battle initiated by activist investor Carl Icahn.

title: Sony, Funko, EOG Resources, Diamondback Energy and Chevron highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day
summary: Zacks Equity Research highlights Sony as the Bull of the Day due to its PlayStation 5 launch and semiconductor growth, while Funko, Inc. is named Bear of the Day despite growth projections, attributed to an analyst's lowered estimates. The article also recommends energy stocks EOG Resources, Diamondback Energy, and Chevron as buying opportunities given recent oil market upticks and attractive valuations.

title: Energy stocks surge, as crude oil prices spike on Middle East tensions
summary: Energy stocks experienced a broad surge in premarket trading on Friday as crude oil prices spiked due to Middle East tensions following a U.S. airstrike. The SPDR Energy Select Sector ETF saw a 1.4% gain, with major components like Exxon Mobil Corp., Occidental Petroleum Corp., and Chevron Corp. all rising. This rally in energy stocks contrasted with a broader market downturn, as S&P 500 futures sank and crude oil futures shot up significantly.

title: Oil-Field-Service Stocks Are Getting Scrapped
summary: Amid a steep decline in drilling activity and a global oil-price war, oil-field-service stocks are taking a hit, with prospects looking dim for contractors and equipment suppliers. Companies involved in drilling, manufacturing tools, and managing pumper trucks are caught in a struggle for market share between Saudi Arabia, Russia, and the North American oil industry, further compounded by the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil demand.

title: TGS finaliza construcción de gasoducto en Vaca Muerta
summary: Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS) has completed the construction of a 150 km gas pipeline and an conditioning plant in Vaca Muerta, Neuquén, Argentina. This infrastructure will allow for the capture and transport of up to 60 MMm3/d of unconventional gas from the Neuquén basin to the national transportation network. The project, completed in record time, is deemed crucial for accelerating the development of gas production in Vaca Muerta, with companies like Pluspetrol, YPF, Pampa Energía, Total, Shell, GyP, and Tecpetrol already injecting gas into the new system.

title: Year in Review: 2019 Was A Pivotal Year for American Oil and Natural Gas
summary: 2019 proved to be a pivotal year for the American oil and natural gas industry, marked by record production and export achievements that reshaped global energy markets. The U.S. became a net exporter of petroleum products and solidified its position as the world's leading oil and natural gas producer. These advancements have not only driven significant economic growth and job creation but also contributed to substantial reductions in emissions and considerable savings for American families.

title: Natural Gas Extraction Opportunities in the Mississippian Barnett Shale
summary: The Barnett Shale in North-central Texas is becoming a major source of natural gas, offering low-cost extraction opportunities due to advancements in technology. Despite senior companies moving to other regions, smaller E&P firms are finding success by re-working existing wells and utilizing established infrastructure. The US is set to become a net energy exporter by 2020, with rising global demand for natural gas, particularly from countries like China.

title: News Content Hub - Industry leader: Quintin Kneen, President and CEO, Tidewater Inc
summary: Quintin Kneen, President and CEO of Tidewater Inc., is aggressively reshaping the company's fleet, management, and IT infrastructure to prepare for a market recovery and further industry consolidation. He has implemented significant organizational changes, including management shakeups and board reductions, and is focusing on cost-efficiency, technology leverage, and cultural transformation to improve decision-making and generate cash flow. Tidewater is also actively managing its fleet, including scrapping older vessels, acquiring new ones, and divesting non-returning assets, while considering strategic mergers to strengthen its market position.

title: Chevron sanctions Anchor project in Deepwater Gulf of Mexico
summary: Chevron has sanctioned the Anchor project in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, marking the industry's first deepwater high-pressure development to reach a final investment decision. This project involves a $5.7 billion investment for its initial stage, targeting first oil in 2024 with a design capacity of 75,000 bbls of crude oil daily and an estimated 440 million bbls of recoverable oil-equivalent resources. Chevron holds a 62.86% working interest, with Total E&P USA Inc. holding 37.14%.

title: Satellite observations reveal extreme methane leakage from a natural gas well blowout
summary: Satellite observations using the Tropospheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI) revealed a major methane leak from a natural gas well blowout in Ohio in 2018. The leak, which lasted 20 days, emitted an estimated 120 ± 32 metric tons of methane per hour, a rate twice that of the Aliso Canyon event in 2015. This single event's total methane emission was comparable to a significant fraction of annual anthropogenic emissions from several European countries, highlighting the importance of satellite monitoring for unexpected large-scale greenhouse gas releases.

title: Chevron Awards OneSubsea Industry’s First Fully Integrated Subsea Production System Rated up to 20,000 psi
summary: Schlumberger announced that its OneSubsea division has been awarded a contract by Chevron U.S.A. Inc. for the supply of an integrated subsea production and multiphase boosting system for the Anchor Field in the US Gulf of Mexico. This marks the industry's first 20,000-psi subsea production system contract, leveraging OneSubsea's innovative technologies to optimize project efficiency and reduce cycle times. The equipment will be deployed under a 20-year master order, aiming to reduce investment costs and improve subsea development performance for Chevron.

title: Chevron to sell its 50% stake in Kitimat LNG project as it writes down assets by $10B
summary: Chevron Corp. announced its decision to sell its 50% stake in the Kitimat LNG project and will cut funding to other gas-related ventures, including shale gas fields, while also writing down $10 billion in assets due to expected lower long-term oil and gas prices. This move is seen as a setback for the Canadian natural gas industry, despite optimism from Canadian politicians. The company stated that the project, while globally competitive, no longer aligns with its global portfolio optimization efforts.

title: Chevron may sell stake in Kitimat LNG
summary: Chevron Corp. is considering selling its 50% stake in the Kitimat LNG project as part of a significant write-down due to an oil and gas glut and depressed natural gas prices. The company is evaluating strategic alternatives for several assets including its Appalachia shale holdings and the Kitimat LNG project, which recently received a new 40-year LNG export license. Despite potential divestment, industry experts believe the Kitimat LNG project remains attractive and globally competitive.

title: Chevron looking to sell its 50 per cent stake in its Kitimat LNG project
summary: Chevron Corp. is seeking to sell its 50 per cent stake in the Kitimat LNG Project in British Columbia as part of a broader effort to cut spending and optimize its global portfolio. This decision follows a projected charge of at least US$10 billion due to lower long-term oil and natural gas prices impacting asset values. The Kitimat LNG Project is a 50-50 joint venture with Woodside Energy International and includes upstream resources, a pipeline, and a liquefaction facility.

title: Natural Gas Boom Fizzles as a U.S. Glut Sinks Profits (Published 2019)
summary: A decade after being heralded as the fuel of the future, the U.S. natural gas industry is experiencing a bust due to a significant glut in supply, leading to sinking profits and company write-downs. Chevron's $10 billion to $11 billion asset write-down, mainly in shale gas holdings, highlights the industry's over-optimism and the current oversupply situation. This market downturn is exacerbated by the falling costs of renewable energy and growing international gas production, suggesting a potentially prolonged slump.

title: Chevron to Take $11 Billion Writedown Amid Weak Gas Prices
summary: Chevron (CVX) is expected to take a writedown of up to $11 billion in the fourth quarter, primarily due to weak natural gas prices impacting its Appalachian assets. The company is considering selling its shale-gas holdings and exiting its stake in the Kitimat liquefied natural gas project in Canada, while maintaining its 2020 capital budget at $20 billion.

title: Chevron to take $11-billion charge as it looks to sell stake in LNG project in B.C.
summary: Chevron Corp. plans an $11-billion writedown, primarily from its Appalachia shale gas assets, and intends to sell its 50-per-cent stake in the proposed Kitimat LNG project in British Columbia. CEO Michael Wirth stated this move is part of the company's capital discipline to focus on its most advantaged assets and deliver higher cash returns to shareholders. Despite the divestment, Chevron Canada spokesman Leif Sollid confirmed they will continue to work with Woodside Petroleum and advance the project during the sale process.

title: Drilling Down: Top 10 drilling rig companies in Texas and their customers
summary: This article identifies the top 10 drilling rig companies and their top customers in Texas, based on exclusive data from Enverus as of November 26, 2019. It highlights Helmerich & Payne as the leading operator with 117 horizontal rigs and notes that Exxon Mobil leads in rig count among customers. The article also discusses the impact of low oil prices on the industry and the overall U.S. rig count.

title: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones is on the prowl in this overlooked shale play
summary: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones, through his company Comstock Resources Inc., is aggressively pursuing shale gas assets in Louisiana's Haynesville play, considering it the best for low-cost hydrocarbons. This strategy involves potential acquisitions exceeding $1 billion, including rumored talks with Chesapeake Energy Corp. and the recent acquisition of Covey Park Energy LLC, as Jones doubles down on natural gas despite a glut in the market and a significant drop in Comstock's share price.

title: Why ONEOK Partners acquires Permian assets from Chevron
summary: ONEOK Partners (OKS) announced its agreement to acquire natural gas liquids pipeline assets from Chevron Corporation (CVX) in the Permian Basin for $800 million. This acquisition will make OKS the 80% owner of West Texas LPG Pipeline and 100% owner of Mesquite Pipeline, expanding its presence in the NGL market. The deal, expected to close in 4Q14, is subject to FTC anti-trust clearance.

title: Chevron sells Malampaya stake to Udenna
summary: Udenna Corp. has acquired Chevron's 45-percent stake in the Malampaya gas field, a significant national energy asset off Palawan. This move aligns with Udenna's long-term goal of developing a sustainable clean energy business in the Philippines and ensures the future security of the country's energy supply. The transaction value was not disclosed, and it remains subject to regulatory approvals.

title: Dennis Uy’s Udenna Corp. acquires Chevron’s 45% Malampaya stake
summary: Dennis Uy’s Udenna Corp. has acquired Chevron Philippines Ltd.’s 45% stake in the $4.5 billion Malampaya deep water-gas-to-power project. This acquisition marks a significant milestone for Udenna, aligning with its long-term strategy to develop a sustainable clean energy business in the Philippines. The Malampaya gas field, which supplies the Philippines' current natural gas kebutuhan, is projected to be nearly depleted by 2024.

title: Ecopetrol y OXY cierran acuerdo de inversión en la Cuenca Permian en EE.UU.
summary: Ecopetrol and OXY have finalized their joint venture investment agreement in the Permian Basin in the U.S., which was first announced in July. Ecopetrol made an initial payment of approximately US$876.5 million for its 49% stake in the Rodeo Midland Basin LLC. This alliance is expected to add around 160 million barrels of proven oil equivalent reserves for Ecopetrol by the end of 2019.

title: Can the Energy Sector Power Through the Rest of 2019?
summary: This article discusses the potential for the energy sector to recover by the end of 2019, despite a challenging year for oil prices. It highlights the recent strong performance of the Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE) and includes insights from analysts like Mark Newton and Gina Sanchez on the sector's prospects and the role of oil prices and global demand.

title: Oxy to Sell Permian Campus After Anadarko Acquisition
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. plans to sell a four-story office building in the Permian Basin and move employees into an Anadarko-owned building after its $37 billion acquisition. The sale, handled by CBRE Group Inc. and Moriah Real Estate Co., aims to consolidate operations and alleviate financial pressure on Occidental, which is under investor scrutiny to reduce debt. The 213,000 square-foot complex, built in 2014, is expected to be vacated by April 2020.

title: Second Failed Brazil Oil Auction Has Officials Attacking Rules
summary: Brazil experienced its second consecutive failed oil auction, leading government officials and the head of the state-run producer to criticize current bidding rules. Most major oil companies avoided bidding, with only one of five available blocks receiving a bid, prompting the Economy Minister to express concern about the difficulty of doing business in Brazil.

title: Chesapeake Warns On Risk to Business From Sagging Oil Prices
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp. has warned that its ability to remain in business is at risk if oil and natural gas prices stay low. The company stated there is "substantial doubt" about its going concern status and that tightening loan agreements could lead to a debt default, causing investors to sell off shares and bonds. This highlights the ongoing challenges for drillers recovering from the 2014-2015 commodity price collapse.

title: Anna Williams, Jacob Jurlina (Published 2019)
summary: Anna Frances Williams and Jacob Jarrett Jurlina were married on November 2, 2019, in Louisville, Ky. Both 32, Anna works for Shell Oil Company in Houston, and Jacob is a finance manager at Ridgewood Energy Corporation, an oil and gas private equity firm also in Houston. The article provides details about their professional backgrounds, education, and parents.

title: Energy giant Encana to move HQ from Calgary to the U.S.
summary: Encana Corp., one of Canada's largest energy companies, is relocating its corporate headquarters from Calgary to the United States and changing its name to Ovintiv Inc. The company asserts this move is to access larger U.S. investment pools and will not impact Canadian staff or investment strategies in Alberta and B.C. The decision has garnered mixed reactions, with some analysts unsurprised given Encana's increasing focus on U.S. assets, while others note the historical significance of the company's Canadian roots.

title: Second offshore wind project announced
summary: Massachusetts has announced Mayflower Wind as the developer for its second offshore wind project, an 804-megawatt installation south of Nantucket, projected for completion by 2025. This project will join Vineyard Wind in advancing the state's clean energy goals, aiming to create jobs and significantly reduce carbon emissions. The state is actively working towards its 2027 goal of 1,600 megawatts from offshore wind production to meet increasing energy demands and environmental targets.

title: Encana leaves for U.S., changes name as industry veterans lament ‘heart-wrenching’ decision
summary: Encana Corp., a major Canadian oil and gas company, is moving its head office to the United States and rebranding as Ovintiv Inc. The decision, which comes amid struggles in Alberta's energy sector and political debate over environmental policies, allows Encana access to larger U.S. investment funds. The move has been criticized by industry veterans and politicians, despite the company's assurance of no job losses in Canada.

title: Hess, Chevron make oil discovery at Esox prospect in US Gulf of Mexico
summary: Hess and Chevron have announced an oil discovery at the Esox prospect in the US deepwater Gulf of Mexico. The Esox-1 exploration well intersected approximately 58m of high-quality oil-bearing Miocene reservoirs and is expected to begin production in the first quarter of 2020 as a subsea tieback to the Hess-operated Tubular Bells platform. Hess holds a 57.14% stake in Esox, with Chevron owning the remaining 42.86%.

title: Stopping Global Warming Will Cost $50 Trillion: Morgan Stanley Report
summary: A Morgan Stanley report estimates that $50 trillion in investment will be needed over the next three decades to stop global warming and achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. This monumental investment will be allocated across five key areas of zero-carbon technology: renewables, electric vehicles, carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and biofuels. The report also highlights specific companies poised to benefit from this spending and cautions about significant global GDP loss if climate targets are not met.

title: Ford Motor (F) Q3 earnings beat; stock falls on weak guidance
summary: Ford Motor Company reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings despite a revenue decline, yet its stock fell due to trimmed full-year guidance. The company lowered its full-year adjusted EBIT guidance to $6.5 billion-$7.0 billion, citing increased warranty costs, higher incentives in North America, and reduced volumes in China. Adjusted earnings per share are now projected to be $1.20-$1.32 for the full year.

title: Marathon Petroleum Weighs Sale of Two Refineries
summary: Marathon Petroleum Corp. is considering selling its two refineries in Alaska and Utah, in response to pressure from activist investor Elliott Management Corp. The company is in active discussions with potential buyers for its Kenai and Salt Lake City refineries, an action Elliott Management views as a way to unlock over $22 billion in value by breaking up the company. This comes as Marathon Petroleum faces demands from activist investors for strategic changes, including the potential ouster of its CEO.

title: The late Aubrey McClendon's Permian business merges with parent to avoid bankruptcy
summary: The Permian Basin business founded by the late Aubrey McClendon, American Energy - Permian Basin, merged its assets with its parent company, Permian Sable Resources, to avoid bankruptcy. This restructuring involved a $400 million cash deal with creditors to reduce the company's debt by $1.4 billion. McClendon's other ventures had similarly faced financial difficulties, with some units being acquired through bankruptcy auctions.

title: The story of Smilin’ Jack, Wilmington’s huge pumpkin-shaped oil tank
summary: The article details the 67-year-old Halloween tradition of "Smilin' Jack," a giant pumpkin face painted on an 80,000-barrel oil tank at the Phillips 66 refinery in Wilmington. The tradition started in 1952 when Union Oil operators noticed the tank's pumpkin-like appearance after a primer coat. Smilin' Jack features a 73-foot grin and 18-foot tall eyes, with the tradition including costumed characters and caramel corn for visitors.

title: World's top three asset managers oversee $300bn fossil fuel investments
summary: The world's three largest asset managers, BlackRock, Vanguard, and State Street, collectively oversee $300bn in fossil fuel investments, utilizing private savings and pension contributions. Data shows these firms have grown significant stakes in carbon-intensive companies since the Paris Agreement and have often opposed climate-related shareholder motions. While offering "climate-friendly" funds, they face scrutiny for their substantial fossil fuel holdings and the conflicting nature of their business models.

title: Is the U.S. Oil Industry Dominant? On the Verge of Oblivion? Neither (Published 2019)
summary: The US oil industry has shown surprising resilience to geopolitical tensions and attacks on oil production, suggesting neither dominance nor impending oblivion. Despite significant disruptions like sanctions, tanker seizures, and a drone attack on Saudi Arabia that impacted 6% of world production, oil markets have remained relatively stable. This unexpected stability is attributed to the strength gained by the United States in oil markets, even without being a low-cost producer.

title: Hibernia Platform Resumes Production
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced on Friday that production has resumed at its Hibernia oil platform in Canada, which had been shut down last month due to a power outage. The Hibernia platform has been operating since 1997 and is located approximately 315 km (200 miles) east of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, with ExxonMobil holding the largest stake.

title: Cresco Labs to Sell Illinois Facilities to Cannabis REIT for $46.3 Million
summary: Cresco Labs has signed a binding agreement to sell its Joliet and Kankakee, Illinois properties to Innovative Industrial Properties, Inc. for approximately $46.3 million. This sale-and-leaseback agreement provides non-dilutive capital to Cresco Labs, supporting the expansion of its Illinois operations in anticipation of adult-use cannabis legalization in January 2020. Cresco Labs will continue to operate the facilities under a long-term, triple-net lease agreement.

title: Enterprise Products Partners builds multibillion dollar empire ‘chasing demand’
summary: Enterprise Products Partners has built a multi-billion dollar empire by rapidly identifying and exploiting opportunities in the energy market, particularly through strategic investments in pipelines, processing plants, and export terminals. Founded in 1968, the company now dominates the U.S. crude oil, ethane, propane, and butane export markets, leveraging its significant infrastructure and a strategy of "chasing demand" to maintain profitability. Despite market challenges, Enterprise continues to expand its reach with new projects and investments, especially at the Mont Belvieu complex and along the Houston Ship Channel.

title: Young climate activists protest outside Chevron headquarters in San Ramon
summary: Young climate activists from Youth vs. Apocalypse protested outside Chevron's headquarters in San Ramon, demanding the company transition to sustainable practices and phase out fossil fuels by 2025. This protest was part of a Global Climate Strike and called on Governor Gavin Newsom to hold Chevron and other oil-producing companies accountable.

title: Chevron, Thailand in Dispute Over Decom Tab
summary: Chevron and Thailand are in ongoing negotiations to resolve a dispute over who should pay for decommissioning offshore oil and gas platforms at the Erawan gas field, with estimated costs up to $2.5 billion. Chevron argues that a new retroactive regulation requiring it to pay for all assets, even usable ones, contradicts its initial 1971 contracts.
