The outcome of this dispute is being closely watched by other international energy companies and foreign investors in Thailand due to its potential precedent-setting implications.

title: 7 Indigenous communities buying stake in Wabamun-Fort McMurray power line
summary: Seven Indigenous communities in Alberta are acquiring a 40% stake in Canada's longest 500-kilovolt power transmission line, stretching from Wabamun to Fort McMurray. This investment, totaling $300 million plus assuming $1.4 billion in debt, aims to create self-sourced funding for community services like health and education, and diversify investment portfolios away from solely oil and gas. The sale is expected to close in late 2019, with Canadian Utilities operating the line for the next 35 years.

title: Argos Resources looking new partners to participate in Falklands oil industry
summary: Argos Resources reported an interim loss of US$176,000 for the first half of 2019 but confirmed it is adequately financed for the next 12 months due to quarterly payments from Noble Energy Falklands Ltd and Edison International SPA. These payments stem from the two companies' withdrawal from the PL001 production license in the North Falkland Basin. Argos is now seeking new partners for the license's development and is in discussions with the Falkland Islands government to extend the permit.

title: Big Oil CEOs talk climate change, methane and why they need gas
summary: During Climate Week in New York, CEOs from major oil and gas companies like Shell, Exxon Mobil, Total, and Occidental Petroleum discussed climate change, methane emissions, and the role of natural gas. They emphasized the industry's responsibility in the energy transition, the need for technological evolution, and the importance of initiatives like carbon capture and methane leakage detection. The discussions highlighted the challenge of balancing rising energy needs with climate concerns.

title: The Environmental Left Is Softening on Carbon Capture Technology. Maybe That’s OK.
summary: The environmental left is showing signs of moderating its opposition to carbon capture technology, with some groups and politicians recognizing its potential role in decarbonizing hard-to-abate industrial sectors. This shift is partly driven by scientific consensus suggesting carbon capture is necessary to meet climate targets, as well as the strong support for the technology from labor unions seeking to preserve high-paying jobs. Despite past criticisms regarding cost and its association with the fossil fuel industry, advocates argue for government investment akin to renewables and highlight successful projects, emphasizing its global necessity alongside other climate solutions.

title: 7 Oil ETFs to Buy to Invest in Black Gold
summary: This article identifies seven Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) that offer investors a way to capitalize on the short-term fluctuations in crude oil prices, which can be significant despite long-term trends favoring cleaner energy. It details various types of oil-related ETFs, from direct crude futures exposure to investments in oil services, exploration and production, and global energy companies, catering to different risk appetites and investment strategies within the "black gold" market.

title: ExxonMobil Looks to Sell Australian Assets
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is seeking to sell its 50% stake in the Gippsland Basin oil and gas development in Australia's Bass Strait, part of a global portfolio review; the sale could fetch up to $3 billion. The aging fields, which have been a primary supplier for southeastern Australia, are seeing declining output. Potential bidders are expected to include other companies operating in the Bass Strait, such as Mitsui & Co, Beach Energy, and Cooper Energy, possibly forming a consortium due to the significant price.

title: Schlumberger, Chevron and Microsoft Announce Collaboration to Accelerate Digital Transformation
summary: Schlumberger, Chevron, and Microsoft have announced a three-party collaboration to accelerate the creation of innovative petrotechnical and digital technologies. This partnership aims to build Azure-native applications within the DELFI cognitive E&P environment to process, visualize, and interpret data from multiple sources, enhancing insights for Chevron. The initiative focuses on accelerating the industry's digital transformation, leveraging cloud and AI to address energy challenges, including sustainability.

title: Oil prices soar after attacks on Saudi facilities
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 15% after drone attacks on Saudi Arabian facilities disrupted 5% of global oil supply. Analysts warn that sustained outages could push prices higher, while the US and Saudi Arabia attribute the attacks to Iran, escalating regional tensions. The long-term impact on consumer fuel prices remains uncertain, with some experts suggesting initial increases, while others point to existing market adjustments and reserves.

title: Why the Saudi oil attack is a ‘big deal’ that could be a ‘game changer’ in stock markets and crude prices
summary: The article discusses the significant impact of the Saudi oil attacks on global energy markets and crude prices, calling it a "game changer." S&P Global Platts forecasts a potential $5 to $10 per barrel spike in Brent oil prices due to the disruption. The attacks on Saudi Aramco’s Abqaiq plant and a nearby oil field on September 14, 2019, resulted in a shutdown that could temporarily cut approximately 50% of Saudi Arabia's crude oil production.

title: New Report Finds Record-Breaking U.S. Natural Gas Reserves
summary: A new report by the Potential Gas Committee and the American Gas Association reveals that U.S. recoverable natural gas reserves have reached a record high of 3,374 trillion cubic feet (Tcf), marking a 20 percent increase over the 2016 assessment. This increase is attributed to technological innovations in shale, conventional, and tight gas extraction, particularly in the Atlantic and Mid-Continent regions. The report emphasizes the economic and environmental benefits of natural gas, while noting that some presidential candidates are considering policies that could negatively impact this sector.

title: Cheniere Energy: 2nd LNG train at South Texas plant is ahead of schedule
summary: Cheniere Energy Inc. announced that its second liquefied natural gas (LNG) train at its Gregory, Texas plant has achieved "substantial completion" ahead of schedule. This milestone means commissioning has wrapped up, and financial results from LNG sales from Train 2 will now be reflected in Cheniere's statements. The company and its contractor, Bechtel, have consistently completed liquefaction trains ahead of their guaranteed completion dates and within budget.

title: Hess Announces Arrival of Liza Destiny Offshore Guyana
summary: Hess Corporation announced the arrival of the Liza Destiny, Guyana's first oil production vessel, at the Stabroek Block after a 42-day journey from Singapore. This Floating, Production, Storage and Offloading (FPSO) vessel is crucial for the Liza Phase 1 development, which is expected to start by Q1 2020 and produce up to 120,000 gross barrels of oil per day. Hess Guyana Exploration Ltd. holds a 30 percent interest in the Stabroek Block, with ExxonMobil and CNOOC Petroleum Guyana Limited holding 45 percent and 25 percent respectively.

title: 2019 Mystery Shop: Getting the Most From Employees
summary: This article highlights findings from the 2019 Mystery Shop, focusing on how several convenience store brands excel in employee performance, particularly in customer service. It showcases ExtraMile and QuikTrip for their 100% scores on employees in revealed audits, and details strategies employed by Rutter's, True North Energy, Maverik, and Enmarket to empower staff and enhance customer experience. The piece emphasizes the importance of employee empowerment, training, and team-building in achieving top-tier customer service in the convenience retail sector.

title: Chevron Offers Consumers Another Way to Pay
summary: Chevron Corp. has expanded payment options within its Chevron and Texaco mobile apps by introducing the Chevron and Texaco eGift Card. This new digital payment solution allows customers to pay for fuel and car washes directly at the dispenser using their mobile devices. The eGift Card is designed for various uses including brand promotions, loyalty programs, and business-to-business channels.

title: California rare earths miner races to refine amid U.S.-China trade row
summary: MP Materials, owner of the only U.S. rare earths mine, is investing $200 million and hiring significantly to restart domestic rare earths refining by next year. This move comes as China escalates tariffs on rare earth imports, fueling U.S. national security concerns over its reliance on China for processing these critical minerals. The company aims to reduce U.S. dependence on China for rare earth processing and potentially encourage further domestic investment in magnet production.

title: Chevron is a better bet than Exxon, Barclays says
summary: Barclays analysts, led by Jeanine Wai, initiated coverage on Chevron and Exxon Mobil, recommending Chevron over Exxon. While both companies are driven by West Texas's Permian Basin, Chevron's "superior" cash position gives it an edge. Barclays rated Chevron the equivalent of a buy and Exxon the equivalent of neutral shares.

title: Chevron is a better bet than Exxon, Barclays says
summary: Barclays analysts rated Chevron's shares as the equivalent of a buy and Exxon's as the equivalent of neutral, citing Chevron's "superior" cash position. The Permian Basin is a key factor for both Chevron Corp. and Exxon Mobil Corp. but Chevron has an edge.

title: Chevron is a better bet than Exxon, Barclays says
summary: Barclays analysts rated Chevron as a better investment than Exxon, citing Chevron's "superior" cash position. The Permian Basin is a key factor for both companies, but Chevron was given a "buy" rating while Exxon received a "neutral" rating from the analysts led by Jeanine Wai.

title: Hibernia Platform Resumes Production
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp announced that production has resumed at Canada's Hibernia oil platform after a spill in mid-July. The company stated that the platform will gradually return to full production in a safe and environmentally responsible manner. ExxonMobil holds the largest stake in the Hibernia project, which has been producing oil since 1997.

title: Exxon Mobil says Hibernia oil platform resumes production
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. announced that production has resumed at its Hibernia oil platform after a spill in mid-July. The company stated that the platform will gradually return to full production in a safe and environmentally responsible manner. The Hibernia platform, which has been operational since 1997, is located east of St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, and ExxonMobil holds the largest stake in the project.

title: ETF News, Trends, Analysis, Opinions
summary: New data from discount broker Stake suggests that Australians are using their access to American exchanges to speculate on oil prices and VIX futures, with leveraged oil and gas products being particularly popular, especially among older age groups. While the Vanguard 500 Index Fund (VOO) was the most popular overall, many other highly traded ETFs were leveraged and considered "gambling devices" by the article. This trend occurs despite 3x leveraged ETFs being banned in Australia by ASIC.

title: Houston-based Occidental completes $55B deal with the Woodlands' Anadarko
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. (OXY) completed its $55 billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum Corp. (APC) on August 8, 2019. The deal value decreased slightly from the initial proposal due to a drop in Occidental's stock price, though the stock makes up less than a quarter of the purchase price. This acquisition marks one of the highest-profile energy megadeals in recent years.

title: After Anadarko merger, difficult decisions ahead for Oxy
summary: Occidental Petroleum (Oxy) has completed its $38 billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum, forming the largest player in the Permian Basin and Gulf of Mexico. This acquisition, which involved significant debt and outbidding Chevron, now forces Oxy to prioritize debt reduction, asset sales, and integrate the two companies. The company also faces a proxy war from activist investor Carl Icahn, who believes Oxy overpaid.

title: Enterprise signs long-term agreements with Chevron for US oil terminal
summary: Enterprise Products Partners LP and Chevron USA. Inc. have entered into long-term agreements to support the development of Enterprise's Sea Port Oil Terminal (SPOT) in the Gulf of Mexico. This project will enable the loading of very large crude carriers (VLCCs) and aims to expand export capacity for Permian crude oil and optimize Houston Ship Channel facilities. The final investment decision for SPOT has been made, pending government approvals, marking a significant step to balance the market and meet global demand for US production.

title: Cómo será el nuevo gasoducto a Vaca Muerta
summary: The Argentine government has called for tenders to construct a new central gas pipeline to Vaca Muerta, which will be the country's third transport concession. The project will be divided into two main stages, connecting Tratayén to Salliqueló and then extending to San Nicolás, with an estimated cost of $800 million for the first stage. Strict operational experience requirements narrow down potential operators primarily to Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS) or Transportadora Gas del Norte (TGN).

title: Chevron, Exxon earnings: Shale M&A is high on the list of investor concerns
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. are preparing to report second-quarter earnings, with investor attention focused on U.S. shale M&A activities and concerns about flagging oil demand. Chevron's upcoming earnings report will be particularly scrutinized as it follows their failed bid for Anadarko Petroleum Corp., which was ultimately acquired by Occidental Petroleum Corp.

title: Chevron Gets Approval to Keep Producing Oil in Venezuela
summary: Chevron Corp. and four oil services companies received U.S. government approval to continue oil production in Venezuela, extending a sanctions waiver for three months until October 25. This decision allows Chevron, the only major U.S. producer still in the country, to maintain its joint venture with Petroleos de Venezuela SA, ensuring U.S. interests remain while avoiding potential asset transfers to other nations. The U.S. government uses sanctions to pressure the Maduro regime, and Venezuela's opposition has guaranteed protection of Chevron's assets under a new government.

title: Giant gas stations turning into Speedway stations
summary: Giant gas stations are being rebranded as Speedway stations following a $23.3 billion merger in 2018 between Marathon Petroleum Corp. and Andeavor. Marathon, which operates Speedway, acquired Andeavor's shares, creating the largest refiner in the United States and expanding Speedway's convenience store count significantly. The cambio primarily affects visual branding and rewards programs, with gas and merchandise remaining largely similar, although fountain drink prices have been lowered.

title: Reporter’s Notebook: Mexico’s energy reforms in action at retail level
summary: Mexico's energy reforms have led to a competitive retail fuel market with foreign companies like ARCO, Chevron, and Shell, as well as private Mexican brands like OxxoGas and Rendichicas, challenging the former Pemex monopoly. This competition has resulted in diverse pricing, services, and marketing strategies at gas stations across border states like Sonora and Baja California. The article also touches on President Lopez-Obrador's nationalist approach to energy while Mexico continues to import a significant portion of its transportation fuels.

title: Tapping the opportunities of U.S. liquefied natural gas
summary: This article discusses the revolution in global energy markets driven by the abundance of U.S. natural gas and LNG plants, especially highlighting developments in Cameron Parish, Louisiana. It emphasizes the complexities and challenges for U.S. companies in this evolving market, including increasing competition and geopolitical uncertainties. The authors suggest that success depends on best-in-class capabilities in sales, marketing, trading, capital project execution, and operational excellence.

title: After 800,000-gallon spill, Chevron site is still leaking oil
summary: A Chevron oil drilling operation in Kern County continues to leak oil and water from a surface expression vent, following an 800,000-gallon spill that began in May. Senator Dianne Feinstein criticized Chevron for not publicly disclosing the leaks sooner, while California officials confirmed the ongoing seepage and ordered Chevron to address the issue. Environmental groups are calling for Chevron to be held fully accountable for the environmental damage.

title: Kitimat LNG touts natural gas reserves as it seeks 40-year export licence
summary: Kitimat LNG, a joint venture led by Chevron Corp. and Woodside Petroleum Ltd., is seeking to extend its export license to 40 years, citing vast natural gas reserves in British Columbia and Alberta. The company plans to use electric-motor-driven technology powered by hydroelectricity to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and aims for a final investment decision on terminal construction by 2022-23. The project, located on Haisla Nation reserve land, has received support from the elected Haisla band council.

title: Decreto de Necesidad y Urgencia para licitar el nuevo gasoducto desde Vaca Muerta
summary: Argentina is set to launch a national and international public tender for a new gas pipeline from Vaca Muerta, supported by an Emergency Decree (DNU) signed by President Mauricio Macri. The pipeline aims to connect the Neuquén subzone to Salliqueló and the Greater Buenos Aires/Litoral subzones, alleviating transport congestion and enabling increased natural gas production and exports. The project, estimated at $1.5 billion, will be financed by firm contracts with gas producers and power generators, with the DNU fast-tracking the process to ensure operability by winter 2021 and avoid significant economic losses.

title: Techron Advantage Cards from Chevron/Synchrony Get a Boost
summary: Chevron and Synchrony Financial have boosted their Techron Advantage Cards program. Customers can now earn up to 47¢ per gallon in Fuel Credits through various offers, including increased savings for premium fuel, new account bonuses, and Visa card purchases outside of fuel merchants, with the limited-time offer valid through December 31, 2019.

title: Is US Energy Independence On Its Way?
summary: The article discusses the concept of US energy independence, defining it primarily as becoming a net energy exporter. It highlights the US's progress towards this milestone through increased domestic oil and natural gas production and emphasizes the significant role of midstream companies in supporting this shift, despite the continued need for some energy imports due to refining requirements.

title: Is Oil on Its Way Back up to $100 Per Barrel?
summary: This article examines the factors contributing to the 2019 surge in crude oil prices, including OPEC+ production cuts, geopolitical tensions in Iran, Libya, and Venezuela, and US sanctions. It discusses whether these factors are strong enough to push oil back to $100 per barrel and highlights differing forecasts from various institutions and analysts. The piece concludes by noting the significant influence of Saudi Arabia's output decisions and the upcoming OPEC+ meeting.

title: Husband’s response to Kentuckian Kelly Craft’s government email complicates UN nomination
summary: The article details how an email response from coal magnate Joseph Craft, husband of U.S. ambassador Kelly Craft, to an EPA email addressed to his wife is complicating her nomination to be U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. Critics and ethics experts are raising concerns about the blurring of roles and potential conflicts of interest given Joseph Craft's coal industry ties and Kelly Craft's initial skepticism about climate change, despite her recent statements. This situation highlights ongoing concerns about the Trump administration's relationship with the coal industry and its impact on environmental policy.

title: BP PLC to sell offshore Malaysia gas producing assets
summary: BP PLC plans to sell its 25% interest in Block A-18 of the Malaysia-Thailand joint development area for about $500 million. This decision aligns with BP's strategy to focus on core liquefied natural gas developments in Southeast Asia where it can be a leading player. The asset was inherited from Atlantic Richfield Co., and its partners include Trans Thailand Malaysia Co. and Amerada Hess Corp.

title: 12 Stocks To Buy For Market's Upturn: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs has advised investors to view the recent stock market slump as a major buying opportunity, particularly focusing on companies with low labor costs, cyclicals, small caps, and value plays. The firm identified 25 buy-rated stocks that have fallen more than their historic correlations with the broader market, implying a faster recovery. They provided a list of 12 specific stocks, including McDonald's, Chevron, and Alphabet, that are positioned for an upturn.

title: Pembina Peace Pipeline Expansion, Alberta, Canada
summary: The Pembina Peace Pipeline, a natural gas liquids and condensate pipeline in Alberta, Canada, is undergoing multiple expansion phases to increase its capacity to 1.3 million barrels a day. Phases four and five were completed in late 2018, while phases six, seven, and eight are scheduled for commissioning between 2020 and 2022, with an estimated combined cost of $1.73 billion. These expansions will involve new pipelines, pump stations, and terminal upgrades to accommodate growing customer demand and increased production from various resource plays.

title: Oscar Sardi, CEO de TGS: “Vaca Muerta tiene que ser una política de Estado”
summary: Oscar Sardi, CEO of Transportadora Gas del Sur (TGS), emphasizes the critical importance of Vaca Muerta as a state policy for Argentina's energy future, highlighting its immense potential and the need for significant infrastructure investments. TGS is investing $300 million in a new gas pipeline in Vaca Muerta and plans to participate in the tender for the new Transportadora Gas del Centro, aiming to increase gas transport capacity and reduce imports. Sardi discusses the company's financial performance, its investment plans, and its satisfaction with current gas prices despite the country's economic situation.

title: Exclusive: Chevron Phillips Chemical in bid to acquire Nova Chemicals - sources
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Company has reportedly offered to acquire Nova Chemicals Corp for over $15 billion including debt, aiming to expand its scale and footprint. Nova Chemicals' owner, Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund Mubadala Investment Co, has been exploring a sale since the beginning of the year. There is no certainty Mubadala will accept the offer, and other bidders or a partial sale are possibilities.

title: Chevron Phillips Chemical in $15 billion bid to acquire Nova Chemicals
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical (CPCHEM) has made a US$15 billion bid to acquire Nova Chemicals, a move that would make CPCHEM the third-largest polyethylene producer in North America and the largest producer of high-density polyethylene (HDPE) in the region. The acquisition is expected to create significant synergies in the polyethylene and polystyrene sectors, expanding CPCHEM's geographic market reach and technological edge. This deal underscores the trend of "Big Oil" diversifying into the petrochemical sector as a growth engine and a means for margin security amidst a consolidating market and challenging economic outlook.

title: Italian Energy Giant Rejects Suspected Iran Oil
summary: Italian oil company Eni SpA rejected a shipment of suspected Iranian crude oil, citing specifications that did not match its contract and properties consistent with Iranian crude. This incident highlights the challenges energy companies face in navigating US sanctions against Iran, due to the Iranian regime's deceptive shipping practices like ship-to-ship transfers and disabling tracking systems. The rejected cargo, originally believed to be Iraqi oil from Nigeria’s Oando PLC, had been transferred multiple times before reaching Eni.
source: National Council of Resistance of Iran - NCRI
source_domain: National Council of Resistance of Iran - NCRI

title: Sources: Chevron Phillips Chemical in bid to acquire Nova Chemicals
authors: Reuters Greg Roumeliotis and Harry Brumpton
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Company has reportedly offered to acquire Nova Chemicals Corp for over $15 billion, including debt. Nova Chemicals' owner, Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment Co, has been exploring a sale since the beginning of the year, although there's no certainty the offer will be accepted, and other bidders may emerge. This acquisition would allow Chevron Phillips Chemical to expand its scale and footprint in the petrochemical industry.

title: Anadarko approves $20 billion LNG export project in Mozambique
summary: U.S. energy firm Anadarko Petroleum Corp has approved a $20 billion gas liquefaction and export terminal in Mozambique, marking Africa's largest single LNG project. This decision was largely expected and is set to transform Mozambique's economy while positioning the project to meet growing Asian and European energy demands. The project secured long-term buyers despite a recent slump in LNG prices, demonstrating industry confidence in future demand.

title: Energy Investing Showdown: Midstream/MLPs vs. Majors vs. Broader Energy
summary: This article compares midstream/MLPs, integrated energy majors (like Exxon and Chevron), and broader energy investments, highlighting their defensive characteristics and performance. Midstream has outperformed this year due to its fee-based business model and resilience to commodity price volatility. The article also discusses tradeoffs in yield, oil price sensitivity, and diversification for investors considering these energy investment options.

title: Inside General Electric's moves to turn off the lights at its venture capital arm
summary: General Electric is looking to sell off its venture capital arm, GE Ventures, which has invested in hundreds of companies since its founding in 2013. The portfolio, valued at approximately $500 million, is considered to be of moderate strength and is subject to significant discounts in the secondary market. GE Ventures is effectively no longer making new investments as it seeks a buyer and evaluates strategic options.

title: Eni enters into cooperation pact with KazMunayGas
summary: Kazakhstan’s state-owned oil and gas company KazMunayGas (KMG) and Eni’s affiliate, Agip Caspian Sea B.V., signed a memorandum of cooperation to expand their relationship. The pact focuses on technological cooperation in hydrocarbon exploration and production, co-development opportunities, and staff training for KMG. This agreement strengthens their long-term partnership, particularly as partners in the giant Kashagan field.

title: Pipeline update: Where these 2 projects through the Lehigh Valley stand, amid continuing Pa. natural gas boom
summary: This article provides an update on two natural gas pipeline projects, PennEast Pipeline and Adelphia Gateway, moving through the Lehigh Valley as Pennsylvania's natural gas production continues to boom. It details the status of each project, including regulatory approvals, environmental concerns, and their purposes for domestic energy supply in the region. The article also touches on the broader context of Pennsylvania's natural gas industry, its role in electricity generation, and the ongoing debate surrounding pipeline development and exports.

title: Anadarko’s CEO gets a $98 million golden parachute after sale
summary: Anadarko Petroleum Corp.'s CEO Al Walker is set to receive a $98 million golden parachute following the company's $38 billion sale to Occidental Petroleum Corp. This payout is part of a larger $300 million distribution among six senior executives. The severance terms were altered prior to the acquisition, ensuring executives would receive additional compensation and covering excise taxes on the golden parachute payments.

title: NOV in ‘historic’ 20,000 psi BOP sale to Transocean
summary: National Oilwell Varco (NOV) has made a historic sale of two 20,000-psi (20K) blowout preventer (BOP) stacks to Transocean, marking the first time such a package has been designed, engineered, and sold in the offshore oil and gas industry. These high-pressure BOP stacks are intended for Transocean's newbuild drillship, which is contracted by Chevron for operations in the Gulf of Mexico starting in 2021, focusing on ultra-deepwater and challenging reservoirs. This deal highlights a significant advancement in offshore drilling technology, enabling safer and more efficient exploration of high-pressure formations.

title: Activist investor Carl Icahn sues Occidental Petroleum over $38 billion Anadarko merger
summary: Activist investor Carl Icahn has filed a lawsuit against Occidental Petroleum over its $38 billion merger with Anadarko Petroleum, calling the deal "fundamentally misguided and hugely overpriced." Icahn, who owns $1.6 billion in Occidental stock, is seeking records related to the transaction and is considering joining other shareholders to force a revamp of the company's board of directors. The lawsuit scrutinizes Occidental CEO Vicki Hollub's leadership and her decision to sell Anadarko's African assets to Total S.A. to reduce debt.

title: British oil fields bought by Israeli company in $2bn deal
authors: Yaacov Benmeleh and Kelly Gilblom and Bloomberg
summary: Delek Group Ltd., an Israeli energy company controlled by billionaire Yitzhak Tshuva, has acquired North Sea oil and gas fields from Chevron Corp. for approximately $2 billion. This acquisition is part of Delek's strategy to expand beyond its domestic market and transform into an international oil and gas company with operational expertise. The deal is expected to significantly boost Ithaca Energy's (Delek's unit) production and reserves, with plans for a future London IPO.

title: Devon Energy Announces Strategic Exit of Canadian Business for CAD $3.8 Billion
summary: Devon Energy announced its strategic exit from its Canadian business, agreeing to sell its assets to Canadian Natural Resources Limited for CAD $3.8 billion (USD $2.8 billion). This sale is a key step in Devon's transformation into a U.S. oil growth business, with proceeds earmarked for debt reduction. The company also plans to divest its Barnett Shale gas assets by the end of 2019 to complete its focus on high-return U.S. oil plays.

title: Canadian Natural buys assets for $3.8-billion as Devon Energy exits Canada’s oil patch
summary: Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. is acquiring the Alberta assets of Devon Energy Corp. for $3.8-billion, marking another foreign company's exit from Western Canada's oil fields. The acquisition is expected to boost CNRL's earnings per share and free cash flow, making it Canada's largest crude producer. The deal highlights ongoing challenges for Alberta's oil industry, including limited export capacity and regulatory concerns.

title: Plains All American enters joint venture to expand Red River Pipeline
summary: Plains All American Pipeline has formed a joint venture with Delek US to expand the capacity of its Red River Pipeline. This $128 million deal will boost the pipeline's capacity from 150,000 to approximately 235,000 barrels per day by the first half of 2020. The expansion aligns with Plains' strategy to optimize existing systems and allows Delek, an existing customer, to significantly increase its committed capacity on the pipeline.

title: Suncor’s hydrogen-cyanide emissions exceeded permit last year; Colorado now weighing refinery’s request to increase limit
summary: Suncor Energy's Commerce City refinery exceeded its permit limit for hydrogen cyanide emissions in 2018, releasing 14.1 tons against a 12.8-ton limit. Colorado health officials have not penalized Suncor and are currently considering the refinery's request to increase its permit limit for hydrogen cyanide to 19.9 tons annually, raising concerns among residents and environmental advocates about air quality and regulatory oversight. The article highlights the ongoing debate between environmental concerns, community health impacts, and the state's regulatory approach to industrial pollution.

title: Occidental Petroleum took on the Chevron giant and won big in the Permian Basin
summary: Occidental Petroleum's CEO Vicki Hollub successfully outbid Chevron for Anadarko Petroleum Corp., securing a $38 billion deal despite Wall Street's concerns. The acquisition, backed by Total SA and Warren Buffett, is a high-stakes bet on Occidental's ability to operate Permian Basin assets more efficiently and on sustained high oil prices. This move highlights Texas's growing significance in the global oil industry due to advancements in fracking and horizontal drilling.

title: 'We are the rightful owners' of Anadarko, Occidental CEO tells shareholders
summary: Occidental Petroleum CEO Vicki Hollub defended her company's $38 billion deal for Anadarko Petroleum Corp, asserting Occidental's rightful ownership despite investor criticism over the pricey terms and the deal's impact on debt. She highlighted securing a $10 billion investment from Warren Buffett and the strategic benefits of doubling Occidental's global production and expanding its Permian Basin acreage. Shareholders, however, showed displeasure by voting less favorably for directors and the stock closed at a 10-year low.

title: Oxy CEO on Anadarko: 'We were not going to let it be taken away'
summary: Occidental Petroleum's CEO, Vicki Hollub, defended the company's decision to acquire Anadarko Petroleum for $38 billion despite investor skepticism and a significant drop in Oxy's stock. Hollub emphasized the strategic importance of Anadarko's Permian Basin acreage to Oxy's shareholders and outlined plans for cost reductions and asset sales. The acquisition was financed in part by selling Anadarko's African assets to Total and securing a $10 billion investment from Warren Buffett.

title: Oxy Agrees to Buy Anadarko for $57B
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corporation has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corporation for $57 billion, including assumed debt. This deal aims to create a "global energy leader" with significant production and is expected to deliver $3.5 billion in free cash flow improvement. The transaction followed a bidding war with Chevron, which Anadarko terminated to finalize the agreement with Occidental.

title: Chevron will not increase offer to acquire Anadarko
summary: Chevron Corp. has announced it will not increase its offer to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp. following the terms of their merger agreement. The company anticipates Anadarko will terminate the agreement, leading to a US$1 billion termination fee for Anadarko. Chevron plans to increase its share repurchase rate by 25% to US$5 billion per year, emphasizing capital discipline and shareholder value.

title: Timeline: Occidental's victory over Chevron for Anadarko
authors: Jessica Resnick-Ault and Devika Krishna Kumar
summary: This article provides a detailed timeline of Occidental Petroleum's successful bid to acquire Anadarko Petroleum for $38 billion, outmaneuvering Chevron. It highlights the multi-year pursuit, Anadarko's initial rejections, and Occidental's strategic moves, including securing investments from Berkshire Hathaway and asset sales to Total SA, which ultimately led to its victory.

title: Chevron drops Anadarko takeover battle after Occidental raises bid
summary: Chevron Corp abandoned its $33 billion takeover bid for Anadarko Petroleum Corp after Occidental Petroleum Corp raised its offer to $38 billion with a significantly higher cash component. Chevron decided the increased offer would erode shareholder value despite Anadarko being a strategic fit, and will receive a $1 billion breakup fee. Occidental's victory, backed by Warren Buffett, will strengthen its position in the Permian Basin, though some investors are wary of the debt incurred and lack of shareholder vote.

title: Occidental chief Vicki Hollub faces shareholders on cusp of Anadarko takeover victory
summary: Occidental Petroleum CEO Vicki Hollub is set to face shareholders after securing a deal to acquire Anadarko Petroleum, a victory achieved through rapid deal-making despite initial investor concerns about the $46 billion debt it would incur. The deal, which prompted Chevron to withdraw its own bid, is expected to double Occidental's global production and make it the largest oil producer in the Permian Basin, though some major shareholders have criticized the lack of a shareholder vote on the acquisition. Hollub secured crucial backing from Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and an agreement with France's Total to acquire Anadarko's non-U.S. assets.

title: Occidental CEO Vicki Hollub touts deal with Warren Buffett that helped secure US$38-billion purchase of Anadarko
summary: Occidental Petroleum CEO Vicki Hollub defended her US$38-billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum, including the terms negotiated with Warren Buffett to secure financing without shareholder approval. Despite shareholder displeasure over the significant debt and premium terms, Hollub emphasized the strategic benefits and Occidental's ability to operate the assets effectively. The deal is set to double Occidental's global production and make it the largest oil producer in the Permian Basin, though it faces criticism for financial risks and potential credit rating downgrades.

title: Where Does the United States Export Oil?
summary: The United States' crude oil exports in 2018 were primarily directed to Canada (19%), Korea (12%), and China (11%), with the top five countries accounting for 57% of total exports. When petroleum products are included, Mexico becomes the top destination. The industry is also developing infrastructure, such as Enterprise Products Partners' new export terminal, to support increasing crude oil exports.

title: Chevron ends Anadarko bidding war with Occidental
summary: Chevron has decided not to counter Occidental Petroleum's enhanced bid for Anadarko Petroleum, effectively ending the bidding war. Michael Wirth, Chevron's CEO, stated that the company would not dilute returns or erode shareholder value for the sake of a deal, implying Occidental's offer exceeded Chevron's valuation. This decision follows Anadarko's selection of Occidental's bid and Occidental's plans to sell assets and secure backing from Warren Buffett.

title: Occidental Wins Battle for Anadarko as Chevron Exits Bidding
authors: Bradley Olson and Christopher M. Matthews
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. won the bidding war for Anadarko Petroleum Corp. with a $38 billion agreement after Chevron Corp. withdrew its offer. Chevron expects to receive a $1 billion breakup fee. This deal concludes a high-stakes energy acquisition battle, positioning Occidental to significantly expand its presence in the Permian Basin and marking a major consolidation in the U.S. oil industry.

title: Occidental CEO Battles Oil-Field Giant to Rule the Permian Basin
Anadarko to terminate Chevron deal after 'superior' Occidental Petroleum offer
summary: Anadarko Petroleum Corp. intends to terminate its merger agreement with Chevron Corp. after deeming a revised offer from Occidental Petroleum Corp. as "superior." Occidental's new bid is valued at $76 per share, with a higher cash component, and includes a deal for France's Total S.A. to acquire Anadarko's African assets. Chevron has until the end of the week to revise its offer, or Anadarko will be required to pay a $1 billion termination fee.

title: Occidental CEO on verge of outmuscling a rival five times as big
summary: Occidental Petroleum CEO Vicki Hollub is poised to win a bidding war for Anadarko Petroleum Corp., outmaneuvering Chevron Corp. after securing a $10 billion investment from Warren Buffett and selling Anadarko's African assets to Total SA. Her aggressive strategy, including upping the cash portion of her offer to avoid a shareholder vote, has put Occidental in a strong position, despite investor concerns about the deal's cost. Hollub's deep expertise in the Permian Basin underpins her drive for this acquisition, which would make Occidental the largest crude producer in the region.

title: Occidental inks $8.8 billion deal to sell Anadarko's African oil and gas assets to Total
summary: Occidental Petroleum has reached a binding agreement to sell Anadarko Petroleum's African oil and gas assets to French oil major Total for $8.8 billion. This deal is contingent on Occidental successfully acquiring Anadarko, and aims to help fund Occidental's proposed $38 billion takeover bid. The divestment would leave Occidental with Anadarko's assets primarily in U.S. shale basins, the Gulf of Mexico, and South America.

title: Jordan Cove LNG slows spending, delays project to wait for permits
summary: Pembina Pipeline Corp., the backer of the Jordan Cove LNG project, is cutting its projected spending by half and delaying the project's startup by a year as it awaits key state and federal permits. The company plans to spend $50 million this year on the $10 billion project, down from a previous forecast of $100 million, while facing a challenging market with plummeted LNG prices in Asia and competition from other export facilities. Analysts like Robert McCullough suggest the project faces a significant cost disadvantage and question its viability given current market conditions and stronger competitors.

title: Occidental jet flew to Paris after Anadarko offer, data show
summary: Flight-tracking data shows Occidental Petroleum's corporate jet visited Paris on April 26th, two days after its unsolicited takeover offer for Anadarko Petroleum. Speculation suggests the visit may have been to meet with Total SA regarding the potential divestment of Anadarko's Mozambique LNG project. This Paris trip occurred two days before the same jet was seen in Omaha, where Warren Buffett committed $10 billion to Occidental's Anadarko bid.

title: Buffett's Berkshire helps bankroll Occidental's $38 billion bid for Anadarko
authors: Arathy S Nair and David French
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. committed $10 billion to Occidental Petroleum Corp.'s $38 billion bid for Anadarko Petroleum Corp., significantly boosting Occidental's chances against Chevron Corp. This investment, while positioning Occidental favorably, comes at a high cost with 8% dividends on preferred shares, raising concerns among Occidental shareholders regarding financing and potential circumvention of a shareholder vote.

title: Warren Buffett Backs Occidentals Anadarko Bid With $10 Billion Pledge
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. pledged $10 billion to Occidental Petroleum Corp. to support its $38 billion bid for Anadarko Petroleum Corp. This investment, contingent on the Anadarko deal closing, gives Occidental a significant boost against Chevron's earlier offer. Berkshire will receive preferred Occidental stock with an 8 percent annual dividend, marking a strategic deployment of Buffett's substantial cash reserves.

title: Occidental Drops as Anadarko `Obsession' Gets Buffett Help
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. (OXY) stock dropped significantly after announcing a $10 billion deal with Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. to finance its proposed acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum Corp. Investors reacted negatively, with the stock falling as much as 4.3%, marking its largest drop since Occidental's interest in Anadarko was revealed. Meanwhile, rival bidder Chevron Corp. saw its stock rise.

title: Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway to invest $10B in Occidental Petroleum for bidding war
summary: Berkshire Hathaway announced its intention to invest $10 billion in Occidental Petroleum, contingent on Occidental's proposed takeover of Anadarko Petroleum. This investment would provide Occidental with financial backing for its $38 billion rival bid for Anadarko, competing against Chevron's $33 billion offer. In return, Berkshire Hathaway would receive preferred stock and warrants to purchase common stock in Occidental.

title: Warren Buffett drops a $10-billion bomb into Anadarko bidding war
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway plans to invest $10 billion into Occidental Petroleum to support its bid to acquire Anadarko Petroleum, significantly impacting a decades-long bidding war. This substantial investment, contingent on the deal closing, provides Occidental with crucial financing and a seal of approval from Buffett, while raising questions about the high cost of his support. The move intensifies the competition between Occidental and Chevron, which has an existing agreement with Anadarko.

title: Primrose opens oil-company day care facility
summary: Primrose School of Midland at Westridge has opened to provide child care services for employees of four major oil companies: Anadarko Petroleum Corp., Chevron U.S.A., EOG Resources, and Occidental Petroleum Corp. This initiative aims to address the challenge of finding quality child care in Midland, supporting the recruitment and retention of a strong workforce. The facility offers early education for children aged 6 weeks to 5 years and after-school care for kindergarten through fifth grade.

title: Why Is Anadarko Talking to Occidental Again?
summary: Anadarko Petroleum (APC) has reopened negotiations with Occidental Petroleum (OXY) after OXY presented a superior acquisition offer of approximately $57 billion, including debt assumption, compared to Chevron's (CVX) $50 billion bid. Although Anadarko's board had previously accepted Chevron's offer, OXY's proposal of $76 per share (vs. Chevron's $65 per share) is considered a "Superior Proposal." This development is putting pressure on Chevron to sweeten its bid, while also causing a negative reaction in Occidental's stock price.

title: Top 2019 GOM Equity Producers
summary: A combined Chevron and Anadarko entity would top the list of 2019 Gulf of Mexico equity producers, according to Rystad Energy, yielding over 400,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. BP plc and Royal Dutch Shell plc secured second and third positions, respectively, while Equinor ASA and Fieldwood Energy LLC rounded out the top five. The article also mentions recent acquisition activities impacting the GOM production landscape, including Chevron's bid for Anadarko and Murphy Oil Corporation's acquisition of deepwater GOM assets.

title: New Orleans Sues Oil and Gas Companies to Preserve Wetlands, But Is That Enough?
summary: New Orleans has filed a lawsuit against 11 oil and gas companies, accusing them of destroying surrounding wetlands, similar to other suits filed by Louisiana parishes. Mayor LaToya Cantrell stated the city and its people have been harmed, with their way of life threatened by the loss of coastal wetlands. The suit alleges violations of the state's Coastal Zone Management Act of 1978, by failing to restore damage or clean up hazardous waste, contributing to the rapid land loss that exacerbated the impact of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) Q1 earnings results
summary: Bristol-Myers Squibb reported better-than-expected first-quarter 2019 results, with revenue up 14% to $5.92 billion and adjusted earnings of $1.10 per share. The biopharma company also announced shareholder approval for its acquisition of Celgene Corporation and raised its 2019 GAAP EPS guidance.

title: Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) earnings Q1 2019
summary: Amazon.com Inc. surpassed Q1 2019 earnings estimates, with revenues aligning with expectations. Net sales increased 17% year-over-year to $59.7 billion, and net income rose significantly to $3.6 billion. The company provided Q2 2019 sales and operating income guidance and announced expanded YouTube and Prime Video app availability on various devices.

title: Oxy may lack size but it's never lacked ambition
summary: Occidental Petroleum's $38 billion bid for Anadarko Petroleum, led by CEO Vicki Hollub, reflects the company's long-standing ambition despite its smaller size compared to supermajors. Hollub aims to secure Occidental's position as the top Permian producer and believes the deal will boost cash flow and moderate growth, even as analysts express skepticism and Anadarko's board maintains its recommendation for Chevron's offer. The company plans to issue new shares and sell assets to finance the acquisition.

title: Oxy makes public bid for Anadarko over Chevron
summary: Occidental Petroleum has publicly launched a bidding war for Anadarko Petroleum, offering approximately $38 billion in a cash-and-stock deal, surpassing Chevron's $33 billion offer. This move creates a rare direct confrontation between a major oil company and a smaller, yet significant, player for Anadarko's valuable Permian Basin assets. Anadarko is reviewing Oxy's new offer while sticking with Chevron for now, despite Occidental's belief that its bid is superior due to its shale expertise and focus on the Permian.

title: Occidental ups the ante on Anadarko with bid valued at $57 billion
summary: A bidding war has erupted over Anadarko Petroleum, with Occidental Petroleum Corp. making a $57 billion offer that it says is about a 20% premium to Chevron's $33 billion deal. Occidental's bid is worth $76 per share in cash and stock, aiming to bolster its position in the Permian Basin. This comes after Occidental expressed disappointment that Anadarko did not engage with its previous proposals.

title: Occidental Petroleum outbids Chevron for Anadarko Petroleum
summary: Occidental Petroleum has outbid Chevron for Anadarko Petroleum with a cash-and-stock offer valued at approximately $57 billion, a 20 percent premium over Chevron's $33 billion deal. This move intensifies the competition for Anadarko's assets, especially its lucrative Permian Basin position, Gulf of Mexico presence, and a natural gas project in Mozambique, amid rising U.S. crude prices. The takeover would significantly boost Occidental's position in the Permian Basin, with the company aiming to complete the combination by the end of the year.

title: Murphy Oil to Buy LLOG's GoM Assets
summary: Murphy Oil Corp announced its acquisition of Gulf of Mexico assets from LLOG Exploration Offshore and LLOG Bluewater Holdings for at least $1.38 billion in cash. This strategic move aims to strengthen Murphy Oil's position in the region, adding 32,000 to 35,000 net barrels of oil equivalent per day to their GoM production. The acquisition aligns with Murphy's focus on the Western Hemisphere, particularly the U.S. Gulf of Mexico.

title: Robots in the Permian? Climate concerns drive innovation
summary: Oil supermajors like Chevron and Exxon Mobil are heavily investing in the Permian Basin, using advanced automation, cloud computing, and AI to maximize oil extraction. This strategy is seen as a hedge against future climate change regulations and potential drops in oil demand, allowing for quick returns and flexibility. However, environmentalists criticize the focus on fossil fuels, and some experts question the feasibility of the desired automation and the long-term sustainability of shale production.

title: On day before Chevron announcement, Anadarko sweetened severance for top execs
summary: Anadarko Petroleum Corp. modified severance terms for its senior executives, including CEO Al Walker, the day before Chevron Corp.'s $33 billion buyout offer was announced. These changes, which include increased bonus payouts and tax payments on golden parachute deals, could boost Walker's payout by $6.7 million and increase total executive compensation by almost $22 million. An energy economist suggests the changes were a reward for the management team, given that most Anadarko executives are not expected to be retained by Chevron.

title: ConocoPhillips sells UK business to Chrysaor for $2.7 billion
summary: ConocoPhillips has agreed to sell its two UK subsidiaries, holding its exploration and production assets in the UK, to Chrysaor for $2.675 billion. This acquisition will make Chrysaor one of the largest oil and gas producers in the UK North Sea, significantly increasing its production and reserves. ConocoPhillips will use the proceeds for general corporate purposes as it focuses its portfolio on new low-cost opportunities.

title: PepsiCo (PEP) posts upbeat Q1 2019 earnings
summary: PepsiCo announced upbeat first-quarter 2019 earnings, with net revenue increasing by 3% to $12.9 billion and net attributable income rising 6% to $1.4 billion, both exceeding market expectations. The company also provided a positive full-year 2019 outlook, anticipating 4% organic revenue growth and $8 billion in total cash returns to shareholders. CEO Ramon Laguarta highlighted strong performance across several divisions despite adverse foreign exchange rates.

title: Chevron buying Anadarko, will likely take over operations of Roraima Block
summary: Chevron Corp. announced a $33-billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum Corp., a deal that will significantly expand Chevron's presence in U.S. shale oil and African liquefied natural gas, positioning it among the top global energy companies. This acquisition means Chevron will likely take over Anadarko's operations on the Roraima Block offshore Guyana, where Anadarko's exploration was previously halted by a Venezuelan Navy interception. The deal is expected to create a formidable competitor to ExxonMobil and Royal Dutch Shell, with Chevron planning to divest $15 billion to $20 billion in assets to reduce debt and return cash to investors.

title: Chevron Leaps to `Ultramajor' Oil Status With Anadarko Deal
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp. in a $33 billion cash-stock deal, significantly expanding its U.S. shale oil and African liquefied natural gas assets. This acquisition propels Chevron into the top tier of global energy companies, putting it on par with the production levels of Exxon Mobil Corp. and Royal Dutch Shell Plc. The combined entity's cash flow in the prior year would have surpassed Exxon's.

title: Chevron vaults into new league by buying Anadarko for $33 billion
summary: Chevron announced a $33 billion cash-and-stock deal to acquire Anadarko Petroleum, significantly boosting its position in the Permian Basin, Gulf of Mexico, and LNG business in Mozambique. This acquisition transforms Chevron from the fourth largest producer among major drillers to the second, creating what analysts are calling an "UltraMajor." The deal is expected to close in the second half of the year, subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, and includes plans for increased stock buybacks and asset divestitures.

title: Chevron vaults into new league with $33B acquisition of Anadarko, one of Colorado's largest oil and gas operators
summary: Chevron announced its acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum for $33 billion in a cash-and-stock deal, significantly expanding its operations in deepwater exploration and particularly in the Permian Basin and Delaware Basin. This move vaults Chevron from the fourth to the second-largest producer among major drillers, making it an "UltraMajor" and enhancing its LNG business and presence in Colorado. The deal, which includes a bump in stock buybacks and asset divestitures, is pending shareholder and regulatory approval and reflects a strategic move amidst volatile oil prices.

title: Chevron Buys Anadarko
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp. for $33 billion, a move that significantly boosts Chevron's footprint in Permian shale oil and liquefied natural gas. The deal, valued at $50 billion including debt, is expected to enhance free cash flow and earnings per share for Chevron within a year of closing, and generate $1 billion in cost synergies.

title: Chevron, Anadarko Beyond 'Just a Shale Deal,' as Global Options Expand
summary: Chevron announced a $33 billion merger with Anadarko Petroleum Corp., creating the No. 1 U.S. producer with expanded global natural gas and oil opportunities. The deal, valued at $50 billion including debt, significantly strengthens Chevron's position in the Permian Basin, deepwater Gulf of Mexico, and LNG export business while aiming for $2 billion in annual synergies. Analysts view this as a strategic move beyond just shale, propelling Chevron into the top echelon of global oil and gas producers.

title: Twice as many companies paying zero taxes under Trump tax plan
summary: A new analysis by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (ITEP) reveals that 60 large U.S. companies paid no federal income taxes in 2018, more than double the average in previous years, despite earning billions in profits. This increase is largely attributed to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, which significantly lowered the corporate tax rate and introduced new tax breaks. Companies like Amazon, Netflix, Chevron, Eli Lilly, and Deere & Co. are among those that effectively paid zero taxes, leading to a substantial impact on the federal budget.

title: Brownsville: Three LNG Facility Projects on Track to Commence Exports in 2023-2024
summary: Three major LNG facility projects in Brownsville, including Rio Grande LNG, Texas LNG, and Annova LNG, are moving forward to begin exports in 2023-2024. These projects, located at the Port of Brownsville, involve significant investment, job creation, and environmental considerations. Regulatory approvals are progressing, with Final Investment Decisions and construction anticipated in the near future.

title: Second Large Plastics Manufacturer — Chevron Phillips Chemical — Agrees to Report on Plastic Pollution Pellet Spills
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. has agreed to publically report on spills of pre-production plastic pellets, known as nurdles, following engagement with the Plastic Pollution Coalition member As You Sow. This agreement comes after similar action by ExxonMobil and mandates reporting on pellet loss, recovery, best practices, and supply chain engagement, with third-party auditing to verify data. The move aims to increase transparency regarding plastic pellet pollution, which is a significant source of ocean microplastic and harmful to marine life.

title: First E&P Spuds First Well on Anyala & Madu
summary: First E&P has commenced drilling operations for its first well in the development of the Anyala and Madu fields in Oil Mining Leases (OMLs) 83 & 85, offshore central Niger Delta. The project, involving Borr Drilling and financed in part by Schlumberger ($724 million), aims for 20 wells to drain the fields, which hold an estimated 193 million barrels of oil and 0.637 trillion cubic feet of gas. While first oil was initially expected in late 2019, the current drilling schedule suggests a delay in achieving this target.

title: Canadian court dismisses Ecuador’s $9.5 billion claim against Chevron Canada
summary: The Supreme Court of Canada has dismissed a $9.5 billion claim against Chevron Canada by residents of Ecuador's Lago Agrio region. The claim stemmed from water and soil contamination caused by Texaco (later acquired by Chevron) between 1964 and 1992. The Canadian court ruled that Chevron Canada is a separate entity from its parent company, preventing the seizure of its assets to enforce the Ecuadorian judgment.

title: Chevron, Woodside apply to nearly double size of Canadian LNG project
summary: Chevron Canada Ltd. and Woodside Energy Ltd. have applied to significantly expand their Kitimat LNG plant in northern British Columbia, aiming to nearly double its production capacity to 18 million tonnes per annum (mtpa). This expansion, which involves a revised design that may include up to three LNG trains, seeks to improve the project's cost competitiveness globally. The move follows the approval of the LNG Canada project and signals a potential boon for western Canadian natural gas producers.

title: East Bay Jury Orders Chevron To Pay $21M For Cancer Claims
summary: A Northern California jury ordered Chevron Corp. to pay the families of two brothers, Gary and Randy Eaves, a combined $21.4 million after concluding the company failed to properly warn them about the dangers of the toxic solvent benzene. The brothers died of cancer, and the jury found that Chevron's subsidiary, Unocal, produced the solvent they worked with at a tire factory. Chevron is evaluating its legal options.

title: BP already hit its methane targets. Or did it?
summary: BP announced it met its ambitious methane emissions target of 0.2 percent of total production by the end of 2018, just a year after setting it. This rapid achievement raises questions among environmental groups about the methodologies used and the transparency of the data, as they advocate for clearer demonstration and validation of such claims in the industry. The company's actions are set against a backdrop of increasing scrutiny on natural gas's climate impact and ongoing efforts to roll back federal methane regulations.

title: ArcelorMittal USA LLC v Essar Steel Limited and others
summary: The Commercial Court continued a US$1.5 billion Worldwide Freezing Order, Search Order, and Norwich Pharmacal Orders against Essar Group and associated individuals, stemming from ArcelorMittal USA's efforts to enforce an ICC Award for over US$1.5 billion. The judgment from Jacobs J provides significant guidance on combating international fraud and enforcing foreign arbitral awards, even against foreign defendants with no apparent assets in England. The court found justifying circumstances for the orders due to the presence of persons and papers in England capable of identifying hidden assets.

title: U.S. Natural Gas Consumption Reaches Record in 2018
summary: U.S. natural gas consumption hit a record high in 2018, increasing by 10 percent due to rising oil prices and a greater reliance on natural gas for electricity generation across all sectors. Extreme weather conditions, including prolonged cold and record-high summer temperatures, further boosted consumption in the electric power sector. Despite potential trade tensions with China, the natural gas market saw no major disruptions, though analysts anticipate increased trading once a permanent trade deal is established.

title: Citgo, Valero try to return Venezuelan oil following sanctions
summary: Top U.S. buyers of Venezuelan oil, including Citgo and Valero, are attempting to return millions of barrels of crude due to U.S. sanctions imposed on Venezuela and its state-run oil company, PDVSA. Over 6 million barrels of Venezuelan crude are in limbo, as U.S. firms cannot pay PDVSA, and the Guaido administration lacks bank accounts to receive funds. This situation has led to stranded tankers, accumulating demurrage fees, and a scramble by PDVSA to avoid further export shortfalls amid declining oil shipments.

title: Corporate Counsel awards: Chevron's Melissa Brown Sladden pays it forward
summary: Melissa Brown Sladden, Senior Counsel at Chevron Corporation, was recognized at the Bay Area Corporate Counsel Awards 2019 in the Diversity category. She chairs Chevron's Law Function Diversity Council, which promotes inclusion and diversity among both in-house attorneys and external legal partners. The article highlights her role in fostering diversity within the legal profession.

title: Venezuela must pay Conoco over $8 billion - World Bank
summary: The World Bank ruled that Venezuela must pay ConocoPhillips over $8 billion as compensation for the 2007 expropriation of its oil assets by Hugo Chavez's government. This makes ConocoPhillips the largest beneficiary in claims stemming from nationalizations in Venezuela, although the company may face challenges in collecting the payment given Venezuela's history with arbitration cases and its current economic crisis.

title: Chevron awards Matrix ionic alkylation unit construction
summary: Chevron has awarded Matrix Service Inc. the construction contract for the first ionic alkylation unit in the U.S. at its Salt Lake City refinery. This unit will replace an existing hydrofluoric acid alkylation unit and utilize the ISOALKY™ technology to produce cleaner-burning fuels. Matrix Service Co. expressed pride in being selected for this historic project, highlighting its long-standing relationship with Chevron.

title: CrossAmerica Partners Closes Out 2018 With Flurry of Activity
summary: CrossAmerica Partners LP finalized plans for 192 convenience stores acquired from Circle K's parent company, Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc., making significant progress on the dealerization process. The company also secured a new supply contract for former Jet-Pep sites and achieved $9.5 million in cost savings through synergies with Couche-Tard. CrossAmerica plans to continue growth initiatives in 2019 without requiring additional capital, focusing on fuel strategic reviews, rebranding efforts, and evaluating third-party acquisitions.

title: Is LNG the New Oil?
summary: The global LNG market is rapidly growing, impacting international relations and geopolitical strategies due to its role in energy transformation and security. The U.S. has emerged as a significant player, influencing global LNG trade dynamics with its market-based approach and flexible contracts, leading to intense competition and shifting energy policies worldwide. This transformation has positioned LNG in international political discourse, drawing parallels to how oil has historically influenced global affairs.

title: ‘San Ramon Voyager’ takes to the high seas
summary: Chevron's new crude oil tanker, the "San Ramon Voyager," has begun transporting oil primarily between the Arabian Gulf and the United States. The vessel, named after the city where Chevron's global headquarters are located, was dedicated in Okpo, South Korea, on January 4. It has a capacity of 2 million barrels of oil and is one of seven new vessels modernizing Chevron's fleet, equipped with new technology for improved efficiency and reduced emissions.

title: Texas Shale Forces Big Oil Cost Revolution, Chevron CEO Says
summary: Chevron CEO Mike Wirth states that the low break-even costs in the Permian Basin are forcing Chevron, and the oil industry at large, to become significantly more efficient across all operations. He emphasizes a strategy of continuous cost discipline and preparing for lower energy prices, rather than betting on high prices. This approach allows Chevron to focus investment on high-return areas like the Permian, even as other projects are abandoned.

title: CDU shut by Phillips 66 Wood River, Illinois refinery fire: Source
summary: A fire broke out on Sunday at Phillips 66's Wood River, Illinois, refinery, leading to the shutdown of its second-largest crude distillation unit (CDU). One person sustained burns and was hospitalized, though their injuries were not life-threatening. The 120,000 bpd DU-2 CDU was returning to production after an overhaul when the incident occurred.

title: Exxon's Darren Woods is about to do something its CEO hasn't done in 15 years
summary: ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods is set to speak on an earnings conference call, breaking a 15-year company tradition previously held by his predecessor, Rex Tillerson. This change reflects increased pressure on Exxon after a significant stock drop and underperformance relative to peers. Woods will address fourth-quarter results, with analysts keenly watching for improvements in production, profit, refining performance, Permian basin output, and capital expenditure plans.

title: Enterprise Products Partners closes 2018 with $4.1 billion profit amid record shipments
summary: Enterprise Products Partners closed 2018 with a $4.2 billion profit, driven by record shipments of crude oil, natural gas, and natural gas liquids. The company exceeded analyst expectations for earnings per share in Q4 but missed revenue estimates. CEO Jim Teague highlighted 23 new operational and financial records set in 2018 due to increased volumes and higher marketing margins.

title: It's official: Chevron to buy Petrobras refinery
summary: Chevron officially announced its acquisition of Petrobras' refinery in Pasadena, marking it as Chevron's sole refinery in Texas. This move follows previous reports and coincides with expansion efforts in Chevron's Permian operations. The acquisition is a significant development for Chevron's presence in the Houston area.

title: Petro Rio Buys Chevron's Frade Field in Brazil Expansion
summary: Independent Brazilian oil producer Petro Rio SA is set to acquire Chevron Corp.'s 52 percent stake in the Frade field off Brazil's coast, giving Petro Rio 70 percent ownership and operational control. This acquisition will make Petro Rio the largest Brazil-based independent oil producer, with an estimated output of 28,000 barrels of equivalent oil per day and sparked a significant rise in its shares. The deal is rumored to be worth over $500 million.

title: Chevron CIO Says Technology Triggers Faster Human Decisions
summary: Chevron's CIO, Bill Braun, discusses how technology is enabling faster decision-making within the energy giant. He notes that the increasing pressure to innovate rapidly across industries is changing the nature of his role, emphasizing the critical need for quick reactions.

title: Tsakos orders suezmax pair at Hyundai Samho
summary: Tsakos Energy Navigation (TEN) has ordered two 158,000 dwt suezmax tankers from Hyundai Samho. These vessels are expected to be delivered in 2020 and will be chartered to Chevron, with each vessel priced at $65 million. This addition will expand TEN's fleet, which also includes other tankers and LNG carriers.

title: Saudi Aramco Refinery Is Hiring Advisers on Funding a $5 Billion Project
summary: Satorp, a joint venture between Saudi Aramco and Total SA, has hired Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. and Riyad Bank to advise on funding a $5 billion petrochemical facility project in Saudi Arabia. The "Amiral" project, which will convert fossil fuels into plastics building blocks, is expected to secure financing from banks and export credit agencies. This move aligns with Saudi Arabia's strategy to increase revenue from petrochemicals.

title: Oil industry makes landmark investment in CO2 air capture
summary: Chevron Corp. and Occidental Petroleum Corp. have made a landmark investment in Carbon Engineering, a company deploying technology to capture carbon dioxide directly from the air. This significant collaboration marks the first major public equity investment by oil companies in a direct air capture firm, aiming to accelerate the technology's commercialization and deployment. The move comes as direct air capture gains traction, with new federal tax credits and increasing recognition of its potential role in addressing climate change, despite some environmental criticisms regarding its cost-effectiveness compared to other carbon capture methods.

title: Chevron, Occidental invest in CO2 removal technology
summary: Canada-based Carbon Engineering has received investment from Occidental Petroleum Corp.'s subsidiary and Chevron Corp.'s venture capital arm for its direct air capture (DAC) technology, which removes carbon dioxide directly from the air. The firm, founded in 2009, develops technology that captures CO2 and converts it into low-carbon fuels and for enhanced oil recovery, aiming to accelerate commercialization with the new investments. These energy industry leaders are expected to significantly boost the deployment of Carbon Engineering's DAC and Air to Fuels technologies.

title: State Of American Energy 2019
summary: The "State of American Energy 2019" report, "America’s Generation Energy," highlights the crucial role of natural gas and oil in driving U.S. economic health, global security, and individual prosperity. API President and CEO Mike Sommers emphasized how this "Generation Energy" is reshaping the global energy balance, fueling manufacturing, and leading environmental progress. The report also detailed polling results showing strong American support for natural gas and oil, and panel discussions addressed infrastructure needs and the Renewable Fuel Standard.

title: Occidental Wins Battle for Anadarko as Chevron Exits Bidding
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. has successfully outbid Chevron for Anadarko Petroleum Corp., securing a $38 billion agreement after Chevron withdrew its offer. Chevron expects to receive a $1 billion breakup fee. Both companies sought Anadarko for its valuable assets in the Permian Basin, with Occidental now poised to significantly expand its presence in the region.

title: Occidental Wins Battle for Anadarko as Chevron Exits Bidding
authors: Bradley Olson and Christopher M. Matthews
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp. secured a $38 billion agreement to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp., as Chevron Corp. withdrew from the bidding war. This outcome concludes a significant energy-deal drama, with Occidental set to expand its presence in the highly sought-after Permian Basin. Chevron is expected to receive a $1 billion breakup fee.

title: New Mexico oil producers brace for tighter regulation as output jumps
summary: New Mexico's oil producers are anticipating stricter regulations as Democratic leadership takes over, despite a significant increase in crude oil output. The incoming administration plans to limit new leasing on state lands to protect freshwater aquifers and crack down on methane emissions to boost tax revenue. This shift is expected to make drilling more expensive and challenging for operators in the state.

title: Oil surges 10% after the settle, rebounding with stocks from Christmas Eve sell-off
summary: Oil prices, for both international Brent and U.S. WTI crude, surged significantly on Wednesday, rebounding from sharp losses experienced on Christmas Eve. The rebound was attributed to a relief rally in conjunction with a strong stock market performance, with some traders suggesting the prior sell-off was overdone. Despite the short-term recovery, concerns remain regarding global economic growth and demand, though analysts also note OPEC's efforts to stabilize the market.

title: Causas de corrupción podrían impedir inversiones estadounidenses en empresas argentinas
summary: US corruption concerns may hinder American investments in Argentine companies, particularly those with executives implicated in ongoing judicial cases. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) has warned that loans to firms like Tecpetrol, Genneia, and TGS, totaling over $800 million, will be contingent on rigorous reviews of executives and companies facing corruption investigations. Specific cases highlighted include Paolo Rocca of Techint and Jorge Brito of Genneia, impacting projects in gas and renewable energy crucial for Argentina's infrastructure.

title: 5 things to know in Texas energy this week
summary: The first export of liquefied natural gas (LNG) from Texas has been shipped from Cheniere Energy Inc.'s Corpus Christi facility. This announcement, made on Dec. 11, marks a significant milestone for the state's energy sector. The article highlights this as a key event in Texas energy for the week of December 17, 2018.

title: Stock of the week: Chevron
summary: Chevron announced a significant increase in its capital expenditure budget for 2019, marking the first such increase in four years, with a focus on high-return, short-cycle projects, particularly in its upstream business. Despite past struggles during low oil prices, Chevron has a strong dividend policy and improved financial ratios, positioning it well among its peers. The company's stock is trading within a consolidation range, with potential for upside given anticipated oil market rebounds.

title: Premier Oil Said to Eye Bid for Chevron's U.K. North Sea Assets
summary: Premier Oil Plc is reportedly considering a bid for Chevron Corp.'s U.K. North Sea oil and gas assets, valued at approximately $2 billion. Premier, with a market value of around $733 million, may seek a partner or acquire only the operating rights for the assets, with first-round bids due by the end of the month. No final decision has been made, and Premier may still opt against a bid.

title: American Institute of Chemical Engineers praises companies for inspiring female engineers
summary: The American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) honored Pfizer and Covestro for their commitment to inspiring and empowering women in engineering at a gala in New York City. Pfizer was recognized for its support of female engineers, women in leadership, and women-owned businesses, while Covestro was lauded for championing women in manufacturing, corporate leadership, and STEM fields, exemplified by its investment in global mentorship programs. The event also recognized Nance Dicciani with the AIChE Foundation’s Doing a World of Good Medal and raised approximately $570,000 to support programs for women in engineering.

title: Hybrid Power for Offshore Drilling Rig
summary: Siemens announced it will supply its BlueVault lithium-ion energy storage solution to Northern Drilling Ltd.'s West Mira offshore rig, making it the world's first to operate a low-emission hybrid power plant. This system aims to reduce operating costs and environmental impact by cutting CO2 emissions by 15% and NOx emissions by 12%. The technology is based on field-proven solutions used in over 60 marine vessels and will help optimize diesel engine operation and provide backup power.

title: Debra Reed-Klages elected to Chevron’s board of directors
summary: Debra Reed-Klages has been elected to Chevron Corp.'s board of directors. She recently retired as executive chairman of Sempra Energy and held various leadership roles there and at its subsidiaries, San Diego Gas & Electric and Southern California Gas Co. Michael K. Wirth, Chevron's Chairman and CEO, highlighted her extensive experience in regulated utilities and energy infrastructure, along with her nearly two decades on Halliburton's Board, as valuable assets to Chevron and its stockholders.

title: Sempra’s ex-CEO joins Chevron BoD
summary: Debra Reed-Klages, former CEO of Sempra Energy, has been appointed to Chevron's board of directors, effective immediately. She will serve on the Management Compensation Committee and the Public Policy Committee. Reed-Klages brings extensive experience from her tenure at Sempra and her previous board positions at Caterpillar Inc. and Halliburton.

title: Worlds biggest oil traders bribed Petrobras staff: prosecutors
summary: Prosecutors allege that top oil trading firms Vitol, Trafigura, and Glencore paid over $30 million in bribes to employees of Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrobras, between 2011 and 2014. The scheme involved Petrobras staff offering lower prices for oil and storage in exchange for kickbacks, a part of the wider "Car Wash" corruption probe. This revelation surfaces as Petrobras attempts to rebuild its reputation and pursue privatization plans.
