title: Exclusive: Exxon, Chevron seek to exit Azerbaijan's oil after 25 years
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are looking to sell their stakes in Azerbaijan's largest oilfield, Azeri-Chirag-Gunashli (ACG), after 25 years of involvement. Exxon aims to raise up to $2 billion for its 6.8 percent stake, while Chevron is selling its 9.57 percent stake in ACG and 8.9 percent interest in the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline, as both companies refocus on domestic production and other major projects. This move marks the retreat of U.S. majors from a project once hoped to diversify Europe's energy supply from Russia.

title: Vessel Arrives At Cheniere's Corpus Christi LNG Plant
summary: A liquefied natural gas (LNG) vessel, the Maria Energy, arrived at Cheniere Energy Inc's Corpus Christi LNG export facility, marking the second vessel visit since production began in November. This arrival suggests the facility is actively producing LNG and could be its first cargo pickup, following the Sabine Pass terminal which has already delivered around 500 cargoes. The article details Cheniere's expansion plans with new liquefaction trains at both Corpus Christi and Sabine Pass terminals set to become operational in the coming years, contributing to the significant growth of U.S. LNG exports.

title: Nvidia Corp. (NVDA) earnings Q3 2019
summary: Nvidia Corp. (NVDA) reported a surge in Q3 2019 earnings per share, beating estimates, despite revenue falling short of expectations and weak Q4 guidance. The company's stock dropped 16% in after-hours trading due to the revenue miss and outlook. Nvidia saw strong growth in its Datacenter business and other segments, while also announcing increased dividends and share repurchase plans.

title: Pioneer Natural Resources sells pressure pumping assets to ProPetro
summary: Pioneer Natural Resources announced the sale of its pressure pumping business to ProPetro Holding Corp. for $400 million, comprised of cash and ProPetro stock. This deal establishes ProPetro as a strategic, long-term service provider to Pioneer for up to 10 years, expanding ProPetro's operations in the Permian Basin and allowing Pioneer to enhance capital efficiency. The transaction is expected to close in Q4 2018, subject to regulatory approval.

title: Halliburton CFO Leaves After 17 Months
summary: Chris Weber, Halliburton's CFO for 17 months, is leaving the company, with Lance Loeffler, VP of investor relations, named as his replacement. The change comes as Halliburton's shares have significantly declined, amid a tough environment for oil and gas stocks and infrastructure constraints affecting demand for its services. Loeffler, with his financial expertise and experience with the investment community, is expected to lead the company's financial strategy.

title: ExtraMile Convenience Stores Celebrates 800th Store Milestone
summary: ExtraMile Convenience Stores, a joint venture between Chevron U.S.A. Inc. and Jacksons Food Stores Inc., announced the opening of its 800th store in West Covina, Calif. This milestone is part of a larger expansion plan, with the company aiming to grow to 1,400 ExtraMile sites nationwide by 2027. G&M Oil Co. LLC, one of ExtraMile's largest franchisees, operates the new store.

title: Chevron, Exxon Mobil weigh bids for Endeavor Energy
summary: Chevron Corp. and Exxon Mobil Corp. are reportedly considering first-round bids for the closely held oil producer Endeavor Energy Resources LP, which could be valued at approximately $15 billion including debt. ConocoPhillips and Royal Dutch Shell Plc may also participate in the auction, though Endeavor's founder prefers an initial public offering in 2019 to retain control. This potential sale highlights increased deal activity in the North American oil and gas market, particularly in the Permian Basin.

title: Earnings: Plug Power shrinks Q3 loss as revenue beats estimates
summary: Hydrogen fuel cell maker Plug Power Inc reported a significant decrease in its Q3 loss and beat revenue estimates, with net revenue soaring 54% to $53.2 million. The company's net loss shrunk to $0.07 per share, demonstrating improved financial performance. Plug Power also highlighted robust sales of GenDrive fuel cell units and GenFuel hydrogen stations, leading to lifted gross revenue targets for fiscal 2018.

title: Chevron announces senior leadership changes
summary: Chevron announced several senior leadership changes effective March 1, 2019. Steven W. Green will become President of Chevron North America Exploration and Production, succeeding Jeff Shellebarger. Nigel Hearne will replace Green as President of Chevron Asia Pacific Exploration and Production.

title: Chevron quarterly profit doubles as U.S. oil production jumps
summary: Chevron's quarterly profit doubled due to record oil and gas production and higher crude oil prices, despite one-time expenses. The company's net income significantly exceeded analysts' estimates, reflecting strong financial results for major oil companies in the third quarter. Shares saw a premarket rise but had declined in the preceding month.

title: Chevron to pay $150 million in settlement with EPA for violating Clean Air Act
summary: Chevron will pay $150 million and incur an additional $2.95 million in civil penalties as part of a national settlement with the EPA, U.S. Department of Justice, and Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality. The settlement addresses repeated violations of the Clean Air Act, including a 2012 fire at its Richmond refinery that led to 15,000 residents seeking medical attention and other incidents in 2013 at its El Segundo and Pascagoula refineries. This settlement, totaling over $160 million, is the largest in EPA history for enforcing the Clean Air Act's risk management plan rule.

title: Chevron agrees to pay $163 million on fine and upgrades to end probes
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to pay a nearly $3 million fine and spend $160 million on environmental improvements and upgrading oil refineries to resolve allegations of pollution law violations. This settlement ends investigations in four states where Chevron's refineries experienced fires or chemical releases, including a 2013 explosion in Mississippi and a 2012 fire in Richmond, California. The company will invest $10 million in environmental projects in the four states and $150 million to upgrade its refineries nationwide.

title: Chevron to end regulators’ probes by upgrading refineries and doing environmental work
summary: Chevron has agreed to pay a nearly $3-million fine and invest $160 million in environmental improvements and refinery upgrades to settle allegations of violating pollution laws. This agreement resolves investigations in California, Mississippi, Utah, and Hawaii, stemming from incidents including a fatal 2013 explosion and a 2012 fire that caused mass evacuations. The company will spend $10 million on environmental projects in affected states and $150 million on national refinery upgrades.

title: Exxon is lobbying for a carbon tax. There is, obviously, a catch.
summary: ExxonMobil announced it would spend $1 million lobbying for a US carbon tax, a move that comes with a significant caveat: the company wants immunity from all future climate change lawsuits. This proposal is seen by some as a strategic move to establish climate policy on its own terms and prevent more stringent regulations, rather than a genuine concern for curbing emissions. The article discusses why Exxon might support a carbon tax, the limitations of their proposed $40 per ton price, and the controversy surrounding their demand for legal immunity from climate change litigation.

title: Kosmos Energy announces results of Pontoenoe-1 well
summary: Kosmos Energy's Pontoenoe-1 well offshore Suriname did not discover commercial hydrocarbons despite encountering high-quality reservoirs, as the primary objective proved water-bearing due to a lack of trap. The company believes there is still significant potential in Block 42, given evidence of a mature source and quality Cretaceous reservoir, and plans to test the next prospect in 2020. Kosmos, Hess, and Chevron are partners in exploring Block 42.

title: Murphy takes over Petrobras Gulf of Mexico assets in $1.1B JV deal
summary: Murphy Oil has acquired Petrobras's Gulf of Mexico assets in a joint-venture deal valued at "up to $1.1 billion," giving Murphy 80 percent participation. The transaction included a $900 million cash payment and additional payments of up to $150 million until 2025, significantly enhancing Murphy's production and reserves in the region. Petrobras benefits from the cash inflow and a better-balanced risk-return portfolio.

title: Chevron Quits Norway
summary: Chevron Corp. is selling its last remaining oil exploration license in Norway, signaling a full retreat from the North Sea basin to pursue higher returns elsewhere. This move follows similar divestments in the U.K. and Denmark, making Chevron the first oil major to completely exit Norway. The company's departure comes after its last major prospect in the region, Korpfjell, proved to be uncommercial.

title: Unions accuse Chevron of 'massive' tax avoidance via the Netherlands
summary: International and Dutch unions have filed a complaint with the OECD, accusing Chevron Corp. of using Dutch letter box companies to avoid billions in taxes. The unions argue that Chevron's alleged tax avoidance deprives workers of essential government services and deepens global wealth inequality. Chevron denies the accusations, stating it complies with all tax laws.

title: The opportunities and threats for the Three Seas Initiative
summary: The Three Seas Initiative, led by Poland, aims to foster regional integration among 12 Central and Eastern European EU member states to improve energy, transportation, and digitalization infrastructure. This effort seeks to overcome historical failures in regional cooperation and reduce vulnerabilities, particularly concerning Russian influence, by developing north-south infrastructure links. While facing challenges in funding and skepticism from some EU members, the initiative has gained support from the US and is working to secure EU backing and investment for numerous proposed projects.

title: 6 Insights From Chevron’s Retail Convention
summary: Chevron's 2018 Retail Convention highlighted the company's commitment to the convenience-gas format. Key announcements included the expansion of the ExtraMile c-store network, new partnerships with PayPal and Honda for mobile payments, and the reinforcement of its Techron additive branding. The convention also covered the "Fuel Your School" program and the positive outlook for liquid fuels and retail growth.

title: Photos: Tour Chevron's former Bellaire campus available for lease
summary: Chevron's former Bellaire campus, located at 4800 Fournace, is now available for lease after the company vacated the property in 2017. Chevron invested nearly $100 million in capital improvements into the campus since 2005 before relocating its employees to other Houston locations.

title: Nigerian Oil Union Sees Chevron Job Dispute Ending in a Week
summary: A Nigerian oil labor union expects a resolution within a week regarding a job dispute with Chevron Corp. over planned layoffs. Talks between the union, Chevron, and Nigeria's Ministry of Labour and Employment concluded cordially on Friday. The union, Pengassan, had previously warned of a national strike if Chevron's decision to fire thousands of workers was not reversed.

title: Chevron Phillips Chemical Receives $38,190 in Incentives
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP received a $38,190 incentive check from Entergy Texas, Inc. for implementing energy efficiency upgrades at its headquarters in The Woodlands. These upgrades, part of the Entergy Solutions program, included a new HVAC system with an auxiliary chiller, variable frequency drives, and enhanced automation, expected to save the company an estimated $7,620 annually in energy costs. The project aims to reduce energy usage and lessen the company's carbon footprint.

title: Fracking made the U.S. a major oil producer, but not energy independent
summary: Journalist Bethany McLean discusses her book "Saudi America" which explores the nuanced success of fracking, arguing that while it made the U.S. a major oil producer, it didn't lead to energy independence. She highlights that capital, rather than chemicals, is the key ingredient in fracking and that the industry's financial fragility makes the concept of energy independence illusory due to global oil pricing.

title: Arvin CA acts to protect residents from oil and gas
summary: The City of Arvin, CA, passed a setback ordinance on July 17, 2018, restricting new oil and gas wells within 300 feet of residential and commercial areas, marking the first such policy in an oil-producing California county. This achievement was supported by Earthworks' documentation of methane and VOC pollution at existing well sites using optical gas imaging. The article highlights the ongoing struggle against the oil and gas industry's influence in California and the need for further action to address existing wells and emissions.

title: Chevron wins Ecuador rainforest 'oil dumping' case
summary: An international tribunal in The Hague has ruled in favor of Chevron in an environmental dispute with Ecuador, overturning a previous $9.5 billion compensation order. The ruling stated that the 2011 Ecuador Supreme Court decision was obtained through fraud, bribery, and corruption. Chevron may now be awarded hundreds of millions of dollars in costs.

title: Transocean to buy Ocean Rig in $2.7 billion deal
summary: Transocean Ltd announced its acquisition of Ocean Rig UDW Inc in a $2.7 billion cash-and-stock deal, marking its second major acquisition this year. This move signals renewed optimism in the offshore drilling sector following a recovery in global oil prices. The deal is expected to provide Transocean with nine ultra-deepwater drillships and two semisubmersibles, alongside projected annual cost savings.

title: Canadian Natural Resources buys Joslyn oilsands project for $225M
summary: Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. has signed a deal to acquire the Joslyn oilsands project from Total SA and its partners for $225 million. The purchase involves a $100 million cash payment on closing, followed by five annual payments of $25 million. The Joslyn project, previously put on hold, is located directly south of Canadian Natural's Horizon Project.

title: Venezuela agrees to pay $2 billion over seizure of oil projects
summary: Venezuela's state oil company, PDVSA, has agreed to pay ConocoPhillips $2 billion as a settlement for the seizure of its oil projects more than a decade ago. The agreement, which allows PDVSA to pay over nearly five years, came after ConocoPhillips seized Venezuelan oil assets, impacting the country's exports. This settlement helps resolve one legal dispute, though ConocoPhillips is pursuing another arbitration case that could lead to a larger award.

title: DTE breaks ground on St. Clair Co. electricity power plant
summary: DTE Energy is making preparations to begin constructing its new $1-billion Blue Water Energy Center, a natural-gas power plant in St. Clair County, Michigan. This plant, DTE's first since 1984, will generate 1,150 megawatts of electricity for 850,000 homes and is expected to be 70% cleaner and 40% more efficient than the coal-fired plants it will replace. The project aligns with DTE's commitment to reduce carbon emissions and invest in cleaner energy sources, despite previous environmental group criticisms regarding renewable energy usage.

title: Chevron Petroleum Company Colombia (Chevron Colombia)
summary: Chevron Petroleum Company Colombia (Chevron Colombia) operates primarily in the Oil & Gas sector in Colombia, focusing on E&P, marketing, and retail activities. The company, in partnership with Ecopetrol, operates significant natural gas fields like Chuchupa offshore and Ballena onshore, contributing significantly to Colombia's natural gas supply. Chevron Colombia was established in 1926 and is based in Bogotá.

title: BP pays $10.5 billion for BHP shale assets to beef up U.S. business
summary: BP has agreed to acquire U.S. shale oil and gas assets from BHP Billiton for $10.5 billion, marking its largest deal in nearly two decades and significantly expanding its U.S. onshore footprint. This acquisition is seen as a transformational step for BP, allowing the company to increase its quarterly dividend and announce a $6 billion share buyback. The sale concludes BHP's challenging seven-year venture into shale, with proceeds to be returned to shareholders.

title: BP pays $10.5 billion for BHP shale assets to beef up US business
summary: BP has acquired U.S. shale oil and gas assets from BHP Billiton for $10.5 billion, marking its largest deal in nearly two decades and a significant expansion of its onshore operations in the U.S. This acquisition is seen as a transformational step for BP following the Deepwater Horizon disaster, enabling the company to increase its U.S. onshore oil and gas resources by 57% and boost earnings and cash flow per share. BHP plans to return the sale proceeds to shareholders, ending its seven-year investment in the shale business which had faced pressure from investors.

title: A year in, CP Chem's CEO has growth in mind
summary: Mark Lashier, CEO of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LLC, led the company through its Hurricane Harvey recovery shortly after his appointment. The article discusses his leadership and future plans for the company.

title: Texas Company Opens Gas Stations in Northern Mexico
summary: Texas-based Phillips 66, through its licensee Windstar, has opened its first 76 gas stations in northern Mexico as a result of Mexico's energy reform act. This move signifies increased competition in the Mexican gasoline market, despite potential policy reviews by Mexico's new president. Windstar plans aggressive expansion, with more stations opening soon and many more planned for Sonora by year-end.

title: The U.S. natural gas industry is leaking way more methane than previously thought
summary: A new study, synthesizing five years of research, suggests that methane emissions from U.S. oil and gas operations are significantly higher than current EPA estimates, with a leak rate of 2.3 percent compared to the EPA's 1.4 percent. This 60 percent difference has profound climate consequences given methane's potency as a greenhouse gas. The article highlights that while natural gas has climate benefits over coal, these benefits are reduced by leakage and could be far greater with lower leak rates.

title: Loews Taking Over Boardwalk, in Line with Peers After FERC MLP Ruling
summary: Loews Corp. announced its plan to acquire the remaining stake in its subsidiary Boardwalk Pipeline Partners LP for an estimated $1.5 billion, following a trend among pipeline operators to take over their master limited partnerships (MLPs) due to changes in federal law. This move comes after a FERC ruling reversed tax benefits for MLPs, prompting Loews to consider that publicly traded MLP status would materially decrease Boardwalk's maximum applicable rates. The acquisition aims to simplify Boardwalk's corporate structure, ending its public trading on the NYSE.

title: A Threat to Shale’s Dominance Emerges 200 Miles off the Gulf Coast
summary: A quiet revolution is occurring in offshore drilling, potentially challenging shale's dominance. Despite the high costs and technical challenges associated with deep-water oil production, companies like Chevron Corp., Royal Dutch Shell Plc, and BP Plc have made their offshore operations leaner and safer after navigating significant industry setbacks. This newfound efficiency could signal a resurgence for deep-water drilling.

title: Kosmos Energy Provides Update on Exploration Drilling Program Offshore Suriname
summary: Kosmos Energy announced the completion of the Anapai-1A exploration well offshore Suriname, which encountered high-quality reservoirs but no hydrocarbons. Despite this, the company plans to proceed with its drilling program, moving to test the Pontoenoe prospect in Block 42, which is similar to successful discoveries in Guyana. Kosmos operates blocks 45 and 42 with partners Chevron and Hess.

title: Syncrude Canada crude production offline through July -spokesman
summary: Syncrude Canada's oil sands facility, capable of producing up to 360,000 barrels per day, is offline at least through July following a power outage. This shutdown is expected to open up pipeline capacity for other Western Canada oil producers, potentially reducing the discount on Canadian heavy crude. Syncrude, a joint venture primarily owned by Suncor Energy Inc and Imperial Oil Ltd, is investigating the cause of the power transformer trip.

title: Empire Petroleum Picks Up Willoughby's Wholesale Distribution Business
summary: Empire Petroleum Partners LLC acquired the wholesale distribution business of Willoughby Inc., expanding Empire's presence in Tennessee, Mississippi, and Arkansas. This acquisition adds over 120 new dealer customers and strengthens Empire's relationships with major fuel brands. David Willoughby, former owner, will now focus on the growth of his transportation and commercial business.

title: Behind the deal: What's in store for Chevron's latest venture capital fund
summary: This article discusses Chevron's latest venture capital fund through its Chevron Technology Ventures arm. Barbara Burger, president of Chevron Technology Ventures, explains that the fund seeks opportunities with direct intersection to Chevron's current business and makes strategic bets on the future energy landscape. It highlights the dual focus of the VC fund on immediate business relevance and long-term energy trends.

title: Chevron names Brazil chief to lead Venezuela operations after arrests
summary: Chevron Corp has appointed Javier La Rosa, its Brazil country chief, to lead its Venezuelan operations following the detention and subsequent release of two executives. This move comes amid deepening tensions between foreign oil firms and Venezuela's government as its political and economic crisis worsens. La Rosa previously headed Chevron's Venezuelan commercial operations and his appointment follows a significant oil deal for Chevron in Brazil.

title: Pioneers in petroleum: Meet Chevron's two new female VPs
summary: Chevron has appointed Kim McHugh and Liz Schwarze as its newest Vice Presidents, making them the first women to hold their respective roles within the company. Both executives are based in downtown Houston. This move highlights a changing landscape in the energy industry regarding female leadership.

title: Chevron promotes first females to exploration, drilling and completions VP roles
summary: Chevron Corp. has promoted Liz Schwarze and Kim McHugh to Vice President roles in exploration, and drilling and completions, respectively. These promotions mark the first time females have held these positions at Chevron. Both newly appointed Vice Presidents will be based in Chevron's downtown Houston office.

title: Tap Oil, partners drill appraisal well at Manora in Thailand
summary: Tap Oil Ltd. reported successful results from its Manora-8ST1 appraisal well offshore Gulf of Thailand, encountering multiple oil-bearing zones with a combined net pay of 307 ft. These finds are considered new contingent resources and the information will be used by Tap Oil to fend off a takeover bid from Risco Energy Investments. The well has been abandoned, and the rig will move on to a two-well development drilling program.

title: Multifunctional H2S Scavenger and Corrosion Inhibitor
summary: This technical paper discusses the development and field testing of a novel multifunctional chemical capable of scavenging H2S and inhibiting corrosion in subsea oil and gas production. The solution, which incorporates ethylenedioxy(dimethanol) (EDDM) into an existing corrosion inhibitor, enables higher production rates from sour fields without modifications to existing infrastructure. The development aims to manage reservoir souring risks and reduce operational expenditure associated with H2S.

title: Cheniere Energy formally approves third LNG unit at South Texas plant
summary: Cheniere Energy Inc. has formally approved the construction of a third liquefaction unit at its South Texas export terminal, marking the first new U.S. LNG project approved since 2015. This expansion reinforces Cheniere's leadership in the U.S. LNG market and is driven by significant global demand. The United States is projected to become the third-largest LNG exporter by 2020.

title: 3 Great Dividend-Growth Funds
summary: This article highlights three dividend-growth funds recommended by Morningstar analysts, focusing on their investment strategies and key characteristics. It features Hartford Dividend and Growth A (IHGIX), T. Rowe Price Dividend Growth (PRDGX), and Vanguard Dividend Appreciation Fund, discussing their management approaches, risk profiles, and performance in various market conditions. The funds are presented as excellent core holdings for investors seeking companies with a history of increasing dividends.

title: Chevron, Richmond Reach $5 Million Settlement Over Refinery Fire
summary: The city of Richmond and Chevron Corp. have agreed to a $5 million settlement in a lawsuit stemming from a 2012 refinery fire that caused a large plume of smoke and resulted in 15,000 people seeking medical treatment. The agreement concludes the city's 2013 lawsuit, with funds to be used for public safety, education, parks, recreation, and community development. Both parties acknowledge Chevron's efforts to enhance refinery safety and cleaner operations.

title: Oklahoma oil industry gains new focus
summary: The Oklahoma oil industry is shifting its focus from increasing production to improving financial health by repaying debt, generating free cash flow, and returning value to shareholders. Following a significant downturn, companies like Chesapeake, Continental Resources, and Devon Energy are prioritizing financial responsibility and drilling only the most profitable wells. This new strategy addresses Wall Street's demands and aims to stabilize stock prices in a volatile market.

title: Chevron, Richmond Settle Lawsuit Over 2012 Refinery Fire
summary: Chevron Corp. has agreed to pay the city of Richmond $5 million to settle a lawsuit stemming from a 2012 refinery fire that sickened thousands of residents. The Richmond City Council approved the settlement, though some critics, including former Mayor Gayle McLaughlin and Councilwoman Jovanka Beckles, argue the amount is too low and that the deal includes no refinery reforms. The fire was caused by a corroded pipe, leading to significant citations and new regulations for refinery safety.

title: Exxon or Chevron? This analyst says there’s one stock to pick
summary: Barclays analysts, led by Paul Cheng, recommend Chevron over Exxon Mobil Corp. despite both reporting mixed first-quarter results. The preference for Chevron stems from a "structural deterioration" in Exxon's project portfolio. They anticipate Chevron's first-quarter results will positively impact its shares.

title: ConocoPhillips Awarded US$2bn for 2007 Oil Field Expropriation, Venezuela Claims Victory
summary: The International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) has ordered Venezuela's national oil company, PDVSA, to pay ConocoPhillips US$2.04 billion for the 2007 expropriation of its oil field assets. Venezuela claims victory despite the significant payout, stating the award is less than what was originally offered by Chavez and a small fraction of what ConocoPhillips sought. The ruling raises questions about enforcement given Venezuela's economic situation and PDVSA's declining oil production.

title: Chevron evacuates Venezuela executives following staff arrests
summary: U.S. oil major Chevron Corp has evacuated executives from Venezuela after two of its workers were imprisoned over a contract dispute with state-owned oil company PDVSA. The arrests are part of a broader government anti-corruption probe, creating difficult conditions for foreign oil firms operating in the country. Chevron, which has no plans to exit Venezuela, is facing escalating tensions and production declines in its joint ventures with PDVSA.

title: Sources: Arrested Chevron Workers Could Face Treason Charge in Venezuela
summary: Two Chevron Corp. employees arrested in Venezuela last week could face treason charges for refusing to sign a supply contract for a joint venture with PDVSA that listed parts at more than double their market price. This incident marks a significant escalation in tensions between PDVSA and foreign companies amid a deepening economic crisis and corruption purge in Venezuela. The arrests highlight growing difficulties for foreign oil firms operating in the country and raise concerns about due process and legal protections for individuals accused of treason.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Valero Revamps Branded Station Design
summary: Valero Energy Corp. is introducing a new branded station design called Vanguard, which will offer a fresh, contemporary look for marketers and distributors, strengthening customer loyalty in the U.S. and allowing for expansion into international markets like Mexico. The design was the favorite among consumers in a national survey and is expected to be available in the second quarter of 2018, representing a significant investment in the Valero brand. The new design was created by Antista Fairclough, a firm that has provided design expertise to Valero for over 13 years.

title: CBC goes to court to get Chevron to unseal documents in $9.5B US environmental battle
summary: CBC News has filed a motion to the Ontario Superior Court of Justice to unseal court records in Chevron's decades-long environmental battle with 30,000 Indigenous Ecuadorian villagers. This legal dispute, stemming from alleged oil contamination, involves arguments over Chevron Canada's responsibility for its parent company's judgment and the enforceability of an Ecuadorian court ruling. The CBC aims to ensure public access to information regarding corporate behavior and environmental impact.

title: Chevron case heads to Court of Appeal again
summary: Third parties, including the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and a group of NGOs, are seeking to unseal court documents in a long-running case concerning the enforcement of a US$9.5-billion Ecuadorian judgment against Chevron Corp. via its Canadian subsidiary in Ontario. The Court of Appeal will hear the appeal, which focuses on whether Chevron Canada's assets can be seized to satisfy the judgment, thereby potentially piercing the corporate veil. This case holds significant implications for corporate law regarding the enforceability of foreign judgments against related companies.

title: California Resources Corp. Buys Remaining Stake in Natural Gas Oil Field
summary: California Resources Corp. acquired the remaining surface and mineral rights to the Elk Hill Oil Field from Chevron Corp. for $460 million and 2.85 million of its common shares. This acquisition led to a 13% rise in CRC's shares and is expected to improve the company's cash flow and credit metrics. CRC has operated the Kern County field, which produced around 48,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day last year, for over 20 years.

title: ¿Quiénes son los dueños de la energía en Argentina?
summary: This article examines the dominant players in Argentina's energy sector, highlighting the rise of local private capital groups like Pampa Energía and Bridas. It details their expansion in electricity and hydrocarbons following the country's economic changes in the early 2000s, which led to the departure of many foreign companies. The article also touches on the current favorable business climate under the Macri government, which has benefited these national energy giants.

title: Dr. Peter C. Farrell, Ph.D., D.Sc., Presented with the Albert Nelson Marquis Lifetime Achievement Award by Marquis Who's Who
summary: Dr. Peter C. Farrell, Ph.D., D.Sc., founder and former CEO of ResMed, Inc., has been honored with the Albert Nelson Marquis Lifetime Achievement Award by Marquis Who's Who. The award recognizes Dr. Farrell's extensive professional achievements, leadership, and credentials in the healthcare industry, particularly his role in establishing ResMed as a global leader in connected health for sleep apnea and respiratory conditions. His career includes leadership roles at Baxter, academic tenure, and contributions to several medical technology companies and advisory boards.

title: OXY IN TALKS TO BUY CONOCOPHILLIPS’ CAMPUS
summary: Occidental Petroleum (Oxy) is reportedly in talks to acquire ConocoPhillips' 62-acre campus in Houston's Energy Corridor. ConocoPhillips plans to vacate the campus, which has been its home since the early 80s, to move to a leased building on the other side of I-10. Oxy's CEO Vicki Hollub informed employees about this unique opportunity to acquire a modern office campus.

title: Deepwater Oil Starting to Hold Its Own With Shale, Chevron Says
summary: Chevron is making deepwater oil discoveries competitive with shale by using existing platforms and reducing development costs, according to Executive Vice President Jay Johnson. Other industry leaders like Transocean CEO Jeremy Thigpen and National Oilwell Varco CEO Clay Williams also chimed in on deepwater's competitiveness and potential future supply squeezes. The strategy aims to make offshore exploration economically viable again amidst rising global crude demand.

title: Ocean Power Technologies Signs Agreement with Eni for PB3 PowerBuoy™
summary: Ocean Power Technologies (OPT) announced an agreement with Eni S.p.A., a multinational oil and gas company, to supply a PB3 PowerBuoy™ for demonstrating subsea oil and gas operations. The agreement includes a minimum 24-month contract for an 18-month lease, deployment support, and remote data collection. The PowerBuoy™ will be used in the Adriatic Sea to advance Eni's Clean Sea technology for marine environmental monitoring and offshore asset inspection using AUVs, with potential for subsea battery charging and a stand-alone charging station.

title: Millions Own Gas And Oil Under Their Land. Here's Why Only Some Strike It Rich
summary: Millions of American landowners receive royalties from gas and oil companies for resources under their property, a unique U.S. policy. However, a growing number accuse energy companies of shortchanging them due to complex laws and varying interpretations of lease agreements, particularly regarding post-production costs. This disparity leads to significant differences in the royalties landowners receive and has sparked numerous lawsuits and calls for legislative reform.

title: Chevron Phillips Chemical starts up Baytown ethane cracker
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. has begun operating its new ethane cracker in Baytown after delays caused by Hurricane Harvey, completing its $6 billion U.S. Gulf Coast petrochemicals project. This cracker is one of the largest and most energy-efficient in the world, capable of producing 3.3 billion pounds per year. The project, which also includes polyethylene units, is expected to create 400 permanent jobs.

title: Chevron Phillips Chemical starts up Baytown ethane cracker
summary: Chevron Phillips Chemical Co. has commenced operations at its new ethane cracker in Baytown, Texas, completing the final phase of its $6 billion U.S. Gulf Coast petrochemicals project. This significant startup follows previous phases of the project, which was initially announced in 2011. The article highlights several related developments, including construction campaigns and earlier partial completions of the project.

title: Crude Oil Price Cuts Loss Following Inventory Report
summary: Crude oil prices cut losses following the EIA report showing a 2.4 million barrel increase in U.S. commercial crude inventories. This increase was less than the API reported and below analysts' consensus estimates, prompting a slight recovery in WTI crude prices. U.S. crude production and exports continue to show significant increases, impacting market forecasts and the performance of related stocks and ETFs.

title: Empire Petroleum acquires distribution contracts from Keeman
summary: Empire Petroleum Partners has acquired the wholesale distribution rights of Keeman Petroleum Company, a Valdosta, Georgia-based distributor. This acquisition strengthens Empire's regional presence in South Georgia and enhances existing partnerships with Citgo and Chevron, providing significant growth opportunities in the southern part of the state. Empire's Vice President of Mergers & Acquisition, Michael O'Brien, highlighted the strategic importance of adding Keeman's dealer network.

title: Syngenta and Bunge Ventures Back South American Agribusiness Marketplace Agrofy
summary: Argentinian agribusiness marketplace Agrofy has raised an oversubscribed $6 million Series A round led by Sao Paulo Ventures, with participation from Bunge Ventures, Syngenta Ventures, and Endeavor Catalyst. The funding will be used to enhance the site's capabilities, broaden product supply, and launch new online payment solutions and agribusiness categories. The company aims to collaborate with large corporate partners to build a supportive platform for e-commerce in the agricultural sector, particularly in Latin America.

title: Global Company a Key Local Partner
summary: Sherwin Williams is adapting its strategy in Mexico's oil and gas industry following market liberalization, shifting from solely serving PEMEX to partnering with new companies entering the country. The company sees significant market opportunities in the midstream sector, emphasizing its products' performance, durability, and features like quick curing and fire protection, and has strengthened its presence through the acquisition of Valspar. Sherwin Williams aims to be a key local partner for the evolving industry, leveraging its global presence and specialized solutions across the value chain.

title: Basement fire in downtown Houston Chevron building leads to evacuation (KHOU video)
authors: By KHOU - HBJ television news partner
summary: The Chevron building in downtown Houston at 1500 Louisiana St. was evacuated on February 28, 2018, due to a basement fire. There was a potential risk of the fire spreading to the downtown tunnel system, though this did not occur. The article also lists several related articles concerning Chevron and other local companies.

title: Suncor Energy files application for 160,000-bpd Lewis oilsands project
summary: Suncor Energy has filed an application for its new Lewis oilsands project, a 160,000-barrels-per-day steam-based operation north of Fort McMurray. This $6.2-billion project aims to replace production from Suncor's aging mining operations, with construction slated to begin in 2024 and oil production by 2027. The move demonstrates Suncor's continued commitment to oilsands despite expectations of slowing growth in the sector.

title: Hess Finalises Ghana Divestment, Exits Africa…
summary: Hess Corporation has finalized its divestment in Ghana with a $100 Million sale of its stake to Norway's Aker Energy, effectively exiting Africa with the exception of an uncertain operation in Libya. This move follows its departure from Equatorial Guinea and is part of a broader trend of Western independents reducing their African portfolios due to the 2014 crude oil price crash. Hess reported a net loss of $2.677 Billion in Q4 2017 and is now focusing on onshore U.S. shale and its stake in ExxonMobil's Guyana discovery.

title: Exxon Mobil claims its foes are conspiring against it
summary: Exxon Mobil is employing aggressive legal tactics against lawyers, public officials, and environmental activists who are suing the company over climate change. The oil giant claims these groups are engaged in a "conspiracy" under a strategy it calls "The La Jolla playbook." Critics argue Exxon Mobil's actions are a scare tactic aimed at intimidating opponents and shifting blame away from allegations of environmental damage.

title: Crude Oil Price Stumbles on Big Additions to Oil, Refined Products Stockpiles
summary: The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) reported a 1.9 million barrel increase in commercial crude inventories last week, contributing to a slump in West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude prices. This build was driven by higher U.S. crude production, which reached 10.25 million barrels a day, and a decrease in exports. While the market speculates on whether this is a temporary blip or the start of a longer-term price decline, major oil stocks like Exxon Mobil and Chevron showed mixed reactions after the report.

title: How to Make Big Profits When Oil Stocks Struggle
summary: Despite oil prices remaining steady, oil stocks have been struggling, falling more than twice as much as the overall market. The Direxion Daily S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production Bear 3X ETF (DRIP) offers a way to profit from this downturn, as it is designed to move three times higher when the SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (XOP) falls. However, investors should be aware of the increased risk associated with this leveraged ETF.

title: Chevron mulling participation in Brazil's March oil auction
summary: Chevron Corp is considering joining a consortium to participate in Brazil's upcoming oil auction on March 29, which will offer 70 blocks. This move indicates Chevron's intent to increase its output in Brazil, despite not participating in a previous October auction, and follows a preliminary agreement to drill six wells in an offshore field.

title: DoubleLine's Gundlach still betting on commodities
summary: DoubleLine CEO Jeffrey Gundlach stated he expects commodities to continue to outperform stocks, noting that global growth is driving demand and a weaker U.S. dollar is helping. He highlighted his belief in a cyclical pattern where commodities are currently poised for outperformance against stocks. While Gundlach did not comment on oil prices, his Deputy CIO Jeffrey Sherman noted structural support for current oil prices and the attractiveness of the energy market.

title: Baker Hughes GE and Nvidia team up on AI for the oil and gas industries
summary: Baker Hughes GE and Nvidia are collaborating to bring artificial intelligence and data analytics to the oil and gas industries. Their initiative aims to enhance efficiency and predictability by analyzing data from drilling operations, seismic activity, and sensors using Nvidia's GPU-powered systems. This partnership will leverage Nvidia's AI expertise with Baker Hughes GE's domain knowledge to create new models and cloud-based tools for improved fault detection, diagnostics, and operational optimization in the energy sector.

title: Halliburton posts better-than-expected Q4 on higher oil prices
summary: Halliburton Co reported a better-than-expected fourth-quarter profit and gave an optimistic outlook for 2018, driven by higher oil prices boosting US production and demand for oilfield services. The company's results, along with those of Schlumberger, indicate a broader oil and gas recovery extending beyond US onshore operations to international markets. Halliburton also disclosed a $385 million charge for its Venezuelan operations but remains optimistic about North American activity and international demand.

title: 5 missing after Oklahoma oil and gas drilling site explosion
summary: Five workers are missing after a fiery explosion at an oil and gas drilling site in eastern Oklahoma, where the fire was fed by gas from a well being drilled. The incident is the latest in a series of accidents in the state's oil and gas fields. The cause of the well explosion remains unclear, and authorities are investigating.

title: You’ll Want to Read This Living Legend’s Thoughts On Copper
summary: This article features an interview with Robert Friedland, founder of Ivanhoe Mines, discussing the future of copper and other industrial metals in the context of electric vehicles and clean energy. Friedland highlights his Kamoa-Kakula Copper Project, predicting significant demand for copper and other metals as global electrification accelerates. The piece also touches on China and India's efforts to clean up their environments and the broader energy transition.

title: This Oil Major Has a Supercomputer the Size of a Soccer Field
summary: Italian oil company Eni SpA has built a supercomputer the size of a soccer field near Milan to scan for oil and gas reservoirs. This investment highlights the trend of "Big Oil becoming Big Tech" as companies use advanced computing to fast-track discoveries and reduce costly drilling errors. The company believes this new machine makes it a leader in powerful computing for exploration.

title: Chevron Plans to Return to Iraq's Kurdistan
summary: Chevron Corp. plans to resume drilling in Iraq's Kurdistan region after temporarily halting operations in October. The U.S. oil major will drill the Sarta 3 well north of Erbil as tensions between the semi-autonomous region and the federal government abate.

title: Borr Drilling
summary: Borr Drilling aims to revolutionize the oil and gas contract drilling industry with a new commercial model and modern fleet of jack-up rigs. Founded by Tor Olav Trøim, the company emphasizes aligning its goals with clients, a young fleet, and a service-based payment structure. CEO Simon Johnson highlights their focus on shareholder value, strategic partnerships, and a belief that the industry needs consolidation for better operational practices and efficiency.
